going...going...gone! ep hemlocke springs pop/r&b the zany, ’80s-inspired debut from the 24-year-old pop singer and tiktok star showcases a promising young artist in the age of internet virality.

changing channels pangaea electronic the hessle audio cofounder’s exuberant new album is stuffed with high bpms, ribcage-vibrating basslines, and richly hued synths. club music this banging is rarely so nuanced.
out and about lewsberg rock the rotterdam quartet makes sparse yet atmospheric post-punk that draws inspiration from all things dreamy and twee.

javelin sufjan stevens folk/country sufjan’s masterful new album recalls his intimate singer-songwriter days. but it also draws on his entire catalog, his dazzling musicality, and his lifelong inquiries about love and devotion.
i don’t want you anymore cherry glazerr rock clementine creevy sifts through the muck on her new album, picking up everything from radio-friendly electro-pop to fuzzed-out garage rock.
hot fruit adeline hotel folk/country acoustic guitarist dan knishkowy is joined by an improvisational quartet for an album of autumnal instrumental folk that meditates on self-knowledge and change.

gettin’ it (album number ten) too $hort rap each sunday, pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. today we revisit the oakland rapper’s imperial ’90s peak with the dangerous crew, a slick and funky landmark of pimp rap.

the nid tapes: electronic music from india 1969​-​1972 various artists gathering vintage compositions from 27 tape reels, this expansive new collection highlights the brief but fertile period, more than 50 years ago, when avant-garde electronic music took root in india.
perfect picture hannah diamond pop/r&b soundtracked by euphoric bubblegum synth, the pc music star takes a deep dive into two-dimensionality.
for all the dogs drake rap on his eighth album, a skillful drake struggles to keep it interesting. his familiar concerns, while occasionally sincere or funny, have become quite boring.

next door leo takami jazz the tokyo guitarist and pianist channels jazz, fusion, and japanese environmental music as he deepens the emotional resonance of his music while maintaining its soothing atmosphere.
falling or flying jorja smith pop/r&b the uk singer’s earthy, sumptuous new album explores her ambivalent relationship to fame. it soars when it lets loose.
nothing lasts forever teenage fanclub rock the scottish power-pop band keeps things light on an album distinguished by subtle touches and twilight grooves.
what is my capacity to love? ep thanks for coming rock the water from your eyes vocalist’s new solo ep is a collection of charming, heartfelt bedroom pop songs that deserve to be more fully realized.

no fixed point in space modern nature rock, experimental featuring players from spiritualized and the necks, the hushed third album from jack cooper’s chamber-improv ensemble slots into a lineage of exploratory groups fusing folk, psych, and post-rock.

again oneohtrix point never experimental daniel lopatin returns with a nostalgic jam session full of proggy synth passages and ’90s alt-rock touches. it leaves a lot to admire but a little less to think about.

we buy diabetic test strips armand hammer rap the duo of elucid and billy woods delivers a moody, unsettling, sharply observed album balancing moments of self-reflection with vivid snapshots of societal dysfunction.

shone a rainbow light on setting electronic, experimental multi-instrumentalists nathan bowles, jaime fennelly, and joe westerlund combine forces on textured, stormy folk compositions that encourage deeper listening.

dissolution grip kmru electronic, experimental the prolific kenyan-born, berlin-based electronic musician departs from his typical use of field recordings, but environmental sound still makes its mark on his immersive, long-form explorations.
arepa mixtape mj nebreda pop/r&b the miami producer and vocalist’s expertly curated, shamelessly horny new mixtape revels in reggaeton’s queer and femme club underground.
debbie’s son maxo rap the los angeles rapper’s second album this year confronts the uncertainties of life with characteristically reflective rhymes and a steely new determination.
yard slow pulp rock the chicago band motors through big emotions with clear-eyed sincerity, bubblegum hooks, and mellow arrangements that feel like a warm embrace.
rustin’ in the rain tyler childers folk/country the kentucky songwriter surveys the past, present, and future of country music on a thoughtful new record with deep roots.
strange disciple nation of language rock the brooklyn synth-pop trio expands its signature sound on its surprisingly idiosyncratic third album.

faith is a rock mike rap the new york rappers team up with the legendary producer for their first full-length collaboration. over his thick, sample-heavy beats, mike and wiki brandish a natural chemistry that feels like it’s existed for decades.
chai chai rock the japanese quartet evolve their perspective and sound, exploring the decadent grooves of city pop as they contend with growing up.
signs purelink electronic the chicago trio excels in precisely detailed ambient dub with just the right amount of reverence for turn-of-the-millennium avant-garde electronic music.
gentle confrontation loraine james electronic on her third album for hyperdub, the uk experimental musician uses chaotic arrangements and glitchy drums to express knotty, difficult-to-name emotions.
cousin wilco rock with help from producer cate le bon, the chicago band’s 13th album flickers to life on several songs that hint at the controlled chaos of their bygone experimental era.

isn’t it now? animal collective experimental on what feels like a companion to , animal collective explore some surprisingly traditional psych-rock modes, but without abandoning their essential trickster spirit.

who’s next : life house (super deluxe) the who rock an exhaustively comprehensive 11-disc box set explores a defining work by the classic rock band alongside the ambitious, shelved concept album that would become pete townshend's white whale.

the breakthrough mary j. blige pop/r&b each sunday, pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. today we revisit a blockbuster r&b comeback record from 2005, an unofficial marker of a more self-actualized mary j. blige.
sit down for dinner blonde redhead rock on their first album in nearly a decade, and following a wave of viral resurgence, the nyc avant-rock vets return with their warmest, most welcoming music yet.
heaven cleo sol pop/r&b the sault vocalist’s new album explores faith and self-love through warm, lustrous neo-soul.
trifecta 3: the finale shittyboyz rap on the final installment of their series, the detroit rap trio delivers quotable after quotable. it’s cocksure and playful, like a high school lunchroom cipher.
karaoke night ep soccer mommy rock on her new ep, sophie allison rents out a room just for herself, singing covers of taylor swift, pavement, sheryl crow, and more.

softscars yeule pop/r&b on their riveting new album, the 25-year-old singer-songwriter-producer shifts from future-shocked electronic pop to a super-sized emotional bloodletting steeped in ’90s alternative.

tim (let it bleed edition) the replacements rock this deluxe reissue is the holy grail that fans of have dreamt of: a new mix that instantly becomes the best and most definitive album in the replacements’ catalog.

one night stand! live at the harlem square club, 1963 sam cooke pop/r&b each sunday, pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. today we revisit a monumental artifact of soul—one of the best live albums of all time, from the singer who wrote the 20th century’s defining civil rights anthem.
v föllakzoid rock the chilean band journeys through icy, alien frontiers on their mesmerizing new album.
flying wig devendra banhart folk/country, experimental the venezuelan singer-songwriter’s 11th album tackles grief and melancholia with the kind of endearing eccentricity only he can.

la planète sauvage (expanded original soundtrack) alain goraguer jazz this score to the 1973 sci-fi film was sampled by generations of hip-hop luminaries. reissued for its 50th anniversary, it remains a dazzlingly avant-garde fusion of styles and moods.

atlas laurel halo electronic the experimental artist’s fifth solo album is among her best, a beautiful collection of minimalist ambient compositions in which no line extends for long without dissolving into an inky blot.
scarlet doja cat rap, pop/r&b in proving herself as a rapper, doja cat offers up an uneven album that is accomplished but gets bogged down in reactive and repetitive songs.

the rise and fall of a midwest princess chappell roan pop/r&b the pop singer’s full-length debut is a bold and uproarious introduction, buoyed by sturdy songcraft and steely indifference to good taste.
powders eartheater experimental the experimental musician’s radiant new album explores love’s rapture within the confines of more traditional pop structures.
postcards from italia ep mykki blanco rap drawing on the sounds of ’90s eurodance and classic rock’n’roll, these six songs are light, lush, and streaked with melancholy.
the enduring spirit tomb mold metal the toronto death metal band returns with its best album yet: an ambitious and deeply human suite that touches the sublime.

destiny dj sabrina the teenage dj pop/r&b, electronic the pseudonymous london producer’s new album is a radiant, elastic, nearly four-hour celebration of the transportive possibilities of dance music.
the beach album eli escobar electronic the new york nightlife veteran’s new album chronicles pandemic survival in the city and the difficult joy that’s followed.

dreams of a dancefloor ep octo octa electronic the new hampshire dj folds multiple influences—trance, drum’n’bass, breaks, acid, deep house—into shape-shifting tracks that mimic the flow of an ecstatic night of dancing.
supernova ralphie choo experimental the spanish artist’s debut cuts and pastes from r&b, hip-hop, reggaeton, and flamenco. it’s bizarre and incongruous—but oddly satisfying.
stone baroness metal for the first time ever, the southern metal expats return with the same lineup as their previous album. a little outside input could’ve gone a long way.

diamonds lil peep rap lil peep and ilovemakonnen’s collaborative album reflects the kinship they share as pop outsiders and queer rappers. it’s the rare posthumous rap album that actually honors an artist’s legacy.
sorry i haven’t called vagabon rock laetitia tamko’s bright, dewy electro-pop album depicts growing up with candor and levity.
tension kylie minogue pop/r&b kylie minogue’s most relaxed album in years is a compendium of all the sounds she’s best known for: confectionary synth-pop, breezy euro house, and propulsive edm.

nothing’s gonna stand in my way again lydia loveless folk/country the alt-country songwriter’s sixth album sits at the eye of the storm, matching a softer, more measured sound with a wryly humorous look at existential turmoil.
world of hassle alan palomo electronic on his first album under his own name, the artist behind neon indian returns with the funniest and most musically accomplished songs of his career.

66689 blvd prequel kipp stone rap the cleveland rapper’s quietly intense new album is fueled by the constant churn of unrelenting self-examination, but that heaviness is offset by his nimble, natural flow.

black rainbows corinne bailey rae pop/r&b the english singer-songwriter takes a scuzzy, loud, and political left turn on her gutsy fourth album. it sounds like a departure but feels like a renaissance.
pretty girls love slizzy cash cobain rap the bronx rapper’s bluntness and playful ear for beats gives his sex-obsessed songs the nonchalance of a one-night stand.

bird machine sparklehorse rock in the year before he died, mark linkous hit the studio with steve albini. fourteen years later, those unreleased sessions reveal a bittersweet cocktail of beauty and torment.

the land is inhospitable and so are we mitski rock after contemplating retirement, mitski returns with a new album that’s warmer, quieter, and more organic-sounding. for the first time in a while, she sounds like she has space to breathe.

time (the revelator) gillian welch folk/country each sunday, pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past. today we revisit gillian welch and dave rawlings’ third album, an americana masterpiece whose prophecies reverberate through modern folk and indie rock.

pharoah pharoah sanders jazz this 1977 album was obscure in its day, but it spawned a fervent cult among fans of spiritual jazz, for good reason: the no-frills recording captures a feeling of unearthly magic.
all around you subsonic eye rock the singaporean band’s new album showcases a punchier indie rock sound and reinvigorated perspective on the environment.
smartwoods piotr kurek experimental in diaphanous compositions like color field paintings, this full-band ambient album conveys relaxation, whimsy, and a vague sense of dread.

born for greatness buju banton pop/r&b the reggae veteran’s new studio album doesn’t match the magic of his legacy. but when he’s not exploring grandiose thematic statements, he sounds as confident and impressive as ever.

messages to god sarah mary chadwick folk/country with flutes and instrumental flair, the new zealand singer-songwriter adds restless drama to her steadfast, plainspoken reflections on pain and personal growth.
protect your light irreversible entanglements jazz the free jazz collective takes a more patient and self-reflective approach to politics on their new album.
laugh track the national rock the national’s second album of 2023 extends its predecessor’s subdued mood and reclusive purview.
mid air romy electronic, pop/r&b hearkening back to her queer nightlife days, the xx singer and guitarist pays homage to the euphoric dance-pop of the 1990s and 2000s.

sidharth sid sriram pop/r&b, rock an indian film-music superstar raised on rap and indie, the 33-year-old singer taps bon iver’s justin vernon and producer ryan olson in the attempt to reconcile his transnational influences.

talàn raphael rogiński experimental in his sparse, instrumental style, the polish guitarist channels centuries of cultural exchange. his new album is slow and reverent, as if suspended in a different measurement of time.
bewitched laufey jazz tiktok’s favorite neoclassical jazz singer gives contemporary heartache a misty, out-of-time quality.
guts olivia rodrigo pop/r&b the pop star rocks out on her biting, charismatic second album, turning the ritual humiliations of girlhood into dazzling, over-the-top spectacles.
brand new soul angel du$t rock justice tripp has a blast channeling the affirming and aggressive spirit of southern california, even if it sounds a little stuck between stations.

hit parade róisín murphy pop/r&b, electronic the irish artist’s full-length collaboration with dj koze is a showcase of everything impressive about the musician sapped of the excitement that has historically made her work feel so vital.
how do you sleep at night? teezo touchdown rap on his debut, the suddenly inescapable singer goes looking for a mashup of texas rap, pop-punk, and r&b original enough to match his fashion sense.
citta’ ’93 les rallizes dénudés rock reissued by temporal drift, this recording of the mysterious japanese psych-rock band’s loud, legendary 1993 set at club citta’ is the best they’ve ever sounded.
drift gaika rap departing from his typically electronic palette, the uk musician’s new album plunges into a maze of contradictory influences drawn from dub, post-punk, and alt rock.
bb/ang3l tinashe pop/r&b at just seven songs, tinashe’s newest album is as stylish and focused as a runway walk.

teghnojoyg babe, terror electronic foregrounding sensory disorientation, clashing keys, and confounding meters, the brazilian musician’s sample-based music investigates the warping effects of cultural and political memory.
e3 midwxst rap the indiana artist’s debut album builds on his hyperpop, digicore, and rage rap roots, but positions him as a pop star in his own right.
through the window prewn rock the massachusetts songwriter’s ragged, tormented indie rock puts a surreal spin on the grim realities of life.
i’m so lucky spirit of the beehive rock after an intra-band breakup, the philly noise experimentalists return with a brief, focused ep that clears away some of their elaborate studio trickery.
careful! deeper rock on its third album, the chicago band continues to refine its strain of post-punk revivalism, trotting out familiar tropes while subtly pushing at the boundaries of its sound.

braintrust of fiends and werewolves alan courtis experimental on their first duo recording together, the veteran guitar improvisers find a shared language in slanted melodies and clouds of dissonance.

everything is alive slowdive rock since forming over three decades ago, the uk shoegaze band’s fifth album is the first to shoulder the weight of those years. the music is wispier, more skeletal, attuned to and aware of fading glories.
the king anjimile folk/country, experimental channeling old testament themes of righteous fury and justice, the indie-folk singer embraces a pared-back sound that only amplifies the drama.

techxodus speaker music electronic considering the gap between techno’s roots and its globalized, commercialized present, the writer, curator, and musician deforrest brown, jr., posits alternate futures for the genre.
come with fierce grace alabaster deplume jazz drawn from the same sessions as 2022’s , the uk jazz poet and saxophonist’s new album counters that record’s opulence with a spare, percussive sound.

music for kids the folk implosion experimental, rock a new compendium of music lou barlow and john davis created for the 1995 cult film brings a piece of prescient indie rock experimentation—and sleeper hit “natural one”—to streaming in full.

playing robots into heaven james blake pop/r&b the former dubstep balladeer and sometime pop super-producer returns to his electronic roots, working cut-up vocal samples into leftfield dancefloor material.

color me country linda martell folk/country each sunday, pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. today we revisit a groundbreaking 1970 album, a lovely but tragic record led by a pioneering force in country music.
bad news real bad man rap the california-based producer crew and indie rap icon’s first full-length collaboration isn’t revelatory, but it does show off their gifts as classicists.

the lamb as effigy or three hundred and fifty xoxoxos for a spark union with my darling divine sprain rock fueled by frontman alexander kent’s raging declamations, the los angeles band’s sprawling, 96-minute album is an incendiary fusion of noise, post-punk, metal, prog, and drone.

another triumph of ghetto engineering open mike eagle rap armed with advice for the next generation and lots of thank-you notes, open mike eagle’s funny and reflective ninth album seeks a sense of closure within his discography.
rabbit rabbit speedy ortiz rock on its fourth album, the philadelphia band lets it rip behind sadie dupuis’ knotty, mischievous songwriting.

trip9love…??? tirzah experimental tirzah and mica levi bore deeper into their strange and unique style of music. this time it is even more cramped and claustrophobic, a minefield of fitful rhythms and rain-filled craters.
hellmode jeff rosenstock rock working in a professional recording studio, the diy lifer goes big by going small. it’s the prettiest album he’s ever made—but it still gets you riled up.
zach bryan zach bryan folk/country the rising country star from oklahoma works with a traditionalist’s appreciation for songwriting and the intense, earnest emotion of heartland rock.
private recordings, august 1970 sylvester pop/r&b essential for superfans, this collection of sylvester’s earliest known recordings illuminates how he would become a disco superstar.
the window ratboys rock the chicago quartet swings big on a chris walla-produced album that brings unexpected grandeur to their modest, rootsy indie rock. it sounds like a breakthrough.

does it look like i’m here? (expanded remaster) emeralds electronic with seven additional tracks and a heba kadry remaster, the ambient synth experimentalists’ landmark album is even more transportive than it was in 2010.

sumday twunny grandaddy rock packaged with demos, outtakes, and a new remaster, this 20th anniversary box set presents the california indie band’s wide-open third album as a prescient meditation on the need to escape.

siamese dream the smashing pumpkins rock each sunday, pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. today we revisit the alternative titans’ 1993 album, where billy corgan discovered the larger-than-life sound that would reshape rock for decades to come.
intercepted message osees rock from synth pop to new wave to disco, the shapeshifting rock band goes all in on its keyboard album.
bite a giant dog rock on its first album in six years, the austin group dreams up an elaborate fictional universe and delivers it with swaggering glam-rock panache.
reset! ep ovrkast. rap on a short and sprightly ep, the up-and-coming oakland rapper and producer makes strides in both fields.

fly or die fly or die fly or die ((world war)) jaimie branch jazz the late trumpeter’s third and final album opens dazzling new paths in her work. it’s a heartbreaking glimpse of where she might have gone next, but more importantly, it’s a joy to hear.

yo no era así pero de ahora en adelante, sí diego raposo electronic, experimental the dominican producer takes a mischievous, electro-punk approach to genre fusions, mashing up the club, the rave, and the mosh pit.
voir dire earl sweatshirt rap the surprise album from an elite rapper-producer combo is lean and beautifully crafted. both make excellent use of each other’s light and shadow.

soul assassins 3: death valley dj muggs rap the latest tape in the west coast producer’s series is understated, but reveals how good he is at letting genre artists approach the best versions of themselves.
alive people ruth garbus rock recorded in front of a live audience, the latest from the brattleboro songwriter is a meditative, idiosyncratic set about the impermanence of all things.

an object in motion drab majesty rock written in the remote coastal town of yachats, oregon, the duo’s latest ep refashions its gloomy guitar pop as ecstatic shoegaze, complete with a cameo from slowdive’s rachel goswell.

i told them... burna boy rap, pop/r&b burna boy’s fifth album takes in the view from the top, fusing his adventurous pan-african pop with memories of 1990s hip-hop, advice from virgil abloh, and a little victory-lap stunting.
unfixed ep barker electronic after challenging himself to make music without kick drums, the berlin-based producer reverses course on an innovative, high-contrast new ep.

hold your horse is (deluxe reissue) hella experimental, rock the sacramento duo’s 2002 debut album might be the platonic ideal of math rock, but its real joy lies in the way it seems to escape the bounds of logic altogether.
ghetto cupid jaydes rap the florida teen rapper’s ambitious new project pulls together disparate strands, from plugg to shoegaze and emo balladry. it’s messy, but it works more often than not.
haunted mountain buck meek folk/country the fullest solo album yet from the big thief guitarist is an earnest ode to getting lost.

rocket power quavo rap on his first solo album since the death of takeoff, the migos rapper takes an uncharacteristically vulnerable approach, looking to his past successes and pushing tentatively forward.

echo the diamond margaret glaspy rock on her third album, the brooklyn musician scraps the synths and elaborate arrangements of her last lp, opting for a stripped-down combo and songs written as fast as the rush of feelings that inspired them.
jump for joy hiss golden messenger folk/country on a loosely conceptual project, the singer-songwriter finds his groove in smooth, soft-rock sounds and adolescent optimism.
spellling & the mystery school spellling experimental chrystia cabral gives her old highlights new studio arrangements, lending them the immediacy and clarity of live versions.
unreal unearth hozier rock the irish balladeer’s third album is a mishmash of mythology and past-date pop that leaves him sounding like an interloper.
el toro 2 est gee rap a too-cautious sequel to the louisville rapper’s breakthrough mixtape dangles fascinating production experiments but winds up returning to the script.
domino diners rock blue broderick’s new power pop record sets her gentle thoughts against the most immediate rock diners has ever attempted.
death is nothing to us fiddlehead rock on its third lp, the boston post-hardcore band completes a thematic trilogy about grief, depression, and the determination to move forward in the face of loss.

jaguar ii victoria monét pop/r&b the decorated pop songwriter arrives in the spotlight with a full-length debut whose plush r&b and live-band arrangements strike a tone that’s classic, sexy, and understated.
you’re the one rhiannon giddens folk/country on her first album of all original songs, the folk polyglot seeks livelier rhythms and vocal styles infused with jazz, country, and zydeco.

world music radio jon batiste jazz, pop/r&b the jazz multi-instrumentalist wants to unite the world in song. but his new album collapses the wide-ranging possibilities of global music into something for everyone and no one.
reset in dub panda bear electronic much as he did on last year’s remix of spoon’s , the storied dub producer uncovers a universe of detail lurking in the folds of the duo’s 2022 album .

lord of the shithouse draag me electronic spirit of the beehive members zack schwartz and corey wichlin shift styles on a collection of warped, dissonant pop with hairpin turns and an underlying unease.

resolve arnold dreyblatt experimental assisted by oren ambarchi, konrad sprenger, and joachim schütz, the iconoclastic instrument builder lays down a hypnotic set of minimalist, microtonal guitar music.

pontiac lyle lovett folk/country each sunday, pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. today we revisit the eclectic texan’s 1987 album, a terrific showcase of his subversive and idiosyncratic country style.
perfect saviors the armed rock the most mysterious group in hardcore pull back the curtain to reveal: a rock band. if their new album sounds like something you’d hear on alt radio, that’s the point.
epoch deyarmond edison rock an elaborate new box set explores the evolution of justin vernon’s early band through pivotal live sets, avant-americana studio experiments, and a formative solo album.

mr. greg & cass mccombs sing and play new folk songs for children mr. greg rock, folk/country on a set of originals for the hallowed folkways label, the california singer-songwriter and his pal, a bay area preschool teacher, know when to honor the past and when to break from it.
ontological mysterium horrendous metal the philadelphia death metal quartet has a blast on its fifth album, veering between styles with uninhibited energy and virtuosic musicianship.
live in brooklyn 2011 sonic youth rock dissolving three decades of music into a 17-song noise opera, this pivotal live album captures a peerless set from a band who knew its days were numbered.
phantasea pharm cumgirl8 rock the new york city quartet’s 4ad debut is an entrée to a world of scuzzy, lewd, electro-punk camp.
marquis key! rap the underground atlanta rap star teams with dj marc b, who backs his signature bouncy flows and silly punchlines with gleaming, thudding beats.

crazy trip ep tomu dj experimental the oakland producer finds a middle ground between her atmospheric tendencies and her more percussive productions, pairing raw, footwork-inspired drum loops with ethereal synths.
chthonic lea bertucci experimental an ominous blend of drones and field recordings, the two musicians’ debut collaboration plays out like a long-distance conversation about geologic time.
final boss icytwat rap the chicago rapper-producer’s new album blankets hedonistic flexes in a layer of frost.

keeping secrets will destroy you bonnie “prince” billy folk/country on his first solo album in four years, will oldham dispenses the wisdom of his life and the anxiety of his present into some of his most intimate and compelling musical settings.

deliverance andrew hung electronic the fuck buttons co-founder fills his latest solo album with familiar, quavering synth-pop, less concerned with exploring feelings than expressing what he’s feeling deeply.
electric ep easyfun the pc music producer’s first ep in eight years is a loving paean to the earnest euphoria of 2010s edm.
appetizer clip rap shielding vulnerability beneath layers of cranked-up bass, the brooklyn rapper and singer’s new tape is music for baddies who keep in touch with their feelings.
defiant presents: jiggy in jersey (ft. mcvertt) defiant presents rap the newark rapper, newark producer, and bronx drill rapper join forces for a 27-track mixtape that fires on all cylinders.

living in memory of something sweet dreamtx rock steeped in a mixture of indie rock, shoegaze, emo, and ambient, the l.a.-based musician’s debut album is an ambitious attempt to make something new out of familiar materials.
a new reality mind madeline kenney rock the oakland singer-songwriter looks to experimental synth and new age music on her self-produced fourth lp, a serene and reflective take on the breakup album.

solo concerts: bremen/lausanne keith jarrett jazz each sunday, pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. today we revisit a career-defining jazz masterpiece, collecting two hours of improvised solo performances from the piano virtuoso.

floating into the night julee cruise pop/r&b for three decades, this 1989 album has remained one of dream pop’s chief benchmarks. while these songs will be forever associated with david lynch’s work, the album stands proudly on its own.
murmuring chasms of nostalgia seventh stitch electronic with whispery beats and spectral vocals, erstwhile dubstep dj jon gooch seeks a quieter, more intimate sound.

the sweat of earth siavash amini experimental the imposing, experimental 18-minute piece from the tehran-based composer draws upon noise, drone, musique concrète, and the poetry of xavier villarrutia.

the death of randy fitzsimmons the hives rock on their first album in over a decade, the swedish garage-rock mainstays refuse to evolve or age—they are here for a good time and absolutely nothing else.
and southern star mikaela davis folk/country on a stirring full-band album, the classically trained harpist lets her instrument become an integral part of her twangy, easygoing rock’n’roll sound.

ruab dhanji rap touring the gritty underbelly of ahmedabad, india to the sounds of swaggering synth and g-funk, the 25-year-old rapper’s debut makes an auteur’s plea for authenticity in a transactional world.
sundial noname rap noname’s first album in five years is a cool and masterful interrogation of the culture. she’s taking everyone’s name—including her own.
they live in my head bush tetras rock the legendary no wave band honors late drummer dee pop on a mournful album of sludgy post-punk.

a pocket full of rain mark mcguire electronic, rock, experimental a new reissue of the emeralds guitarist’s 2009 album captures his style in its infancy. careful songcraft would come later; these wide-eyed jams are cosmic and sprawling.

chrome dreams neil young rock one of neil young’s most widely bootlegged lost albums from the ’70s gets an official release. as familiar as the material may be, its ragged, magical charm is greater than the sum of its parts.
lonestar luchador that mexican ot rap the texas rapper's new album is a brightly colored spectacle that showcases all the lone star state has to offer.
porches reason rap the california rapper is a nimble and versatile vocalist with an impressionistic, occasionally stilted writing style. is it enough to make him tde’s next big star?

end of world public image ltd rock john lydon’s public persona remains as contrarian as ever. but on pil’s first album in eight years, his voice remains captivating—and, occasionally, surprisingly moving.

the dark side of the moon pink floyd rock each sunday, pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. today, we revisit one of the biggest albums of all time: its origins, its impact, and why it remains a permanent fixture in the rock canon.
infinity club bambii electronic the toronto musician produces like a dj: blending genres, playing fast and loose with bpm, and bringing club music’s promise of endless possibility to life.
at royal albert hall gordon lightfoot rock billed as his final album, this 2016 live set by the late songwriter is a thoughtful and intimate survey of his vast catalog.
not a dream but a controlled explosion iceboy violet rap, experimental the uk rapper-producer’s new album is an indelible rush of free-associative rhymes, ghostly textures, and shapeshifting vocals.

the infinite spine lauren auder pop/r&b, experimental on her debut, the british-french experimentalist reckons with the body and the spirit in compositions so bright and ornate they feel like an inverted version of goth-pop.

rich homeboy sandman rap the queens rapper’s latest album, produced in full by mono en stereo, offers few surprises but features plenty of charmingly diaristic, relatable songs that contrast sharply with mainstream rap.
euphoric georgia pop/r&b the uk singer-producer teams up with rostam for a collection of chilled-out electro-pop that plays it a little too safe.
prestige girl ray rock inspired by the fx drama and the flush of new love, the london indie trio uses its third album to cosplay as the house band of a fantasy discotheque.
soft landing art school girlfriend rock welsh songwriter polly mackey expands her bedroom-pop sound on her intimate and adventurous second album.
the holey bible florry folk/country philadelphia singer-songwriter francie medosch’s band combines the weepy twang of old-school country with the cozy intimacy of diy rock.

natural disaster bethany cosentino rock on her debut solo album, the best coast leader draws inspiration from classic country and glossy pop-rock. it’s the brightest her music has ever sounded but the songwriting doesn’t rise to the occasion.
somewhere down below gaadge rock the versatile pittsburgh quartet polishes their scrappy, shoegaze-inspired indie rock on an album studded with references to local favorites and ’90s classics.
utopia travis scott rap in an attempt to give the world a true blockbuster rap album, the houston rapper delivers a shiny, empty spectacle loaded with pop superstars who rarely make an impact.

blackbox life recorder 21f / in a room7 f760 aphex twin electronic there’s more than meets the eye on richard d. james’ first new ep in five years, a slim collection of percussive bruisers with a woozy, inscrutable mood.
neo seven 7038634357 electronic the experimental musician continues their path of dematerialization on a mostly placid set characterized by warm synths, steady tremolo pulses, and an air of unease.

xo elliott smith rock each sunday, pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. today we revisit elliott smith’s big 1998 album, both a transformational landmark and a logical next step for the restless composer.
eyeroll ziúr electronic the berlin-based dj’s new album relies on rototom drums and the interplay of diverse guests to build exhilarating, dynamic soundscapes.

joni mitchell at newport joni mitchell rock the singer’s first full concert in 22 years was a joyous surprise, a moment of wonder. led by brandi carlile, the live recording of the star-studded fête crowds joni out.
the loveliest time carly rae jepsen pop/r&b once again carly rae jepsen’s b-sides are just as good if not better than her a-sides.
love hallucination jessy lanza pop/r&b jessy lanza leans into low-lit club pop (and picks up a saxophone) on an album whose breezy mood feels inspired by her new home of los angeles.
pure music strange ranger rock on an adventurous new album, the shapeshifting indie-rock band blends rave influences with larger-than-life hooks for some of its sharpest songwriting to date.

evenings at the village gate: john coltrane with eric dolphy john coltrane jazz a previously unknown recording, discovered by chance in 2017, captures the saxophonist testing the limits of his sound in the summer of 1961. it’s a snapshot of a pivotal moment in jazz’s evolution.

ooh rap i ya george clanton pop/r&b on the vaporwave producer and label boss’ new album, smeary synths and boyband-inspired vocals feel less like a biting subversion of nostalgia than a straight-up “remember when.”
infinite psychic depths outer heaven metal on an ambitious new album, the pennsylvania death metal band moves in nimble, surprising directions while honing its psychedelically brutal sound.
the last remaining light far caspian rock the leeds-based musician crafts a bittersweet and atmospheric record whose songs find serenity in stillness.

infirmary / unknown​ ​summer ep kode9 electronic, experimental the hyperdub boss and his reclusive label-mate team up on a split single that highlights their differences, contrasting kode9’s restless rhythmic energy with burial’s contented melancholy.
panico no submundo dj k experimental the são paulo producer pushes brazilian funk to horrorcore extremes, colliding lil uzi vert and samples into a dizzying metallic symphony.
i am not there anymore the clientele rock marked by newfound sonic adventurousness and evocative dream-logic lyrics, the long-running uk band’s new double album is a bold quest into the vast unknown.
war on drugs 2 los rap on the detroit rapper’s newest tape, lean and mean stories from the drug game take shape against ominous beats and inspired references.
love in a vicious way mother tongues rock the toronto band’s debut album brightly blurs the line between ’60s psych pop and ’90s dream pop, but its lyrical preoccupations are much darker in tone.

you’ve got to learn (live) nina simone jazz, pop/r&b recorded live at the 1966 newport jazz festival, this brief but incendiary set includes a famous rendition of “mississippi goddam” tucked inside a handful of potent standards.
outside problems andrew bird rock an improvisatory companion to 2022’s , andrew bird’s newest instrumental album channels the warmth of its ojai, california setting.

the ones ahead beverly glenn-copeland experimental the canadian composer’s first new material since the 2016 rediscovery of his 1986 lp is a joyous, hope-filled showcase of his singular voice and healing vision.

new future city radio damon locks jazz, experimental cross-cutting sample collages, beat tracks, and free improv with wryly surrealist dj banter, the chicago musicians’ fictional mixtape celebrates the revolutionary promise of pirate radio.
magic 2 nas rap nas and hit-boy cook up another collaboration, a low-stakes mid-career rap album to show that one of the genre’s icons is still in decent fighting shape.

everybody good? black milk rap on his first new album since 2018, the longtime detroit beatmaker unites rap, soul, funk, rock, and ghettotech with meticulous craftsmanship and a wonky-yet-smooth touch.
austin post malone rap with a focus on guitar-centric pop-rock, posty’s latest record is a passion project that feels overstuffed and undercooked.
barbie the album various artists curated by mark ronson, the pop-heavy soundtrack to the blockbuster doll movie shrivels outside of the magical world of barbieland.
the ballad of darren blur rock the britpop icons contemplate middle-age turbulence and inertia on a meticulously polished reunion album.
alchemy disclosure electronic the a-list dance-pop duo returns to the club on a new record that’s fresher and more fun than the brothers have sounded in ages.

everyone else is a stranger lindstrøm electronic steeped in multiple layers of nostalgia, the norwegian musician’s sixth album spins his habitual vintage space disco into an enveloping fusion of dewy uplift and nocturnal danger.

hands that bind (original motion picture soundtrack) jim o’rourke experimental the experimental producer and composer’s score for the prairie gothic film is luminous, faintly menacing, and clouded with uncertainty.
super snõõper snõõper rock the nashville egg punks’ debut is a short, speedy trip to the world of “devo-core.” bring your giant puppets.
maybe it’s me… ddg rap with little to talk about aside from his girlfriend halle bailey, the youtuber-turned-artist delivers an album that treats rap like just another piece of content.

journey to the moon and beyond mort garson electronic following reissues of and other cult classics, a new anthology of the moog pioneer’s work revolves around his groundbreaking soundtrack to the 1969 moon landing.
virtuoso valee rap on his new album, the chicago rapper known for his muted, monklike delivery struggles to realize his full potential, even when assisted by harry fraud’s lush instrumentals.
crowd can talk / dressed in trenches lifeguard rock
get up ep newjeans pop/r&b the girl-group’s brisk, club-inflected pop songs cement them as one of the most interesting k-pop acts working today.

presenting dionne warwick dionne warwick rock each sunday, pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. today we revisit the legendary singer’s 1963 debut, whose career-making collaborations with burt bacharach and hal david transformed pop music into something more symphonic, boundless, and idiosyncratic.

jelly road blake mills rock, experimental the singer-songwriter-superproducer teams with the vermont jazz musician chris weisman for an invigorating collaborative album that’s whimsical and wistful in surprising ways.

natural wonder beauty concept natural wonder beauty concept electronic on their first album together, ambient singer-songwriter ana roxanne and leftfield producer dj python find common cause in slow-motion grooves and downbeat electronic pop.
eye on the bat palehound rock writing with painful exactitude, el kempner crafts a vividly rendered breakup album that’s always threatening to explode.
crying crystals haviah mighty rap with inventive storytelling and eclectic beats, the toronto-based rapper constructs a breakup album that sucks everyone into the drama.

western cum cory hanson rock the wand frontman’s third solo album offers a funhouse-mirror take on classic rock, combining surreal lyrical vignettes and laid-back delivery with incendiary guitar shredding.

bringing down the horse the wallflowers rock each sunday, pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. today, we revisit a ’90s pop-rock mainstay, a warm and rootsy record where jakob dylan came to terms with being his father’s son.
rain before seven... penguin cafe experimental the penguin cafe orchestra successors’ fifth album is a tribute to pandemic perseverance that’s long on uplifting strings but short on experimentation.

i care so much that i dont care at all glaive pop/r&b, rap the 18-year-old singer-songwriter moves away from hyperpop and digicore on his debut album, sharpening his pop instincts as he unpacks the chaotic intensity of teenage emotions.
little songs colter wall folk/country the canadian country singer immerses himself in a bygone era on this spacious and dynamic full-band set.
playa saturno rauw alejandro pop/r&b, rap the puerto rican hitmaker attempts to replicate the magic of his celestial 2022 album in this summery spinoff but winds up lost in space.

the greater wings julie byrne folk/country completed after the death of her producer, collaborator, and close friend, the new york singer-songwriter’s album envisions mourning as a form of meditative practice and constant renewal.

beautiful and brutal yard j hus rap the london rapper’s third album extends his carnal and philosophical investigation of masculinity against lush, robust beats that evoke a distinctly black british take on g-funk.
i can’t help it big jade rap on her new album, the texas rapper ditches ready-made strip-club anthems for no-hook freestyles that flaunt her verbal dexterity.

speak now (taylor’s version) taylor swift pop/r&b taylor swift’s catalog re-recording campaign continues with a thoughtful version of 2010’s that tempers teen angst with the ageless quality of lullabies and folk songs.

my back was a bridge for you to cross anohni and the johnsons experimental after 13 years, anohni gets the band back together for a soulful and intense record that provides a safe place to grieve nothing less than the destruction of the planet.

data tainy rap the puerto rican superproducer’s debut lp is a wellspring of new ideas for reggaeton. even when the concepts don’t fully connect, he remains one of the genre’s most forward-thinking architects.
when horses would run being dead rock surf-rock riffs, oddball humor, and warped americana storytelling define the austin band’s raucous debut.
slugs of love little dragon electronic the swedish quartet’s seventh album glows with carefree, mosaic pop arrangements. they sound looser and freer than ever.

i inside the old year dying pj harvey rock in songs adapted from her book-length poem , the british singer-songwriter crafts a hallucinatory dreamworld out of folk instruments, primitive electronics, and warped field recordings.
i’ve really never been better lord jah-monte ogbon rap from knotty wordplay to hip-hop in-jokes only a head would attempt, the north carolina rapper’s latest mixtape provides much to savor.
learning in public ep downtown kayoto pop/r&b blending fuzzy guitars and 2-step beats, the uk singer’s richly textured diy pop looks to britpop and garage, frank ocean and drake.
mondo tempo freak heat waves electronic the canadian duo takes a chill, fuzzy-headed left turn but retains the bleak imagery and nuanced production of its best work.

connection ceramic dog rock, experimental, jazz the new york guitarist and his longtime collaborators spend a rollicking, leisurely hour imagining rock music’s role in a world more invested in social justice than commerce.

the idol: music from the hbo original series the weeknd pop/r&b the collected songs from the infamous show would have been better served as a random weeknd posse album meant to launch the promising minor pop career of lily-rose depp.
fish don’t climb trees chester watson rap the st. louis rapper’s new album showcases a fly confidence that the thin writing can’t always match.
flying high ep the alchemist rap the star beatmaker reunites with past collaborators like earl sweatshirt, billy woods, and larry june on a breezy new ep.
blowout john carroll kirby pop/r&b, jazz the latest album from this l.a. session player to the stars reveals him to be a fascinatingly expressive keyboardist who doesn’t take himself too seriously.
ganger veeze rap after years of anticipation, the idiosyncratic detroit rapper returns with an unpredictable new album full of vocal quirks and unlikely punchlines.
swells k-lone electronic the brighton producer works with a light touch, resulting in subtle, pliant songs that evolve in sneaky ways.
good living is coming for you sweeping promises rock the diy fixtures behind silkies, dee-parts, and mini dresses turn their attention to scuzzy, no-fi ’80s punk overflowing with pop hooks.

stories from a rock n roll heart lucinda williams folk/country the masterful singer-songwriter offers her lightest, most earthbound record in years, finding newfound inspiration in the sweetly silly sound of barroom rock’n’roll.

trio dolly parton folk/country, rock each sunday, pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. today, we revisit a historic collaboration that braided three unique histories of american music into a timeless whole.
pink tape lil uzi vert rap the philadelphia rapper delivers a bloated and messy new album, struggling to live up to their reputation for imaginative, genre-blending adventures.

salesforce lauren bousfield electronic unlike the commercial soundtrack music she writes in her day job, the los angeles producer’s solo work is an over-the-top onslaught of electronic noise and withering anti-capitalist sarcasm.

if we stayed alive 12 rods rock two decades after the minneapolis alt-rock also-rans called it quits, lead singer ryan olcott resurrects the project, reworking abandoned demos into contemporary bedroom pop with a vintage cast.

i’ve got me joanna sternberg folk/country the new york city songwriter meets the hardest of feelings with uncommon compassion. their second album’s singsong ditties and openhearted ballads play like new standards.

time was gigantic… when we were kids the durutti column electronic a new reissue highlights vini reilly’s 1998 turn towards pop, a less explored period of the guitarist’s long career as the forward-looking post-punk outfit the durutti column.

the happiest times i ever ignored hayden pedigo rock the eccentric 29-year-old guitarist, artist, model, and former city council candidate’s new solo guitar album showcases his studious and inventive approach to the genre.
chaos for the fly grian chatten rock the subdued solo debut from the fontaines d.c. singer feels alluringly timeless. it’s a combination of novelty and tradition, artifice and honesty.
glockoma 2 (deluxe) key glock rap now expanded in a deluxe edition, the memphis rapper’s blues-inflected third album keeps a tight focus while alluding to the painful loss of mentor young dolph.

dream box pat metheny jazz the 68-year-old guitar virtuoso compiled this understated set of solo recordings from a forgotten folder during downtime on tour. these casual experiments offer a fascinating peek into his creative mind.

spooky lush rock each sunday, pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. today, we look back at the uk band’s 1992 debut, a deceptively hazy pop record that showcases the complementary songwriting of emma anderson and miki berenyi.
go west!: the contemporary records albums sonny rollins jazz this new box documents a pair of late-’50s albums in which the new york saxophonist left an indelible mark on west coast jazz.
be my vengeance destiny bond rock the denver band’s debut is 19 minutes of galvanizing, accessible hardcore with a focus on queer community and uplift.

in the end it always does the japanese house pop/r&b working primarily with the 1975’s george daniel, the english songwriter crafts a breakup album that’s vibrant and playful while exploring nuanced emotional threads.
systemic divide and dissolve rock the naarm, australia-based duo draws upon its black and indigenous heritage to make visceral instrumental metal infused with unmistakable socio-political intent.
please touch rrose electronic at once immersive and disorienting, seth horvitz’s second album as rrose is dance music that erases the dancefloor.
life under the gun militarie gun rock on their debut album, the los angeles hardcore band explodes out of the basement show without abandoning its energy and essence.

strobe.rip amnesia scanner experimental, electronic working alongside the multidisciplinary troll freeka tet, berlin experimental club duo amnesia scanner sound as playful as ever, but there’s a gnawing sense of anxiety behind their fits of delirium.
coi coi leray rap the rapper and singer’s endlessly imitative new album chases trendy sounds and obvious samples to mask that it has nothing to say.

sun arcs blue lake experimental layering his custom-built 48-string zither with slide guitar, clarinet, and pump organ, the texas native makes music that draws as much from drone and ambient as from jazz and americana.
every day like the last wye oak rock a short but resonant compilation from the indie rock duo navigates life’s gray areas with gentle instrumentation and hard-earned serenity.

picture of bunny rabbit arthur russell experimental recorded at the same time as 1986’s masterpiece , this posthumous collection offers an essential glimpse into arthur russell’s haunted, luminous sound.
central city big freedia rap the new orleans bounce icon takes a victory lap on her long-awaited second album, one of the most effective party-starting records of the year.
business is business young thug rap as the atlanta rapper’s court case continues, this scrappy project is all the more compelling for its loose, improvisatory structure.
texas boy mike dimes rap the texas artist’s second album contains sparks of brilliance, but its overreliance on generic flex raps feels stale and tedious.
purge godflesh metal returning to the apocalyptic club setting of its early-’90s work, the industrial metal duo crafts the most inviting record of its late career.

melodies on hiatus albert hammond jr. rock working alongside pop songwriter simon wilcox, the strokes guitarist delivers a cheerfully sprawling double album that feels less like a cohesive statement than a clearinghouse of ideas.

tonight savage electronic each sunday, pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. today, we look back at a 1984 album that exemplifies the best of italo disco, in all its joyfully eccentric glory.
let there be music bonny doon rock after a stint as waxahatchee’s backing band, the detroit folk-rockers subtly sharpen their musicianship on a laid-back album suffused in positive vibes.

petrodragonic apocalypse; or, dawn of eternal night: an annihilation of planet earth and the beginning of merciless damnation king gizzard & the lizard wizard rock the prolific australian psych-rockers deliver a thrash-metal concept album that doesn’t shred hard enough to stave off its overwhelming campiness.
michael killer mike rap the atlanta rapper’s first solo record in 11 years preserves his seismic bars, but its sanctimonious undercurrent can make it hard to stomach.
feed the beast kim petras pop/r&b across her latest album, the pop star’s high-octane, inoffensive dance-pop plays it way too safe and never really finds a point of view.
the whaler home is where rock the second album from the acerbic and eclectic emo-rock band expertly bottles their energy as they sing about constantly pushing for more when given so little.

the days of wine and roses (expanded edition) the dream syndicate rock an extensive 4xcd set celebrates the 40th anniversary of the paisley underground mainstays’ debut lp, chronicling the early years of the los angeles group’s underground rock.

a gift & a curse gunna rap the atlanta rapper tries to testify to the emotional burdens of the ysl case while staying lighthearted, resulting in an album that both lacks depth and is too absorbed in real-life drama.

the omnichord real book meshell ndegeocello pop/r&b meshell ndegeocello’s sprawling new record feels like a natural synthesis of the jazz, rock, dub, and soul sounds she’s explored throughout her career.
3d country geese rock with a newfound emphasis on dynamics and space, the brooklyn group evolves from its gritty post-punk origins into a proudly outrageous jam band.
the complete dirty south drive-by truckers rock an expanded edition of 2004’s alarm-sounding masterpiece presents the century’s greatest southern rock band at its most powerful and its most poignant.
átta sigur rós rock after a decade, the icelandic band returns with an album of minimal music performed maximally, along with a 41-piece orchestra, climate despair, and jónsi’s inimitable vocals.

lavette! bettye lavette folk/country, jazz, pop/r&b the soul legend presents her loosest and most daring album in years, an affectionate tribute to the underappreciated blues and folk songwriter randall bramblett.
in times new roman... queens of the stone age rock on its angriest and heaviest record in years, the rock band restores its bluesy, primitive sound as joshua homme confronts his recent turmoil

work of art asake pop/r&b the nigerian singer-songwriter’s second album is in constant search of innovation, fusing traditional and contemporary african music into a celebration of success and community.

bitter meshell ndegeocello pop/r&b each sunday, pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. today, we return to the 1999 album from the singer and bassist, a spare and mercurial exploration of a breakup that has become her masterpiece.

hood hottest princess sexyy red rap the st. louis rapper’s new mixtape channels gucci mane and trina, delivering filthy, laugh-out-loud punchlines and setting the tone for the freakiest summer since the advent of the smartphone.

smash – the singles 1985 – 2020 pet shop boys electronic a new 55-song compilation from the uk art-pop duo is as definitive as it gets, pearl after pearl of fabulous singles from one of the best to ever do it.
6 babytron rap the irreverent detroit rapper’s latest album reaches toward seriousness with traditional song structures and slower, more menacing production.
girl with fish feeble little horse rock the pittsburgh noise-pop experimentalists come into their own on a short yet richly textured album full of fuzzy melodic hooks and beguiling left turns.
sugar the bruise hand habits rock meg duffy sharpens their slow, perceptive songwriting into a vulnerable and compelling meditation on creativity and human connection.
guy jayda g electronic the canadian producer and dj’s second album pays tribute to her father’s memory, fusing home-video recordings with ambrosial disco, soul, and dance-pop.
myuthafoo caterina barbieri experimental the italian synthesizer wizard follows up her 2019 album with an instrumental set of controlled abandon and rapturous minimalism.
dolphin greg foat jazz, electronic the uk jazz pianist greg foat deftly balances the rhythmic and ambient poles of his sound on his collaborative album with veteran italian artist gigi masin.
the onederful nephew dj rude one rap assisted by brooklyn beatmaker dj rude one, the rambunctious rapper makes his most focused, pared-down project yet.

fountain baby amaarae pop/r&b the ghanaian american singer’s dazzling second album is a confident and unconventional record that flows, saunters, and boasts its way to one of the best pop albums of the year.

further out than the edge speakers corner quartet jazz joined by a wealth of collaborators, the house band for the venerable south london spoken-word night thrives on a nearly imperceptible blend of live improvisation and studio assemblage.

jarak qaribak dudu tassa rock, experimental the israeli singer and the radiohead guitarist team up with artists from across the middle east to tackle a range of arabic love songs, in an act of concerted musical bridge-building.

crying laughing loving lying labi siffre pop/r&b, folk/country each sunday, pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. today, we revisit the british singer-songwriter’s 1972 album, an intimate and delicate collection of queer folk-rock from one of the best voices in his generation.

heaven is a junkyard youth lagoon rock trevor powers has long shown a penchant for reinvention, but his first album as youth lagoon in eight years feels like a homecoming; he’s never sounded so confident or at peace with himself.
when the poems do what they do aja monet jazz backed by a prodigious jazz combo, the poet’s debut album possesses a profound and forceful clarity.

ticket to fame decisive pink electronic kate nv and angel deradoorian lock themselves in a cologne studio with an arsenal of synths and a mutual appreciation for the absurd; tongue-in-cheek krautrock hijinks ensue.

animals kassa overall jazz, rap like his last lp, the drummer-producer’s warp debut rejects false dichotomies like jazz vs. hip-hop. but sometimes, his freeform style is too scattered for its own good.
lost at sea rob grant experimental at age 69, lana del rey’s father—boating enthusiast, real-estate agent, domain-name investor—makes his piano-playing debut on a major label. it’s totally fine.
paranoïa, angels, true love christine and the queens pop/r&b inspired by , the french artist’s latest album is a raw, dreamlike, 20-song epic that still feels like a first draft.
joy’all jenny lewis rock the veteran singer-songwriter takes inspiration from classic country on an album full of barbed wit and insight, but the music could use more of the genre’s bite.

time ain’t accidental jess williamson folk/country with understated production and forceful vocal performances, the los angeles songwriter crafts a heartbroken road-trip record that feels like a breakthrough.

jam city presents efm jam city electronic the uk dance producer delivers an effervescent blend of rattling garage, glitzy disco, and thumping house that invokes the idea of nightlife as an endless fantasy.
zango witch rock on their first album in nearly 40 years, the zamrock pioneers prove their malleable, genre-spanning style still sounds like the future.
orbs anthony naples electronic the new york producer once known for muscular house and techno continues to drift into the ether, channeling ’90s chillout and dub techno into his singular vision.

formal growth in the desert protomartyr rock under a gray sky of grief, the detroit post-punks’ sixth album makes space for skulking grooves, shoegaze-y experimentation, and a baja blast that’s always half full.
new jazz lunchbox rap with restless vocals and shapeshifting beats, the harlem rapper’s new mixtape innovates on the chaotic sound of rage-rap.
wandering rebel juan wauters rock on his most introspective album to date, the everyman balladeer from queens considers beachside sandwiches, making money from art, and what it means to be home.
space heavy king krule rock on his fourth album as king krule, archy marshall reckons with love and newfound fatherhood, but he still sounds beset by existential doubt.
o monolith squid rock the english band’s second album explores big questions with a bucolic, open-ended new sound. where once they surged forward, now they wander.
weathervanes jason isbell and the 400 unit folk/country a calm breeze blows through the songwriter’s latest album, a road-ready set of tunes forged on the long journey to relaxation.

metro boomin presents spider-man: across the spider-verse (soundtrack from and inspired by the motion picture) metro boomin rap the megastar producer enlists future, 21 savage, james blake, and more in a wobbly attempt to create another synergistic pop moment in the animated spider-man franchise.

folkocracy rufus wainwright rock the enchanting singer enlists anohni, david byrne, brandi carlile, and more for an interesting collection of covers ranging from traditional folk songs, to neil young tunes, to children’s lullabies.
the age of pleasure janelle monáe pop/r&b janelle monáe’s fourth album exchanges science fiction for lusty romance, creating a rapturous afrofuturistic sound collage for sunny days and sticky nights.
qwerty ep saya gray pop/r&b the art-pop musician’s latest ep is a bleary, semiconscious rush that invites you to get lost inside it.
détwat hitech rap twitchy, raunchy, and full of laugh-out-loud punchlines, the detroit trio’s new album is the best ghettotech rager in recent memory.
r u saved? the stools rock the detroit punk trio’s first proper full-length is a blast, but its abstract, evocative lyrics make it a welcome subversion of the punk formula.

bunny beach fossils experimental, rock beach fossils’ latest album distills the best of their daydreamy indie-pop with new wisdom and existential angst. but they’re just still as laid-back as you remember.
almost healed lil durk rap the drill rapper’s mainstream takeover continues with an engaging, guest-heavy, but otherwise run-of-the-mill album.

early grave sans merit rock the australian musician better known as francis inferno orchestra trades his habitual house and disco for lo-fi indie that plays like a love letter to the eccentric records john peel championed.
roach miya folick rock on her second album, the los angeles singer-songwriter trades her off-kilter pop arrangements for straightforward, unfussy compositions.
but here we are foo fighters rock dave grohl gives himself over to arena-sized grief, reckoning, and resolve on the band’s most propulsive and purposeful music of the last two decades.

real b*tches don’t die! kari faux rap kari faux returns to her southern roots on a raucous, eclectic rap album that pays tribute to the ancestors, loved ones, and inspirations that showed her the way.

horse rotorvator coil electronic, experimental, rock each sunday, pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. today, we revisit the uk duo’s second album, a groundbreaking avant-garde pop collage from the early years of the aids epidemic that grapples with the nature of death.
lucky for you bully rock alicia bognanno’s snarling alt-rock and sledgehammer choruses are blunted by the muddy production on her fourth album.

the sport of love asma maroof electronic, experimental, jazz the three improvisers conceived their new album while soundtracking a film for louis vuitton, but the results, far from being glamorous or overblown, are intimate and conversational.

romantic piano gia margaret rock built around wistful piano pieces that follow unexpected paths, the chicago composer’s third album has far more personality and strangeness than its almost aggressively generic title suggests.

sheryl crow sheryl crow rock each sunday, pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. today, we revisit sheryl crow’s barnstorming second album, a collection of restless pop-rock anthems with something to prove.

everyone’s crushed water from your eyes rock the brooklyn duo's logic-defying new album threads anticapitalist critique, stoner humor, and a hazy undercurrent of fatalism into art-pop so mesmerizing it'll give you a contact high.
nothing bigger than the program jay worthy rap with dusty, psychedelic production from roc marciano, jay worthy’s latest collaborative album is his grimiest to date.

the girl is crying in her latte sparks electronic, experimental, rock the mael brothers are riding high. their 26th album strikes the ideal sparksian balance of madcap melody, labyrinthine arrangement, and stinging social satire.

happiness (anniversary edition) fridge electronic, rock this reissue of a 2001 album from kieran hebden’s post-rock trio captures the band’s shift from live instrumental jams to the more intricate, experimental style that he’d pursue as four tet.

sus dog clark electronic executive produced by thom yorke, chris clark’s latest album is warm and gratifying, offering the veteran electronic musician’s fragile falsetto as a graceful counterpoint to his intricate production.

villagers califone rock tim rutili has spent a quarter century cryptically subverting folk-rock convention. but in these songs—some of his warmest and most welcoming yet—he tells you just how he feels.
paradise crick m. sage electronic inspired by the great outdoors, the latest album from the colorado musician and ambient artist is a gently psychedelic ode to all that is wild and wandering.
freak frequency stuck rock the chicago post-punk quartet’s jittery second album rails against gentrification, algorithmic overload, and the bankruptcy of life under an extractive system.
dismantled into juice blawan electronic beneath a shroud of dry ice and woodsmoke, the uk producer’s new record discards the conventional cadences of dance music.
kaytraminé kaytraminé rap, pop/r&b kaytranada and aminé team up for a set of sunny, funky party tracks best experienced with a mai tai in hand.

talisman slowspin folk/country the pakistan-born, u.s.-based musician draws on the migrant’s deep well of loss and longing, weaving traditional south asian musical forms into lushly textured folk, ambient, and dream pop.
could have done anything charlotte cornfield rock the toronto songwriter returns with a brief and lovely alt-folk record, vivid and unmoored from place and time.

tracey denim bar italia rock with a crisper sound and direct homages to underground music of generations past, the enigmatic london trio’s matador debut is moody, moth-eaten record-collector rock that gets by on moody insouciance.
my soft machine arlo parks rock the singer-songwriter’s second album is headier and more dynamic than her mercury prize-winning debut, but its sharp writing is often blunted by its temperate sound.
walk around the moon dave matthews band rock on the band's 10th album, dave matthews taps into his gentler side with the wisdom and grace afforded by age.

where the flowers don’t die monaleo rap on her debut, the breakout houston rapper is determined to complicate her tough-talking persona. not every stylistic swing connects, but it’s a blast to hear her growing into her talent.
seven psalms paul simon rock the veteran songwriter contemplates faith on a quiet, ambitious 33-minute suite. it becomes more surreal—and even funny—the deeper into it you get.
from the cradle to the game heem rap on his sepia-toned second album, the buffalo rapper looks back on a troubled upbringing while sometimes dipping into cliche.

wave notation 3: erik satie 1984 satsuki shibano experimental originally released in 1984 as a companion to hiroshi yoshimura’s , this collection of satie’s solo piano pieces is a cornerstone of japanese ambient.
i’ve seen a way mandy, indiana experimental the manchester quartet’s debut album fuses dance rhythms, corroded guitars, and seething vocals into a transfixing blend of violence and transcendence.

brain scratch galen tipton electronic after finding an audience on tiktok, the ohio producer extends their hypercute, asmr-inspired sound into an album that floats between states of relaxation and overstimulation.
clear 2: soft life summer walker pop/r&b the atlanta singer’s subdued new ep is less interested in reliving drama than finding peace.

here 2 stay dd osama rap the 16-year-old harlem drill rapper attained viral fame after the tragic killing of little brother notti osama. his debut mixtape is an excruciating contrast of teen celebrity and raw grief.

resort island isolée electronic since his 1998 breakout hit “beau mot plage,” the german house producer has been associated with tropical idyll. on his first album in 12 years, he takes a more ambivalent look at paradise.
broken by desire to be heavenly sent lewis capaldi pop/r&b the chart-topping balladeer’s risk-averse second album is simultaneously overwrought and uninspired.
an evening at macri park seán barna rock the singer-songwriter’s second album is a raucous, messy, and celebratory song cycle about finding kinship in queer nightlife.

broken nine inch nails rock each sunday, pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. today, we revisit a six-song ep from 1992, a record that alchemized the sound and provocative aggression of nine inch nails.
brandy clark brandy clark folk/country produced by brandi carlile, the nashville songwriter's melancholy new album presents only a few facets of a complex artist.

the sex ep the dare pop/r&b, electronic harrison patrick smith is the poster boy for a small new york club scene, but his sleazy, party-hard songwriting is not as transgressive as he would like you to believe.
gag order kesha pop/r&b swerving away from party-pop irreverence, kesha collaborates with rick rubin on a spare and eccentric album about coming to terms with ambivalence.
the big mess tanlines electronic on their first new album since 2015, the onetime brooklyn indie darlings turn definitively toward dad rock.

come on feel (30th anniversary edition) the lemonheads rock the uneven but fascinating sixth album by the lemonheads gets a new reissue that explores the moment when evan dando was everything everyone said he was, all at once.
heartbreak rules horse jumper of love rock on a new mini-album, the boston slowcore project pares back its sound to uncover new strengths and summon old ghosts.
end of everything mega bog experimental as tense and exploratory as a sci-fi epic, the los angeles musician’s new album meanders through eerie, desolate prog rock and synth-pop.
the answer is always yes alex lahey rock the australian singer-songwriter’s new album is a collection of hooky, blistering break-up anthems.
orbweaving midwife rock, experimental on an intimate collaborative album, madeline johnston and angel diaz push beyond their common ground toward moments of grand catharsis and melancholy ambience.
the love invention alison goldfrapp pop/r&b not quite a reinvention, the goldfrapp singer’s solo debut sets her against sleek synth disco that she mostly complements rather than commands.

random access memories (10th anniversary edition) daft punk electronic ten years have taken some shine off of daft punk’s gilded final album, but its unforgettable impact still echoes throughout the pop universe.
romantiq oval electronic, experimental the glitch legend puts his past in context on lush, unabashedly beautiful pieces created with painstaking sample processing.
dog dreams (개꿈) lucy liyou electronic, experimental with spine-tingling whispers and cavernous synths, the san francisco-based sound artist traces the ghostly shores of her past.
monochrome highway rap with confessional writing and immersive beats, the seattle rapper-singer’s latest album is a more tender take on the cold-hearted player blueprint.
i hope you can forgive me madison mcferrin pop/r&b the los angeles-based singer-songwriter’s debut builds out her production while retaining the layered harmonies of her a capella work.

how was your life? memotone electronic the latest record from the uk electronic musician is built primarily on the guitar synthesizer, setting a tone that feels gently euphoric, whimsical, and bittersweet.

legacy volume 2 rp boo electronic the chicago producer’s 2013 album affirmed his place in footwork’s vanguard. on a new collection of archival work, his loop-heavy tracks sound as raw, dizzying, and psychedelic as ever.

spirit they’re gone, spirit they’ve vanished (remastered 2023) animal collective experimental in 2000, dave portner and noah lennox self-released a home-recorded album in a tiny edition of cds. but animal collective’s de facto debut is far more deliberate, ambitious, and sophisticated than you might remember.

silver haze sqürl experimental jim jarmusch and carter logan’s first album of non-film music is moody and deliberate, folding marc ribot’s guitar and john ashbery’s poetry into thick slabs of psych-rock drone.

tête-à-tête ruth anderson electronic combining archival material and contemporary reflections, the composers and sound artists’ joint album celebrates their long and resonant partnership in art and life.
try and love ofege rock this 1973 album by a group of lagos high-school students shines a spotlight on a nigerian psych-rock scene that’s long been overshadowed by the legacy of afrobeat.

good lies overmono electronic the welsh brothers earned a rep for festival anthems that bridge big-room functionalism with subtle experimentation. on their debut album, they go in search of transcendence.
cruisin’ bernice pop/r&b the toronto quintet's colorful new album is all midi sheen and new age cheese, the product of classy musicians working with the chintziest materials possible.

harsh 70s reality the dead c experimental, rock each sunday, pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. today, we revisit the influential new zealand band’s 1992 masterpiece, a rambling double-disc totem of noise rock that expertly balances tight songs and long improvisations.

secret life fred again.. pop/r&b, rap, electronic following recent sets with skrillex and four tet, hitmaker fred gibson teams up with the ambient eminence. unlike that anarchic trio, this project is dutifully, and sometimes dully, solemn.
atum the smashing pumpkins rock the smashing pumpkins’ new album is a trilogy-completing, podcast-augmented three-part intergalactic techno-libertarian rock drama!

one wayne g mac demarco rock this hours-long, 199-song compilation of mostly instrumental work is a canny product of our current streaming era. but at its best, it offers a glimpse into mac demarco’s unique and evolving process.
love streak tony shhnow rap the atlanta rapper attempts to convey the subtleties of romance on his new r&b-inspired album. it sounds as though he’s never even been on a date.

daystar beta librae electronic the new york producer’s latest album bounces between rolling grooves and dissolving basslines. it’s primed for both the dancefloor and for getting lost in a headphone fog.
he hymns lcy electronic the uk club producer explores the links between spiritual devotion and bodily release, delivering moments of catharsis in chopped breaks and ghostly vocals.

maps billy woods rap the new york rapper reconnects with the los angeles producer for a masterful road-trip album. humor and dread, weed and food, technique and style—billy woods is in full command of it all.
secret measure cloth rock the glasgow duo’s second record is polished and understated, seeking to offer reassurance in the face of stasis and uncertainty.
greg mendez greg mendez rock the philly singer-songwriter’s third proper album is written and sung with painstaking care and offers an entry point to his sprawling and satisfying discography.

the truth beanie sigel rap each sunday, pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. today, we revisit the philadelphia rapper’s 1999 debut, a dramatic and gritty album that brought a new kind of cred to roc-a-fella records.
you can do it all cusp rock the chicago band grapples with impermanence and loss on their memorable indie rock debut.
anonym tolerance electronic

naldjorlak éliane radigue electronic, experimental in two performances spanning nearly 15 years, the avant-garde french composer and the cellist charles curtis investigate the allegedly unmusical sound of the wolf tone.
spalarkle felicita featuring caroline polachek, kero kero bonito, and more, the latest from the pc music artist is giddy and psychedelic, with a mischievous sense of humor.
