the rat road sbtrkt electronic, rock on his first album in seven years, the uk producer embraces chaos: ten guests, 22 tracks, countless genres. yet it can sometimes be hard to locate sbtrkt’s musical identity amid all the commotion.
an inbuilt fault westerman rock the second album from the soft-rock innovator is world-weary and contemplative—the music adopts a lush, earthy palette and his voice sounds better than ever.

if looks could kill destroy lonely rap the atlanta rapper has promised an unprecedented sound, but this overlong, monochromatic lp juggles a handful of shopworn topics and recycles gimmicks, flows, and ideas.
bekka ma’iingan zoon rock with an unpredictable, amorphous shoegaze sound, the indigenous canadian musician crafts their most opaque and open-hearted work.

erotic probiotic 2 nourished by time pop/r&b filtering the sound of ’80s freestyle through a buoyant, time-warped haze, the debut album from singer/producer marcus brown is both captivating and elusive.
- ed sheeran pop/r&b ed sheeran has bragged that he wrote seven of his new album’s songs in a combined two and a half hours. it’s easy to believe him.
all of this will end indigo de souza rock fueled by earnest writing and exhilarating vocal performances, the asheville songwriter’s third album aims for stadium-sized feelings.
through and through baby rose pop/r&b on her second album, the los angeles singer uses her bluesy, soulful contralto to express a deep, almost ecstatic sense of loneliness.
museum jfdr experimental with patient songwriting and gentle arrangements, the icelandic art-pop musician portrays seismic emotional transformations through resounding moments of stillness.
slowly forgetting, barely remembering martyna basta experimental the polish ambient musician channels deep-seated melodic instincts on her exploratory and enchantingly enigmatic new album.
lucha y la bamba folk/country the mexican-american singer-songwriter harnesses the musical echoes of their ancestors into a gorgeous, dreamlike memory palace.
jackman. jack harlow rap without flashy bars or marquee features, jack harlow’s third album aims for clarity with soft, expensive beats and cloyingly intimate storytelling.

short term agreement nxxxxxs rap as the phonk sound that he helped develop has evolved, the parisian producer has switched up his own style. his latest album feels like a grab bag of genre experiments that lack a distinct identity.
gasms smokey robinson pop/r&b now 83, the soul singer returns with his first album of new material since 2009, and he remains as fixated on love and lust as ever.
bird hour 7ebra rock on their debut album, twin sisters inez and ella johannson are immersed in their own charming, sometimes too insular alt-pop world.
euphoric recall braids electronic raphaelle standell-preston’s operatic vocals and a string ensemble help the canadian trio evoke the rush of new love, though some experiments go awry.

4:23 mike dean electronic featuring several collaborations with the weeknd, the superproducer’s latest solo album explores the ways humanity may prevail over technology—too bad it’s drab and soulless.
heart stopper ron morelli electronic the l.i.e.s. label head makes a rare appearance on his own imprint, clearing away the lo-fi cobwebs and digging into tough, percussive dancefloor cuts.

& the charm avalon emerson pop/r&b the techno dj and leftfield beatmaker pivots to balearic dream pop on her debut album. the tone is disarming and sweet, using nostalgia as a foil for spiritual fatigue.
babylon ix yunè pinku pop/r&b, electronic the london electro-pop artist takes a step forward after last year’s ep: the textures are richer, the emotions deeper, and her confidence more assured.
that! feels good! jessie ware pop/r&b jessie ware’s sumptuous fifth album is classic disco revival done right.

first two pages of frankenstein the national rock with help from taylor swift, phoebe bridgers, and sufjan stevens, the national return with their gentlest album yet: a collection of airy, tender gestures.
everything perfect james ivy pop/r&b, rock the 23-year-old singer-producer’s arena-sized pop-rock opens up a world of sensory pleasure on his second ep.
dsx.fm dazegxd electronic, experimental on a brief collaborative ep, the digipop artists pay tribute to ’90s electronic music while rediscovering the kinetic thrill of their past work.

infinite spring superviolet folk/country five years after indie-rock underdogs the sidekicks dropped their fifth and final album, steve ciolek returns with a new project that recalibrates his ambitions while radiating emotional warmth.
become beach house rock five pleasantly familiar outtakes from 2022’s extend that album’s dream-pop sparkle and festival-headliner sheen.

jump on it bill orcutt experimental on his first solo acoustic outing in a decade, the former harry pussy member shifts from deconstructing the guitar to reassembling it according to his own idiosyncratic design.

ryan leslie ryan leslie pop/r&b each sunday, pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. today, we revisit ryan leslie’s breezy and lovestruck 2009 solo debut, a set of virtuoso r&b productions that emerged in a new era of online music culture.
catharsis covet rock led by guitar virtuoso yvette young, the california band looks beyond math rock with an album full of musical twists and emotional thrills.

...so unknown jesus piece metal the philadelphia group’s metal-tinged style channels the physicality of a hardcore show with propulsive rhythms, call-and-response vocals, and floor-punching breakdowns.
*1 rắn cạp đuôi experimental after the apocalyptic overtones of their 2021 breakthrough album, the vietnamese experimental music collective finds hope in the fusion of rave music and eco-futurism.

safe to run esther rose folk/country having traded new orleans for taos, the michigan-born singer-songwriter offers a chronicle of her wanderings. the songs roll out as though she’d written them behind the wheel on a long drive.
playing w/ fire redveil rap the 19-year-old rapper’s boisterous new ep projects greater confidence, but its juvenile boasts can leave something to be desired.
future’s shadow part 1: the clandestine gate bell witch metal the seattle doom duo embarks on an audacious mission—a beautiful and melancholy three-album cycle about eternal returns and daily toil.
oxygen matt ox rap the 18-year-old viral rapper’s mediocre new album doubles as an endorsement for new york collective surf gang’s excellent production work.
devil music portrayal of guilt rock the latest record from the austin trio is split in two halves: elaborate, hellish metal and dissonant chamber music.
son of africa remi kabaka rock a new reissue shines a light on the nigerian session player, who brought his afro-rock heat and slick funk to british experiments with west african music in the ’70s.

treasures: solo, trio and orchestra recordings from denmark (1965-1969) bill evans jazz a new anthology of previously unissued performances covers three distinct facets of the jazz pianist’s career: his trio work, orchestral arrangements, and his endlessly inventive solo playing.

enys men (original score) mark jenkin electronic composed by the director himself, the score for mark jenkin’s experimental folk-horror film floats ambiguously between beauty and dread, creating tension through mystery.
pila’e teteo kiko el crazy rap the dominican artist’s terrific second album runs at a breakneck pace and excels at two of the elements that make dembow so irresistible: hooks and humor.
have mercy on us icytwat rap the chicago-born rapper-producer’s new mixtape is woozy but tight, flaunting its open infatuation with all kinds of rap.

jōhatsu (蒸発) mark barrott electronic the ibiza-based producer’s first full-length in over four years, originally intended as the score for a japanese documentary, nudges down the thermostat on the island escapism of his earlier work.
enigmatic society dinner party jazz, pop/r&b the hybrid jazz supergroup featuring kamasi washington, robert glasper, terrace martin, and more keeps it exquisitely sparse and supremely chill.
wickman stickman shawny binladen rap though it’s less outlandish than previous projects, the queens rapper’s new album confirms his status as one of new york drill’s most important innovators.
härvest poison ruïn rock the philadelphia punk band couches its revolutionary anthems in winking medieval imagery, flirting with camp as they sharpen the guillotine’s blade.
yallah beibe mc yallah rap the multilingual east african rapper embraces a crisp, confident sound on her second full-length.
secret stratosphere william tyler folk/country, rock backed by a killer band of nashville musicians, the guitarist electrifies and expands his inventive blend of southern rock and space rock.
fuse everything but the girl electronic, pop/r&b after 24 years, the electronic pop duo returns with a moving, handsome album that tells a sophisticated story about recapturing innocence.
hnpm jim legxacy rap, experimental the rapper-producer’s new mixtape creates its own solar system, one where samples and jersey club orbit around the triplet suns of afrobeats, emo, and rap.
big picture fenne lily folk/country, rock the third album from the bristol singer-songwriter furnishes complex storytelling in cozy, lived-in atmospheres.
princess forever dreamer isioma pop/r&b on their new record, the chicago native fights the slow poison of the apocalypse with smooth r&b, galactic funk, and afrofuturist fantasies.

the notorious byrd brothers the byrds rock each sunday, pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. today, we revisit the byrds’ 1968 album, the best and most cohesive project from a classic rock band in constant flux with the changing times.
forever means angel olsen rock a new ep of four songs recorded during sessions for last year’s forms a bridge between the singer-songwriter’s past and present.

since time is gravity natural information society jazz bringing together players from across chicago’s improv community, joshua abrams’ ensemble folds elements of jazz and north african music into mesmerizing pieces that hint at eternity.
call me terry terry rock the australian post-punk band takes aim at the crooks and scammers on its most political album yet.
henry st. the tallest man on earth folk/country on his first album with a proper band, the swedish singer-songwriter sounds great, even as he says so very little.

why does the earth give us people to love? kara jackson folk/country on her brutally honest debut album, the chicago singer-songwriter takes folk music and bends it to her will, exploring agony and adoration in equal measure.

brothers in christ nerver rock kindred spirits in the i-35 noise-rock scene share a split ep rooted in the ’90s underground; the normally pummeling chat pile indulge some surprisingly tuneful indie influences.

international pop overthrow material issue rock each sunday, pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. today, we revisit the power-pop trio’s 1991 debut, a scrappy, diamond-sharp, hook-filled attempt to become the biggest rock band out of chicago.
covers vol. 1 shannon lay folk/country the singer-songwriter pays tribute to elliott smith, nick drake, arthur russell, and more on a set of covers that play like quiet seances.
holy red wagon bruiser and bicycle rock the second album from the albany freak-folk group is vivid and dreamlike, revealing a meticulous attention to detail.

the night safari patrick wolf electronic, rock more than a decade after his last album, the uk singer-songwriter grapples with an intense period of personal upheaval in songs that return to the melancholy, idiosyncratic sound of his early work.

the window is the dream jana horn folk/country on her second album, the texas-born, charlottesville-based singer-songwriter traces generous circles around nebulous feelings; her songs seem to emerge from deep stillness.

the smell of our own (20th anniversary edition) the hidden cameras rock twenty years ago, joel gibb joyfully preached a vision of gay revolution. his group’s debut offered a prescient vision of the currents that power queer culture today.
multitudes feist rock feist’s quietest album to date is warm and comforting throughout, but really peaks when it gets fuller, weirder, and more unpredictable.
sremm 4 life rae sremmurd rap the rap radio pleasure-seekers grow up, exploring new sounds and real-world themes. it’s sometimes formulaic, but maturity looks good on them.

speed run frost children electronic the new york hyperpop duo’s true panther debut is crammed full of ideas but feels creatively vacant: the soundtrack to a party where everyone’s pretending to have fun.
never enough daniel caesar pop/r&b the canadian r&b singer’s sleepy, erratically experimental third album proves that good old-fashioned love songs and heartbreak ballads are still his strong suit.

let me update my status tisakorean rap like a corrupted file ripped straight from limewire, the houston rapper’s new tape smashes together crunk, snap, and souljaboy ad-libs into a blast of nostalgia that’s never stuck in the past.

on the romance of being desire marea experimental after training as a traditional nguni spiritual healer, the south african musician returns with a 13-piece band for an album of divine orchestral soul.

frame & canvas (25th anniversary edition) braid rock on a remastered and remixed edition, the brilliant third record by the champaign, illinois band represents the platonic ideal for what midwest emo has to offer.

brand new life brandee younger jazz pioneering harpist dorothy ashby established the instrument’s place in post-bop jazz. younger pays tribute to ashby’s achievements, covering her songs and tracing her influence on contemporary hip-hop.
muted colors ben sloan experimental the colorado percussionist’s debut solo album is a glitchy sound collage where drums resemble saxophones and voice memos share space with guest vocalists.
blondshell blondshell rock sabrina teitelbaum’s self-titled debut is a candid snapshot of early adulthood, a cruel rotation of bad substances, scummy men, and friendship anxieties.

mythologies thomas bangalter electronic in his first solo project since the group’s dissolution, the former daft punk member swaps his customary synths for a full orchestra—but some old habits die hard.
72 seasons metallica metal at 77 minutes, metallica’s eleventh studio album delivers everything you could want from a metallica album in 2023 and so much more. too much more.
crystal vision nathan fake electronic the english electronic artist pays tribute to his inspirations while maintaining his distinct, masterful sound.
stereo mind game daughter folk/country the moody london indie folk trio return with a stripped-back record inspired by long-distance longing.
leather blvd. b. cool-aid rap the producer and rapper pay homage to urbane black cool with leisurely collages of neo-soul, jazz, and rap. it’s a nice vibe, but the vision wears thin.

the upper cuts (2023 edition) alan braxe electronic, pop/r&b alan braxe’s iconic monograph of french house, originally released in 2005, channels livewire synths, sculpted drums, and tension-stoking filters into a steady succession of dopamine hits.

with a hammer yaeji electronic yaeji’s debut channels a lifetime’s worth of anger into an airy blend of synth-pop, jazz, techno, and ambient. it’s a generous, understated exploration of rage as a source of creative renewal.

bastard jargon nakhane experimental, pop/r&b where the south african singer-songwriter’s work was tinged with melancholy, their new album, executive produced by nile rodgers, renders carnal ecstasy in bright tones and major keys.
rat saw god wednesday rock wednesday’s noisy, rangy sound finds a home in the quiet, lonely corners of america. their outstanding new album is why they’re one of the best indie rock bands around.

instant vintage raphael saadiq pop/r&b each sunday, pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. today, we revisit raphael saadiq’s 2002 debut, a meticulously crafted record that bridged generations of soul and r&b.

gallows wine calvin johnson rock following the blues influences of his last solo album, the k records founder’s new record offers a restless pastiche of primitive rock’n’roll, rockabilly, cowpoke ditties, and living-room dub.

when it’s going wrong marta złakowska electronic the short but well-developed debut from the polish singer features close collaborations with the trip-hop luminary as they conjure a hushed, alluring atmosphere.

the complete scepter singles 1962-1973 dionne warwick rock this compilation is an ideal introduction to a defining voice of the ’60s: a sweeping survey of pop songs as prayers for compassion, consolation, and commitment
jasmine on a night in july scree jazz falling somewhere between bill frisell’s basement and the mediterranean sea, the debut from this instrumental brooklyn trio marks a promising arrival.
reclaim pépe electronic the spanish producer’s evocative debut album exists in an interzone where the natural world seems forever on the cusp of swallowing up the constructed one.
peach blossom piotr kurek experimental the polish composer’s sumptuous new album draws on renaissance-era vocal music, contemporary theater, and the uncanny magic of auto-tune.

miracle-level deerhoof experimental recorded in single takes with minimal overdubs, the san francisco band’s latest album—its first sung entirely in satomi matsuzaki’s native japanese—is a confident set of small epiphanies.
gisela noia pop/r&b the brooklyn-based, barcelona-born musician’s debut album is a dense but cohesive statement on duality, equally shaped by catalan identity and future-leaning cosmic pop.
no highs tim hecker experimental the veteran ambient musician pushes back at the hollowing out of the form with a burly, physically imposing release peppered with moments of gentle beauty.

call me if you get lost: the estate sale tyler, the creator rap the deluxe edition is a continuation of the album’s block-spinning flexes, the pertinent one being that even his b-sides are unforgettable.
duo deleite duo deleite rap two of puerto rico’s most promising independent rappers join forces for a summer-ready album, threading samba and ballroom into the worlds of r&b and reggaeton.
sundown eddie chacon pop/r&b teaming with producer john carroll kirby, the r&b singer sets an idyllic, spiritual mood while contemplating the weight of the world.
let the moon be a planet steve gunn folk/country, experimental the guitarist and the pianist collaborate for an album of gentle, edgeless improvisations.
my vision luh tyler rap the teenage tallahassee rapper fast-tracks a summer-ready debut mixtape that’s in touch with his florida roots.

imagine this is a high dimensional space of all possibilities james holden electronic after experiments in free jazz and psychedelia, the uk producer reckons with the rave music of his youth. it’s a utopian project that melds dance music’s forms with an organic sensibility.
the great escape larry june rap on their first joint album, the veteran producer’s relaxed tempos and the san francisco rapper’s coolheaded flows slide together with easy fluidity.
continue as a guest the new pornographers rock on a sleek and subdued new album, a.c. newman takes the lead and reflects on the isolation of modern life.

rookie’s bustle ada rook electronic, experimental, metal armed with breakbeats, gnarled riffs, and her most uplifting songwriting yet, the black dresses musician maps an arduous path toward love and security.
drag on girard purling hiss rock on its first album in seven years, the philly band jams and shreds and searches for a groove.
punter punter rock the australian punk band refuses to forgive and forget on a nuanced, ambitious punk record.
in pieces chlöe pop/r&b beyoncé protégé chloe bailey is a generational talent, but the generic songwriting and chemistry-free features on her solo debut don’t make the case.
only constant gel rock the new jersey band’s debut lp sticks to time-tested hardcore formulas, but even within those bounds—and in under 17 minutes—the group discovers whole universes.
exodus the north star yaya bey pop/r&b the brooklyn singer and songwriter sounds more hopeful and more vulnerable on a mellow, reggae-infused companion ep to last year’s album.

generational curse icecoldbishop rap the battled-tested l.a. rapper’s debut combines technical skill and narrative ambition for a gripping album about broken systems and the drudgery of art always imitating life.
the price of progress the hold steady rock the brooklyn band’s ninth album is vivid and weird: a celebration of second winds, unlikely comebacks, and undying rock’n’roll dreams.
honky château (50th anniversary edition) elton john rock a new reissue of elton john’s pivotal seventh album highlights its whimsical, rough-hewn charm just as the artist was becoming a superstar.

the record boygenius rock julien baker, phoebe bridgers, and lucy dacus devote their debut record to their singular bond. each amplifies the other’s songwriting, enriches the detail, and heightens the emotion.

绿帽 green hat tzusing electronic on his second album, the malaysian-born, shanghai- and taipei-based producer interweaves industrial-strength techno and asian instruments into a potent expression of rage and anxiety.
scaring the hoes jpegmafia rap the iconoclastic rappers collide on a jpeg-produced joint album that plays things fast and loose.

requiem for jazz angel bat dawid jazz the chicago composer and clarinetist’s latest album interrogates the supposed “death” of jazz. structured as an afrofuturist requiem, it offers an impassioned look at the genre’s role in black history.

live at bush hall black country, new road experimental, rock over a three-night stand in london last december, the uk group evolved from rousing post-punks to an irreverent dinner-theater act. yet the soundtrack of all-new songs feels like a natural evolution.

did you know that there’s a tunnel under ocean blvd lana del rey pop/r&b the singer-songwriter’s ninth album arrives as a sweeping, sterling, often confounding work of self-mythology and psychoamericana: lana’s in the zone.

warren zevon warren zevon rock each sunday, pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. today, we revisit warren zevon’s 1976 breakthrough, an unforgettable collection of rock songs as short stories set in a seedy, mythological american west.

love in exile arooj aftab jazz, experimental recording live in the studio with just voice, keys, and bass, the trio achieves an almost telepathic connection: three seasoned musicians breathing together as a single organism.

the art of forgetting caroline rose rock stylistic shifts and personal reinvention have become par for the course for this new york singer-songwriter. but on their new album, they turn uncharacteristically self-reflective.

amor prohibido selena pop/r&b each sunday, pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. today, we revisit the tejano star’s landmark 1994 album, her magnum opus that redefined the sound of latin pop.
ways of knowing navy blue rap on sage elsesser’s def jam debut, smooth gospel samples set the tone for a worshipful exploration of the ancestral wisdom that guides his present.
93696 liturgy metal on a wildly ambitious 80-minute opus, haela ravenna hunt-hendrix’s shapeshifting metal band reaches its most radiant incarnation yet.
3d & the holograms 3d & the holograms rock the australian band sets tales of the dystopian future to punk rock that’s nasty, cartoonish, and short.
1982 a certain ratio electronic picking up the baton from acolytes like !!! and lcd soundsystem, brit-funk originals acr enter their fifth decade with an energized take on an old sound.

the town that cursed your name the reds, pinks & purples rock the latest record from glenn donaldson chronicles the ups-and-downs of music industry lifers, searching for pockets of transcendence amid ennui.
with love from aly & aj rock the sister duo takes influence from fleetwood mac on a breezy album defined by warm harmonies and easygoing pop melodies.
till i’m dead rxk nephew rap on his supposed debut album, the hyper-prolific rochester rapper upgrades his fidelity and sharpens his focus.
due in color andrea electronic on his latest album, the prolific turin producer aims to hybridize dancefloor potency and dreamy ambience.
since i have a lover 6lack pop/r&b the east atlanta artist is typically an excellent mood curator, but on his first full-length in five years, he feels uncharacteristically dull.
mad est gee rap the louisville rapper has a keen talent for bridging regional styles. the uninspired beats on his new album fail to light up the map.

yian lucinda chua pop/r&b, experimental on her debut album, the london-based cellist and composer explores her experiences as a child of the chinese diaspora. musically and conceptually, the record evokes hazy, in-between spaces.
memento mori depeche mode electronic, rock on their most engaged album in a quarter-century, martin gore and dave gahan find that familiar sounds can offer several new ways forward.
false lankum lankum folk/country the dublin group has spent a decade making folk music sound foreign and transfixing. its spellbinding new album uncovers eerie new depths in centuries-old forms.
joe ely joe ely folk/country, rock
bad premonition tei shi pop/r&b the colombian-canadian singer-songwriter’s latest ep refines her stylish, reflective pop but leans on too uniform of a palette.

voyageur ali farka touré folk/country, global, pop/r&b a collection of songs the iconic malian guitarist and his collaborators recorded at jam sessions and concert rehearsals between 1991 and 2004 reflects the timeless vitality of his music.
songs of surrender u2 rock spearheaded by the edge, this collection of stripped-down, re-imagined u2 songs is a frustrating missed opportunity.

praise a lord who chews but which does not consume; (or simply, hot between worlds) yves tumor rock the art-rock auteur’s latest album is a glistening, richly detailed world that feels like a culmination of their ever-escalating talent and ambition.

fantasy m83 electronic, rock on his ninth album, anthony gonzalez is still trying to recapture childhood’s pangs of wonderment. this time, his nostalgia leads him back to the youthful drama of his own .

v unknown mortal orchestra rock on his fifth album, ruban nielson accompanies some of his strongest songwriting and performances to date with foggy production that makes the whole thing feel like a long, rummy sigh.
eye of delirious bryozone electronic, experimental ganna bryzhata’s ethereal, shape-shifting electroacoustic experiments feel equally conducive to beatific calm and deep melancholy.

10,000 gecs 100 gecs experimental, electronic the madcap duo’s second album is about many things—junk food, being dumb, the ska revival—but mostly it’s about two savants making pop music sound absurdly fun.

kosogor kosaya gora experimental, electronic on their first official duo project, longtime collaborators kedr livanskiy and flaty trade their customary dance influences for atmospheric dream pop steeped in folk, goth, and trip-hop.

…and don’t the kids just love it television personalities rock each sunday, pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. today, we revisit a genre-defining debut from 1981 featuring the acerbic dan treacy and his clever, fragile, timeless songs.

a new tomorrow zulu metal injecting blastbeats and mosh-worthy riffs with classic soul and reggae samples, the los angeles hardcore band’s debut insists on a complex and irreducible vision of blackness.
say what you like doug paisley folk/country on his first new album since 2018, the canadian songwriter with the gentle country lilt laments almost everything.

the complete singles inspiral carpets rock this collection tells the full story of a madchester band that’s never quite gotten its due, documenting tentative forays into acid house alongside tight, ’60s-inspired songwriting.

notorious dump legends: volume 2 mach-hommy rap the rappers deliver an album filled with serpentine, enigmatic stories and gloomy beats. it doesn’t have the gloss and pomp of their best work, but it highlights the pair’s complementary gifts.
the ceiling reposes lia kohl experimental the chicago cellist duets with scraps of radio and field recordings on her bold and strangely moving second record.
1822.demos uly pop/r&b the irish-filipino singer’s elegant new mixtape blends soulful grooves with sci-fi dreaminess.
less deathcrash rock the london slowcore band’s second album is a gentle refinement with an atmosphere of loss.

sunrise bang ur head against tha wall nia archives electronic on her second solo ep in two years, the rising uk producer leans into her fusion of jungle breaks and irresistible melodies. her emotional acuity reveals the makings of a uniquely talented pop writer.
milk for flowers h. hawkline pop/r&b the welsh songwriter’s fifth album flits between whimsical psych-pop levity and candid expressions of grief. at its best, it brings the two together.
radial gate sluice folk/country north carolina singer-songwriter justin morris writes with a sense of offhand intimacy, shading familiar appalachian guitar textures with memory and ambiguity.
uk grim sleaford mods rock it’s the irascible british duo’s most varied album to date. just don’t expect anything to change.
endless summer vacation miley cyrus pop/r&b behind its carefree title, miley cyrus’ eighth album is an edgeless and synthetic collection of disco-pop bummer jams.

blacklips bar: androgyns and deviants - industrial romance for bruised and battered angels, 1992–1995 various artists a new compilation looks back on the storied new york drag ensemble where anohni got her start, placing the troupe in a lineage of queer artists who treated drag as a means of accessing selfhood.

glim kmru electronic, experimental this digital-exclusive album from the berlin-based kenyan artist sounds blank and unrevealing but opens up to reveal a wealth of detail. it’s prickly, insidious, and at times grueling.
ugly slowthai rap the british rapper’s third album is likely to be his most polarizing: he trades rapping and electronic beats for ballads and rage rock. the results are largely underwhelming.
somebody’s child chunky rap on his most substantial solo release to date, the longstanding club mc slots into manchester’s rich lineage of maverick dance musicians.
oh me oh my lonnie holley experimental at 73, the outsider artist has made his most ambitious and approachable album: an extraordinary aural memoir that tells a cosmic story of survival.

rotten bun for an eggless century mui zyu electronic, pop/r&b on her debut solo album, the dama scout singer explores her heritage and grapples with otherness in knotty electro-pop shot through with field recordings and traditional chinese instruments.
kyiv eternal heinali electronic the ukrainian electronic musician collages a decade of field recordings into a moving tribute to the resilience of his hometown in wartime.
radical romantics fever ray electronic karin dreijer’s richly detailed third album renders the search for love as something both sensual and alien.
gumbo young nudy rap the east atlanta rapper’s latest project is full of whimsical beats and datpiff-era nostalgia. it proves you don’t need shiny pop hooks to make a thrilling rap record in 2023.

elegies for the drift joe westerlund experimental the former megafaun drummer uses a resonant, melodic palette of gamelan, thumb piano, and metallophones to achieve gemlike tones and ambient atmospheres.

the gold experience prince pop/r&b, rock each sunday, pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. today, we revisit prince’s best album of the ’90s, a funked-out opus mired in extra-musical drama.
ben macklemore rap macklemore’s earnest yet clunky new album attempts to split the difference between high-budget stadium pop and grimy boom-bap.

a view of a landscape kevin beasley experimental l’rain, jlin, kelsey lu, jason moran, and more join the sculptor and sound artist for a meditation on the complex histories evoked by the antique cotton gin at the center of his 2018 whitney museum exhibition.

post-american mspaint rock on its debut album, the mississippi synth-punk band hones a sound characterized by unlikely combinations: frenzied rhythms and tranquil synths, blistering riffs and hopeful lyrics.

music madonna pop/r&b each sunday, pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. today, we revisit madonna’s first album of the new millennium, a maximalist dance-pop experiment that made the people come together.

gemini girl: the complete hush recordings laurie styvers folk/country, pop/r&b collected on a new anthology, the two albums from the supple-voiced ’70s singer-songwriter mine the internal turmoil of coming of age.

extreme fantasy morgan garrett experimental the philadelphia-based artist uses damaged acoustic guitars, piercing electronics, and unsettling vocals to construct a grotesque and hermetic world, conjuring visions of abject terror.
godcaster godcaster rock, experimental the brooklyn art-rock band continues to be proudly over the top on its relentless and theatrical second album.
outerwear szn 3 bub styles rap loaded with snarled rhymes and hyperlocal references, the brooklyn rapper’s latest tape is a thrilling, larger-than-life depiction of new york hip-hop cornerstones.
thanks 4 nothing tink pop/r&b though a couple of safe songs threaten to slow the momentum, the chicago artist sounds more defiant and grounded than ever on her fourth album.

wow kate nv experimental the russian electronic musician’s latest album turns pointillist quirks into erratic maximalism—call it pop music for people who enjoy both karlheinz stockhausen and lisa frank.
red moon in venus kali uchis pop/r&b on her lush and captivating third album, the pop star looks to the heavens, summoning the cosmic power of love and the divine feminine.

soul’d out: the complete wattstax collection various artists stax records’ historic 1972 soul festival finally gets its due with a new 12-disc box set, presenting a pop label at its imperial peak and an unmediated vision of blackness for a rapt audience.
cluster i mioclono electronic the debut album from the duo of john talabot and fellow barcelona producer velmondo spins a shadowy, subterranean web.

feeling body nyokabi kariũki experimental on her debut album, the kenyan composer folds field recordings, ambient textures, and layered vocalizations into a gripping meditation on illness and healing.

food near me, weather tomorrow babybaby_explores rock the rhode island trio’s weirdo avant-pop tunes land somewhere between the subversive, no-wave skronk of bush tetras and the lo-fi minimalism of sneaks.

even god has a sense of humor maxo rap the california rapper takes stock of his life on an introspective album that balances melancholy and bliss over lush, sampled loops and opulent live-band instrumentation.
aurora daisy jones & the six rock the soundtrack for a new amazon original series seeks to emulate the magic of fleetwood mac. more often than not, it ends up sounding like a broadway tribute.
i play my bass loud gina birch rock the debut solo album from the raincoats bassist is adventurous and collaborative and vibrant and furious.
strange dance philip selway rock the radiohead drummer returns with a solo album whose beautiful, dramatic arrangements clash with the bland songwriting.

the songs of bacharach & costello elvis costello rock, pop/r&b centered on 1998’s timeless , this new compilation showcases the songwriters’ unlikely collaboration and the malleable and enduring songs that emerged from it.

7s avey tare experimental rooted in demos made early in the pandemic, avey tare’s fourth solo album is unusual and slightly disarming: a head-over-heels-in-love album that’s also prickly and claustrophobic.

burnin’ (expanded edition) john lee hooker jazz, rock featuring his eternal hit “boom boom,” the blues legend’s 1962 classic gets an anniversary reissue that showcases how rock’n’roll took shape around his timeless, elemental boogie.

19 naughty iii naughty by nature rap when hip-hop was split between being an industry force or a niche subculture, the new jersey trio’s second album proved they could bridge the gap between commercial success and artistic credibility.
cookup sam gendel jazz the ambient-jazz saxophonist offers unpredictable, impressionistic takes on r&b hits from the ’90s and early ’00s, tackling songs by beyoncé, aaliyah, and erykah badu.
amar bigxthaplug rap though it sometimes follows rags-to-riches templates a little too closely, the texas rapper’s debut is a compelling blend of theater and technical intricacy.
dogsbody model/actriz rock, electronic on its debut album, the new york band’s expertly contained noise-rock din is the perfect foil to frontman cole haden’s white-hot charisma.

goodnight neanderthal gee tee rock on his second album, the sydney punk fleshes out his filthy bubblegum scuzz with riffs, jokes, the requisite car song, and even a few unexpectedly vulnerable moments.
another planet 4 phiik rap the new york rappers’ complementary styles unlock a world of imagistic detail and surreal coincidence.

i don’t wanna be too cool (expanded edition) kate fagan rock captured tracks issues an expanded lp version of songwriter kate fagan’s 1981 single, a cheeky rejoinder to consumerist status-seeking that became a diy hit.
practice free range rock sofia jensen’s gentle indie-folk debut is a portrait of growing up with soul-baring lyrics and occasional breakthroughs.

mind palace music @ folk/country the philadelphia/baltimore duo recorded their 2021 debut remotely from their respective bedrooms, but the album—newly reissued by carpark—captures the spirit of folk-pop at its most intimate.

the future leonard cohen rock each sunday, pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. today, we revisit leonard cohen at the end of history, wielding the darkest, glossiest, most bizarrely righteous songs of his career.
food for worms shame rock the british rockers’ third album peels away from the talky post-punk pack, emphasizing melody, ramshackle piano, and reflections on friendship.
one thing at a time morgan wallen folk/country modern country’s prodigal son returns with a 36-song album that says a whole lot of nothing.
good riddance gracie abrams pop/r&b the artist’s full-length debut is an honest step forward, but emotional vulnerability can’t save it from the clichés of confessional songwriting.
should’ve learned by now lucero rock the memphis alt-country lifers return with an endearing, impassioned album about drinking and the many reasons we do it.

workin’ on a world iris dement folk/country on her first collection of original material in over a decade, the country-folk songwriter frames observations of modern life in timeless american musical forms.
1980 katrina krimsky experimental these unearthed recordings of an early solo piano performance showcase the composer’s ecstatic approach to melody and repetition.
anthronomicon ulthar metal
shook algiers rock with a crew of equally radical peers in tow, the atlanta band’s new album is a dissonant but hopeful statement about dreaming up a better world.

bless this mess u.s. girls pop/r&b meg remy’s most free-ranging and least narrative-minded album draws on retro funk and ’80s r&b as it infuses her biting social critique and wry humor with fresh optimism.

cracker island gorillaz electronic, rock stevie nicks, thundercat, tame impala, and bad bunny guest on the latest album from damon albarn’s cartoon band, but despite the marquee names, the record feels frustratingly like gorillaz as usual.
flounder quinnie pop/r&b the new jersey indie-folk singer’s debut is a refreshingly modern take on classic themes of displacement, devolution, and love, of course.

season of glass yoko ono experimental each sunday, pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. today, we revisit the first album yoko ono recorded after the death of her husband, a brittle and gorgeous capsule of hope triumphing over grief.
glow wesley joseph pop/r&b, rap the british singer, rapper, and producer’s second project approaches the challenge of self-discovery through graceful avant-r&b.

夢之駭客 dream hacker otay:onii experimental singing in english and mandarin, the berklee-educated vocalist and experimental musician uses oddball pop melodies, distorted breaks, and swirling drones to explore themes of anxiety and selfhood.
like dying stars, we’re reaching out runnner rock noah weinman’s cloudy, spacious indie folk songs ruminate on the limits of human communication.
release spirit khotin electronic on a lively new album, the electronic producer is a master of atmosphere, creating a mood of childlike whimsy while teasing a future in dream-pop songwriting.
extra life ep crushed rock on its debut ep, the los angeles duo pulls from favorite sounds of the 1990s to create effortless, widescreen dream pop that’s serene without being sentimental.

the corner: vol. 1 jadasea rap with terse existential inquiries and sun-faded samples, the full-length collaboration between the london rapper and the brooklyn producer sounds at home on two continents.
quest for fire skrillex electronic

desire pathway screaming females rock the new jersey band turns in another solid album of old-school riffs and ripping solos, but the songs stop just short of the radio-rock anthems they want to become.
our likeness phew experimental on her 1992 album, the iconoclastic vocalist and her band of german experimentalists pushed each other to virtuosic extremes, spanning styles and genres.
mourning due nappy nina rap the hushed flows from the brooklyn-based rapper are compelling, but some of her stories struggle to captivate.

desire, i want to turn into you caroline polachek pop/r&b caroline polachek’s best album of her career is a transformative pop experience, a passionate, richly melodic odyssey into the darkest corners of love.

audiodidactic lance skiiiwalker pop/r&b seven years after his debut, the top dawg fixture returns to his habitual stylistic fusions but too often, his muddy, psychedelic haze fails to summon the dreamlike quality it’s aiming for.

sugar world jonatan leandoer96 rap the swedish artist better known as yung lean makes an unexpected pivot on his long-running side project, swapping out sad rap and vaporwave to embrace his inner crooner.
lil spirits two shell electronic the uk mystery duo’s new ep is a more playful affair than , more explicit in its internet-brained aesthetics—yet a little less exciting, too.
land of sleeper pigs pigs pigs pigs pigs pigs pigs metal the uk quintet has a blast playing old-school stoner metal, balancing the riffs with sharp songwriting and a touch of camp.

transmissions from total refreshment centre total refreshment centre jazz produced in collaboration with blue note, a new collection documents some of the artists and sounds emanating from the london cultural institution at the epicenter of contemporary jazz.
maritz jonnine folk/country, experimental on a charming new solo album, the htrk vocalist writes lighthearted folk music about loss and longing.
anevite void erika electronic more science than fiction, detroit techno maven erika sherman’s lean and icy new album plugs into the subtle environmental flux of an alien planet.

the land, the water, the sky black belt eagle scout rock katherine paul’s third album of patient, cinematic indie rock surveys a return trip to her ancestral lands in the swinomish indian tribal community—and the hard-won peace she found once she arrived.
all fiction pile rock on their latest album, the boston trio explores an eerie, percussion-heavy sound that maintains the adventurous spirit of their best work.
segue to infinity laraaji experimental the numero release includes some of laraaji’s breathtaking, newly discovered zither and kalimba odysseys. it reaffirms his preeminent role in ambient history.

oh glistening onion, the nighttime is coming pearla folk/country, rock on her debut album, the brooklyn folk singer writes vividly detailed songs about the peculiarities of human emotion, turning existential questions into playful country romps and homey campfire songs.
girl in the half pearl liv.e pop/r&b liv.e’s brilliant second album bends her expressive r&b into fearsome new shapes, acknowledging all the nuance and pain on the long journey to personal truth.

complex simplicity teedra moses pop/r&b each sunday, pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. today, we revisit teedra moses’ silken debut, a cult classic of 2000s r&b.
war lord talibando rap with shades of late-’90s new orleans and mid-aughts trap, the detroit rapper’s newest mixtape casts an ominous spell even when his writing isn’t at its strongest.
dust gatherers seaming to experimental on her first solo album in over a decade, the avant-pop artist weaves introspective thoughts through shapeshifting, operatic arrangements.
he left nothing for the swim back skech185 rap on his full-length backwoodz debut, skech185’s hoarsely confrontational rapping finds a perfect match in producer jeff markey’s jumpy, abrasive beats.
this is why paramore rock hayley williams and co. pivot to jittery, crackling post-punk on their sixth album, but the monotone vocals and political lyrics don’t always play to their strengths.
pollen tennis rock much as it always has, the married duo’s confectionary indie pop lands somewhere between pleasantly forgettable, reliably vibey, and genuinely inspiring.
moments of clarity narrow head rock the houston rock band’s third album captures a certain kind of painful, melodic bliss that comes in the wake of a crisis.
let her burn rebecca black pop/r&b to shed the stigma of “friday,” rebecca black reinvents herself as a desperate hyperpop star.
norm andy shauf rock the canadian musician’s latest album is his most ambitious yet: a lush, cryptic, and creepy suite that questions the very concept of love.
raven kelela pop/r&b kelela’s rapturous second album is a masterful display of tension and release, centering queer black womanhood through blasts of heated dance music and ambient comedowns.
rush! måneskin rock the italian rock band has become a global sensation. their new album is absolutely terrible at every conceivable level.
new york city the men rock the brooklyn band’s ninth album is an unpretentious garage-punk racket that wears its analog heart on flannel-clad sleeves.
breaking the balls of history quasi experimental, rock after a decade, janet weiss and sam coomes’ band returns with an album that’s musically rejuvenated but lyrically nearsighted.

smalltown stardust king tuff rock steeped in the warm, psychedelic pop-rock of the 1970s, the new record from erstwhile garage rocker kyle thomas is a gold-toned nostalgia voyage that’s never entirely familiar.
university! popstar benny rap full of plinking synths, blown-out bass, and skittering beats, the atlanta producer’s latest compilation sounds like the flyest rap video game never made.

anarchist gospel sunny war folk/country, pop/r&b, rock the los angeles folk-punk singer-songwriter steps into a more expansive, considered sound, blending various strains of american roots music into a quietly idiosyncratic style.

heavy heavy young fathers experimental, electronic, pop/r&b defined by small acts of joyful resistance, the edinburgh group’s fourth album is a celebration of music as shared and spontaneous practice.
petals ep toumba electronic on his debut ep for hessle audio, the jordanian producer brings regional rhythms and arabic maqam scales to cutting-edge club music.
today my friend you drunk the venom the drin rock the cincinnati post-punks craft melodic, hard-driving pop in service of eerie, unsolvable riddles.

my 21st century blues raye pop/r&b the uk pop upcomer put her former record label on blast, then scored her first no. 1 hit. her debut full-length makes an ambitious but uneven bid for independent stardom.
colours of air loscil electronic, experimental two artists from opposite sides of the ambient spectrum find common cause in a 132-year-old pipe organ.
the waeve the waeve rock combining modular synth, saxophone, and a medieval lute, graham coxon and rose elinor dougall create an album of pastoral disquiet and itchy post-punk edge.
the candle and the flame robert forster rock accompanied by family members and former bandmates, the go-betweens songwriter crafts a sparse but deeply felt album.
love is war reuben vincent rap the north carolina rapper refines his technical wizardry on his second album, but he’s too often buried by 9th wonder and khrysis’ overblown production.

portrait of a dog jonah yano electronic featuring the jazzy tones of badbadnotgood, the second album from the hiroshima-born, montreal-based singer-songwriter explores heartbreak and familial history with a subtle and dynamic approach.
queen of me shania twain folk/country working with a team of hit-making collaborators, the country-pop icon returns with a bland collection of optimistic affirmations and pumping electro-pop rhythms.
this stupid world yo la tengo rock on their liveliest album in at least a decade, indie rock’s most steadfast institution squares up against ubiquitous darkness.
chess moves tha god fahim rap the underground hip-hop veteran’s new ep flirts with chess metaphors, but the mundane raps don’t help the thematic wallpaper hold up.
great is he popcaan pop/r&b trite where it should be subtle and mellow where it should be exciting, the jamaican star’s new album fails to consistently capture his magic.
wendy will epstein rock on his new album, the nicolás jaar collaborator undergoes a vivid technicolor upgrade but his songwriting doesn’t always leave an impression.
living mark william lewis rock the london singer-songwriter’s debut lp frames big themes—the heaviness of life and death, the duality in ecstasy and pain—in skeletal, atmospheric indie rock.
after the magic 파란노을 (parannoul) rock on the south korean artist’s astounding third album, the past and the present, the real and the fake dissolve seamlessly into surreal, maximalist pop music.
the abyssal plain dryad metal the iowa black metal quartet’s debut explores the mystery of the deep seas with shapeshifting, dynamic songwriting.

workshop 32 kassem mosse electronic german deep-house technician gunnar wendel’s new album for the workshop label clears away the murk of his early work, achieving disorienting effects with its oddly pristine palette.

anthology of american folk music, vol. 1-3 various artists each sunday, pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. today, we revisit harry smith’s foundational 1952 mixtape that used the united states’ rich musical inheritance to suggest how we might better ourselves.

we cater to cowards oozing wound metal the chicago headbangers’ fifth lp is a confident nod to early grunge. it’s an unusually succinct statement for them, with leaner songwriting and more pointed barbs.
audiolust & higherlove sg lewis electronic the second album from the uk pop producer is pleasant and anonymous, all good vibes and cabana jams.
letters to george george jazz featuring dual saxophones, synthesizers, voice, and drums, the new group led by montreal composer john hollenbeck analyzes pop songcraft through a jazz lens.

fragments - time out of mind sessions (1996-1997): the bootleg series, vol. 17 bob dylan rock spanning the sessions for 1997’s , an illuminating new edition of bob dylan’s bootleg series both subverts and magnifies the legend of his haunted, trancelike comeback album.
every acre h.c. mcentire rock tranquil and reverberant, the north carolina folk songwriter’s new album finds relief and resolution in the circadian rhythms of the natural world.
blue period beauty pill rock a remastered double-lp compilation of the d.c. art-punks’ early 2000s material showcases their atmospheric, wurtlitzer-haloed approach to indie rock.
furling meg baird folk/country largely centered on the piano, the songwriter’s first solo album in eight years is wistful, heady, and mesmerizing.
dead meat the tubs rock former joanna gruesome guitarist owen “o” williams’ new group taps into the chiming sound of ’80s college rock, channeling a wide range of jangly inspirations.
let’s start here. lil yachty rap, rock despite its intriguing concept, lil yachty’s voyage into soul and psych-rock runs aground.
honey samia rock after an arresting opener, the singer-songwriter’s second album wanders into a fog of existential angst and you-had-to-be-there anecdotes.
one day fucked up rock, metal with anthemic hardcore hooks and unabashed lyrics about the power of love, the toronto band’s latest album radiates fired-up joy.

fatima ruhail qaisar electronic, experimental a psychogeographic survey of the himalayan region of ladakh rendered in ambient drones and harsh noise, doubles as an uneasy chronicle of capitalist exploitation and generational trauma.

graffiti in space strategy electronic, experimental turning his ear for imperfection toward dub techno, versatile producer paul dickow turns out six tracks that conceal worlds of activity under their grimy patina.
lobes we are scientists electronic, rock steeped in ’80s revivalism, the new york dance-rockers’ eighth album is a hazy tapestry of half-remembered sounds and shopworn tropes.
before the gloss up gloss up rap in spite of a few obligatory major label maneuvers, the memphis rapper’s debut mixtape preserves her charisma with a rush of shit-talking and warning shots.
gloria sam smith pop/r&b sam smith remains a bit of a pop paradox, a trailblazing figure who often settles into well-trodden songwriting.

does spring hide its joy kali malone experimental presented as a sprawling three-hour epic, the composer’s drone piece for guitar, cello, and sine wave oscillators seeks new rhythms within the interminable sweep of pandemic time.
asking for a ride white reaper rock the louisville rock band refines its major-label sound on a brief but charming new album: it hits hardest when you don’t think too much about it.
to what end oddisee rap on his 10th solo studio album, the brooklyn-based underground rap vet unpacks emotional baggage and asks what—if anything—he’s willing to compromise for the sake of success.

stillmatic nas rap each sunday, pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. today, we revisit the 2001 resurrection of nas, a canonical comeback album that came out swinging and never backed down.
mercy john cale rock on an often chilly album full of unexpected collaborations and smeared with apocalyptic terror, the 80-year-old art-rock legend grapples with the need for human connection.
surgery channel the c.i.a. rock ty and denée segall, along with the cairo gang’s emmett kelly, refine their abrasive sound on a record that writhes, swells, and undulates like the belly of a serpent.

rap game awful clavish rap the rising road-rap talent has built his name on a mixture of sinister detachment and bristling ambition. yet despite his aloof, exacting style, he stretches himself thin on this 28-track mixtape.

ace (50th anniversary deluxe edition) bob weir rock featuring multiple songs that became staples of the grateful dead’s live set, the 1972 solo debut by the guitarist and singer gets a deluxe edition with a new mix and some recent live recordings.

a short diary sebastian rochford jazz, experimental, folk/country on a set inspired by his father’s death, jazz drummer sebastian rochford enlists pianist kit downes, a longtime collaborator, to help him tell a story about company and grief.
saccades rian treanor electronic propulsive and winding, this collaborative album is a hypnotic exercise in reimagining the past and future of a ugandan tradition.
time’s arrow ladytron pop/r&b on its seventh album, the liverpool electro-pop band reaches for a lighter sound, capturing the passage of time in effervescent synths and impressionistic lyrics.
like..? ice spice rap the crown princess of bronx drill arrives with a down-to-earth attitude and a diabolical knack for hooks. assume her naïveté at your own peril.
five easy hot dogs mac demarco rock a listless album about being listless, mac demarco’s new collection of instrumentals summons the bleary, exhausted feeling of time spent on the road.

drifting mette henriette jazz, experimental with pianist johan lindvall and cellist judith hamann, saxophonist and composer mette henriette presents hushed, repetitive meditations unbounded by the pressures of time.

impossible princess kylie minogue pop/r&b each sunday, pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. today, we revisit the australian superstar’s 1997 departure to clubland, a misunderstood journey of self-discovery that became the black sheep of her catalog.

the predator nominate ep brainiac rock a set of previously unreleased demos for the influential dayton band’s never-completed major label debut offers a fascinating glimpse into their strange, singular evolution.

aftersun (original motion picture soundtrack) oliver coates experimental the composer and cellist’s score for charlotte wells’ film is full of suggestion and shadows, wringing emotion from the lightest touches.
cyclamen núria graham rock, pop/r&b the irish-catalan singer-songwriter’s latest release is playful and elliptical, as reverent of folk-pop as it is invested in experimenting with it.

cr​é​puscule i & ii tujiko noriko electronic intimate yet cinematic, the japanese musician’s new two-part album exchanges her colorful pop patchwork for soft, luminous ambient music of alien beauty and human warmth.

monsters of rap various artists each sunday, pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. today, we revisit a tacky, mail-order compilation that strangely, almost perfectly encapsulates the class of early-’90s pop-rap.

bin reaper 3: new testament babytron rap on the fourth tape in his series, the michigan breakout looks to level up with slicker beats and bigger cosigns. fortunately, he’s still rapping about nba stars and .

late developers belle and sebastian rock on the quick follow-up to last year’s , the glasgow indie-pop band’s on-the-fly energy and head-in-the-clouds musings collide in memorable and surprising ways.

free 03 03 greedo rap on a new tape marking his release from prison, the los angeles rapper and folk hero sounds battered but resilient, mixing studio sessions with tracks recorded over the phone from inside.
prize rozi plain folk/country working with minimalist guitar, gentle vocals, and an understated rhythm section, the english musician constructs a careful lesson about the awe of being present.
12 ryuichi sakamoto experimental in a dozen somber, elegiac pieces for piano and electronics recorded in the wake of a cancer diagnosis, the japanese composer reckons with his own mortality.
strays margo price folk/country embracing cosmic empathy and some welcome collaborations, the nashville songwriter’s fourth album bursts with easy confidence and kind, stoic wisdom.
la sustancia x villano antillano rap the puerto rican rapper wields impeccable flows and pointed barbs into a forceful statement of queer caribbean spirit.

every loser iggy pop rock working with pop architect andrew watt, the agelessly incendiary rocker unfurls a parade of timeless archetypes: profane punk, seedy crooner, lovable curmudgeon. it’s iggy pop as a jukebox musical.

songs for the willow ep one step closer rock the wilkes-barre hardcore band blends singalong accessibility, purgative heaviness, and thoughtful craft into songs about the disconnect between dreams and reality.
afrikantis lil b rap, experimental this is lil b’s most head-turning proposition in years: an avant-garde electro-jazz album seemingly recorded with the cheapest midi presets on the market.
oh no ep itoa electronic drawing from footwork, jungle, acid, and more, the uk producer lets his breakneck tempos lead him to some of his funkiest, most kinetic—and oddly beautiful—work to date.
sorry 4 da ooze tae dawg rap surfing between piano-driven minimalism and hazy synth experiments, the maryland rapper’s latest mixtape seeks the next evolution of dmv rap.

the water is the shovel of the shore shovel dance collective rock, folk/country laying bare the strangeness of their repertoire while connecting centuries-old songs to modern struggles, the london collective approaches folk song as a living tradition, not a museum piece.
nadaworld 2 deetranada rap with adrenaline, heart, and an unmistakable baltimore accent, deetranada breathes fresh life into the familiar struggles of the up-and-coming rapper.
suss suss experimental neither rawboned nor ramshackle, the new york group’s elegantly composed brand of ambient country stands as tall and clean as a brand-new pair of cowboy boots.
the work gold panda electronic after six years, derwin dicker returns to his primary project for a lush, sun-drenched set with a genuine emotional charge.

landwerk no. 3 nathan salsburg folk/country on the third album in his series based on loops of early 20th-century, mostly yiddish records, the guitarist and archivist incorporates more instrumentation and more space.
ultratronics ryoji ikeda electronic, rock the glitch pioneer returns with his most accessible album to date: a surprisingly colorful set that sounds like he’s djing a retrospective of his own career.

b-sides, demos & rarities pj harvey rock pj harvey fans have waited a long time for this: a near-exhaustive collection of the singer’s non-album tracks and orphaned gems, many of which rival her classic album cuts.

snoop cube 40 $hort mount westmore rap jumping from the blockchain to streaming platforms, the four west coast ogs offer an album’s worth of trunk-rattling traditionalism that celebrates their exalted elder status.
sauce ghetto gospel 3 sauce walka rap the houston rapper reprises his series, bringing his booming baritone to diaristic confessions and slick songs of celebration.
trillstatik 2 bun b rap written and recorded in a guest-filled marathon session, the texas legend’s second live outing with producer statik selektah carries a spirit of friendly competition.

emergency! the tony williams lifetime jazz, rock each sunday, pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. today, we revisit the birth of jazz fusion, a combustive 1969 album led by a prodigious drummer striking out on his own.
you haven’t missed much thanks for coming rock a compilation from the prolific water from your eyes songwriter offers an endearing tour through their introspective, constantly evolving body of work.

four bill frisell jazz the 71-year-old guitarist has long been known as a peerless interpreter of american musical forms, but on these 13 diaristic originals, he reveals more of himself than ever before.
hotel insomnia for tracy hyde rock the latest album from the japanese shoegaze band shimmers with restless yearning, a sense of wonder kicking like a fluttering heartbeat in the chest.

matter noémi büchi experimental equally inspired by late romantic symphonies and experimental electronic techniques, the swiss composer pushes both classical tropes and ambient conventions to their breaking points.
liquiddd changesss mv carbon rock, experimental on piano and cello, this cross-generational drone partnership finds common ground in the desire to explore the fundamental malleability of sound.
come around carla dal forno electronic the australian songwriter returns with a beachy, airborne set with subtle hints of something darker lurking underneath.

senderos de luz y sombras beatriz ferreyra experimental in a 16-channel piece commissioned for france’s groupe de recherches musicales, the electroacoustic pioneer looks to the origins of the universe and the unconscious mind for inspiration.
paper route frank young dolph rap the memphis rapper’s posthumous album honors his legacy by spotlighting his unmatched charisma, technical prowess, and storytelling flair.
beware of the monkey mike rap mike continues a long run of great records with his self-produced 10th album, a self-assured current of shifting emotional states.
jumping/dancing/fighting hammok rock with a menacing sound and bleak but playful lyrics, the norwegian noise-rock trio stands out from the pack on its debut ep.
my house my rules vigro deep pop/r&b the south african producer behind 2019’s viral hit “untold stories” tests the limits of amapiano, fusing its trademark log drums with established club genres.

take me home pinkpantheress pop/r&b, electronic the london producer’s new three-track ep adds texture and personality to her music without quite innovating on her original, already much-imitated pop formula.
anyhow leland whitty jazz on his solo debut, the badbadnotgood member applies jazz instrumentation and technique to compositions that approach psychedelic rock and dream pop.
niger ep vol. 1 mdou moctar rock
ground groove maral experimental on her third album, the los angeles artist weaves samples of iranian music into a rugged blend of dub and industrial.
keep it lit kamaiyah rap the oakland rapper’s new ep slows her throwback 1990s jams to a leisurely west coast pace.

live at the whisky 1977 cheap trick rock this four-disc set recorded just before cheap trick’s ascent to stardom captures the power-pop icons at their most manic and muscular, sounding more like hungry punks than arena-ready heartthrobs.
to illustrate various artists with each track set around 100 bpm, this compilation from london’s wisdom teeth label allows the artists to stretch out and yield surprisingly dynamic results.
ice, death, planets, lungs, mushrooms and lava king gizzard & the lizard wizard rock
solos dickie landry jazz
live fire black midi rock with a low-stakes live album, the english art-rock band showcases the playfulness that runs through even their most elaborate work.

the smile (live at montreux jazz festival, july 2022) the smile rock the radiohead offshoot’s new live album is both an unexpected treat and a flex, proving the trio can replicate its gnarliest, most thrilling material onstage and sans studio trickery.

full moon mystery garden wicca phase springs eternal rap the gothboiclique affiliate takes a lynchian journey through trap beats, dusty drum breaks, and shoegaze guitar; his vaguely emotive lyrics suggest horrors lurking in the shadows.
premonition white lung rock the canadian punk band’s fifth and final album is a softer, more family-oriented affair, with reflections on motherhood and loss set to metallic riffs.
hypochondriac brakence rock heady, self-loathing, and occasionally overwrought, the ohio singer and producer’s new album plays like an obsessive process document of internet-mediated anxiety.

live at budokan willie nelson rock recorded in 1984, this live set offers a glimpse behind the fog of pot smoke and blur of whiskey when one of country music’s greatest-ever bands was performing at its peak.

yesterday’s tomorrow is not today current rock a totemic box set from numero group collects the output of the midwestern emo band, whose melodic, sentimental take on d.c. hardcore served as a microcosm of the genre’s transition.

call and response stefan goldmann electronic reverb is the sole ingredient on the german-bulgarian artist’s latest conceptual record, in which vintage pedals and digital processors are used to mimic the properties of sound in impossible spaces.

vmak<kombz<<<duglas<<6ndr7<<< douglas mccombs rock, experimental the longtime tortoise bassist picks up lead guitar on his solo debut, a wayward instrumental expedition with a poker-faced sense of humor.

the way it is keyshia cole pop/r&b each sunday, pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. today, we revisit keyshia cole’s 2005 debut, a scrapbook of too-real breakup anthems from a pivotal moment in r&b.
vacabularee valee rap the chicago rapper’s new album contains a few flashes of brilliance, but the aloof flows that set him apart now feel a little too familiar.

the 7" singles paul mccartney rock a ginormous, mostly fans-only box set gathers together 80 records that tell the singular story of a man who has dedicated his entire life to the three-minute pop song.

snake chain shake chain rock mixing viral videos with synths and the unsettling screams of lead singer kate mahony, the london punk quartet delivers an unusual record that’s as funny as it is unhinged.
herbert ab-soul rap after a tumultuous few years, the tde rapper gets personal and sounds reinvigorated, but his worst tendencies as a rapper consistently hold him back.

no thank you little simz rap accolades be damned, the uk star blasts a music industry that has left her feeling drained, adding her voice to a chorus of black british artists pushing back against the status quo.
snake eyes 100 gecs experimental, electronic the mischief-making duo is up to its usual tricks on this three-song, six-minute ep, but it fails to deliver the thrills of the group’s debut.

watertown frank sinatra jazz, pop/r&b each sunday, pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. today, we revisit a fascinating outlier in frank sinatra’s catalog, an unsparing and bleak concept album from 1970.
plasma lotus eater electronic the latest collaboration from luca mortellaro and seth horvitz is a vision of techno as a luminous fog, conjuring vivid imagery with the most stone-faced drones.
all roads lead to the gun (deluxe) militarie gun rock alternating between ruthless hardcore punk and melodic post-hardcore, the los angeles band seek emotional truth that still rips.
heroes & villains metro boomin rap the hitmaking producer’s latest album brandishes his ardent ambition, attention to detail, and gift for curation.
sos sza pop/r&b sza’s long, ambitious, luxurious new album solidifies her position as a generational talent, an artist who translates her innermost feelings into indelible moments.
lucifer on the moon spoon rock on-u sound legend adrian sherwood gives spoon’s latest album a surprisingly sprightly and occasionally awkward dub reconstruction.
mob babyface ray rap with cohesive production and lyrics that veer from tender to stoic, the detroit rapper’s latest is his most meticulous project yet.

a complete anthology of solo and duo violin pieces christian wolff experimental reaching back to the 1950s, this collection highlights the new york school composer’s fragmented, conversational style, as well as his music’s patient, intuitive qualities.
divine symmetry david bowie rock the new -era box set offers a tantalizing peek behind the curtain of bowie’s theatrical persona during arguably the most pivotal moment in his life and career.
palaces of pity malibu experimental the french ambient producer uses the ocean’s duality of stillness and turbulence as inspiration to produce music that ebbs and flows eternally.

live at the fillmore (1997) tom petty rock compiled from a marathon run of shows at the fillmore auditorium, this live set is a joyful, relaxed, and abundant journey through tom petty and the heartbreakers’ personal rock’n’roll history.

type 4: city on the type of forever greydon square rap earnestly didactic “conscious” hip-hop is easy to mock but hard to do well. the compton rapper’s rhyme schemes are persuasive even when his arguments don’t withstand close scrutiny.

dusk pulse emitter electronic the capstone to portland synthesizer musician daryl groetsch’s wildly productive year, runs the gamut of his sound, evoking early ambient classics as it flits between beauty and terror.

100% galcher galcher lustwerk electronic an understated landmark of underground house, galcher lustwerk’s 2013 dj mix receives a remastered 2xlp release. his defiantly unchanging beats feel charged with the knowledge that every party ends.

back to the woodlands ernest hood electronic where his 1975 album was rooted in the sounds of community, these previously unreleased archival recordings capture the oregon wilderness in synths, zither, and field recordings.

his happiness shall come first even though we are suffering backxwash rap on the final entry in a trilogy that began with her polaris prize-winning 2020 album, the montreal rapper seeks elusive redemption in cacophonies of tense noise and gothic samples.

respect the come up meekz rap on his debut mixtape, the manchester rapper deploys his thick, graceful raps with expert precision. it’s a promising opening statement, crafted with candor, wit, and a slick sense of style.
promethean pathology lykotonon metal featuring members of blood incantation, the avant-garde black metal band blends industrial and electronic elements into a seamless whole.

broken spectre ben frost electronic, experimental the experimental composer’s accompaniment for richard mosse’s film installation transforms the natural sounds of the amazon rainforest into a harrowing score to environmental disaster.

and i have been benjamin clementine pop/r&b on his third album—the first part of a projected trilogy—the singer-songwriter retains all his theatrical intensity while shifting his focus to songs about love, a subject he once spurned.

hejira joni mitchell rock each sunday, pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. today, we revisit joni mitchell's eighth album, an iridescent meditation on solitude, a masterpiece in her catalog and across all of music.
on the way to beatenberg ep beatenberg rock the south african indie pop trio returns from hiatus sounding wiser, softer, and as virtuosic as ever.
upright and even mr twin sister pop/r&b the new york band’s alluring new ep of cocktail-lounge house packs a seven-and-a-half-minute dancefloor heater like a magnum of champagne.

world record neil young rock co-produced by rick rubin, neil young’s 42nd album is a mellow, off-kilter collection about the environment, mourning what’s already been lost while expressing a modicum of hope.

foam ulla experimental, electronic drawn mostly from a palette of piano, guitar, and chopped vocal fragments, ulla straus’ new direction in ambient music represents a departure from her previous albums. it’s glitchy, but also human.

this is what i mean stormzy rap the uk rapper’s third album is pitched as both a pious expression of worship and an earnest message of self-affirmation—but with plenty of opportunities for flexing along the way.
wane into it drowse rock blending slowcore, ambient, and folk with lo-fi musings on memory and entropy, portland, oregon musician kyle bates joins a grand tradition of pacific northwestern gloom.

the hands of grace ishmael reed experimental now 84, the celebrated novelist, poet, and playwright presents his first collection of original songs. these sweetly earnest and stirringly beautiful pieces reflect a life immersed in jazz.

onwards! contour pop/r&b blending weighty subject matter and loose, meandering grooves, the charleston-based artist’s latest album moves like a raindrop down a windowpane—jagged, natural, and unpredictable.

saturno rauw alejandro pop/r&b, rap with an eclectic mosaic of sounds across 1980s and ’90s freestyle, miami bass, house, and old-school reggaeton, the puerto rican star’s new album delivers floor-fillers that actually try something different.
spirit roaming akai solo rap anchored by muted samples and soul-baring soliloquies, the new york rapper’s new album is an impressive, winding meditation on survival.
flipped it sarah mary chadwick folk/country intimate and unadorned, these five recordings from the melbourne-based artist sound like the dying embers of torch songs.

flaming swords fievel is glauque experimental, jazz multi-instrumentalist zach phillips and singer ma clément craft alluring jazz fusion songs in miniature. it is heady but not stuffy, precise but not rigid, dense but not cluttered.

isomonstrosity isomonstrosity experimental an innovative effort to produce a contemporary classical record in the piecemeal style of a rap mixtape ends up sounding both tasteful and weirdly frustrating.

black girl magic honey dijon electronic fresh off beyoncé’s co-sign, the house dj and producer returns with a joyous, collaboration-filled lp that channels the buzzy, late-night feeling when affection and tenderness flow freely.
feed tha streets iii roddy ricch rap still trying to capture the lightning of his star-making debut, the compton rapper’s latest is an attempted return to form that plays it far too safe.

back 2 life thaiboy digital rap on his first album in three years, the bangkok-based drain gang rapper taps into the group’s customary sentimentalism, but the rote lyrics and beats fail to convey much genuine emotion.
softcore fousheé pop/r&b on , the new jersey native mashes pop punk grit and airy r&b. it’s a commendable undertaking, but the execution is rough.
king’s disease iii nas rap the fourth album in nas’ ongoing series of collaborations with producer hit-boy locks into a straightforward groove. it’s loose and expert and finally nimble again.

vivid living colour rock each sunday, pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. today, we revisit a groundbreaking 1988 album, a crucial document in black rock music with huge, brawny riffs and a complex socio-political message.

almanac behind daniel bachman folk/country nature takes center stage on the experimental guitarist’s latest album—a response to climate crisis blending fractured melodies with recordings of severe weather and emergency broadcasts.

i don’t give a fuck about this rap shit, imma just drop until i don’t feel like it anymore $ilkmoney rap wordy, thoughtful rapping is thriving, but the virginia-born mc makes the style feel particularly urgent. neither his full-on delivery nor his absurdist sense of humor dilute his razor-sharp focus.

11•11•11 mgmt rock composed for the guggenheim museum’s retrospective of maurizio cattelan, this 2011 performance showcases a band torn between its impulse to entertain and its personal mission to challenge.
the family brockhampton rap the purported final album from the chart-topping hip-hop collective chronicles their rise and accelerated decline through the lens of a mercurial svengali.
