big time things office culture rock sleek but not too sleek for slap bass, the brooklyn quartet’s third album is a dispatch from the gray area between stoicism and comedy.
str4tasfear str4ta experimental, jazz on their second album together, london dj gilles peterson and brit-funk pioneer jean-paul “bluey” maunick pay tribute to an overlooked strain of uk dance music.

redcar les adorables étoiles (prologue) christine and the queens pop/r&b written almost entirely in french, the parisian artist’s quietly imaginative new album pursues a sonic and lyrical interiority that doesn’t always translate to great pop.

the roches the roches folk/country each sunday, pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. today, we revisit the cult-classic 1979 debut from the roche sisters, a playful, poignant, and slyly subversive folk masterpiece.

please have a seat nnamdï experimental, rap the chicago diy star is capable of presenting even the most technically difficult music as a casual, catchy pop song. his secretly canadian debut makes for an ideal introduction.

meeting with a judas tree duval timothy experimental the polymath brings his signature compositional style back to the piano for an expressive album that is intimate, immediate, and, for all its ambition, easy to connect to.

and in the darkness, hearts aglow weyes blood rock natalie mering’s majestic fifth record is a dispatch from the center of catastrophe—an idiosyncratic set of love songs and secular hymns with lushly orchestral arrangements.

maternity beat hedvig mollestad jazz accompanied by the 12-person trondheim jazz orchestra, the norwegian metal-jazz guitarist explores motherhood and mayhem on nine action-packed songs full of overdriven riffs and warring counterpoints.

cazimi caitlin rose the texas-born nashvillian previously proved herself a natural translator of honky-tonk’s emotional entanglements; on her long-delayed third record, she makes a complete song cycle out of them.
anyways, life’s great… glorilla rap with the song of the summer belt around her waist, the memphis rapper collects on the “f.n.f.” fame with a rowdy, promising debut ep.

on the impossible past (10th anniversary edition) the menzingers rock this 2012 lp, newly reissued, is the scranton punk band’s definitive album—the record that inaugurated a signature vernacular of doomed romance and self-loathing nostalgia.
the ruby cord richard dawson folk/country the latest from the ambitious british musician is a grim vision of the future: a crumbling, corroding monument that feels strangely devoid of a soul.
tempus pole electronic on his latest project, the german electronic musician blends piano, percussion, and dying equipment into his moody ambient-dub.
chimæra i colin stetson experimental in two long, bassy, zoned-out compositions, the genre-defying saxophonist strains against the formal restrictions of drone music.
an orange colored day arima ederra pop/r&b the los angeles songwriter balances autobiographical odes to love and loss with dreamlike imagery on her soft, hopeful debut.

what had happened was… dram rap the virginia crooner and sometime rapper is back with his old name and his new sensibilities—a re-re-introduction that solidifies his love for all things smooth and sappy.

we’re not here to be loved fleshwater rock, metal on the vein.fm side project’s full-length debut, these hardcore musicians melt down an entire cd binder’s worth of alt-rock classics and sculpt an alternate timeline out of the pliable remnants.

rtj cu4tro run the jewels rap killer mike and el-p’s collaborative free-for-all puts the spotlight on artists from the latin american diaspora. it’s an exciting lineup, but a little too inconsistent to work as an album.

scarecrow (deluxe edition) john mellencamp rock the deluxe reissue of the heartland songwriter’s 1985 album reinforces its stature as the platonic ideal of a traditional american rock’n’roll record: it is direct, unfussy, and unpretentious.

mk 3.5: die cuts | city planning mount kimbie electronic half woozy los angeles beats and half lo-fi techno, mount kimbie’s new double album doesn’t sound much like anything they’ve done before. it’s also some of their least original work.

hh5 ceo trayle rap with its macabre textures and sinister flows, the fifth installment of ceo trayle’s series unspools the rapper’s fears and sorrows into one of the most original rap albums of the year.
how the light felt smut rock carefully parsing the nuances of shoegaze, dream pop, and alt rock, the chicago quintet’s second album amounts to a rigorous study of 1990s guitar sounds.
song of salvation dream unending metal exploding death metal into atmospheric and experimental new dimensions, the dream-doom duo’s monuments to melancholy have never felt so crushing or beautiful.

nothing you do matters ganser rock the chicago quartet play nervy post-punk with a groundedness and poise that suggests if your back is up against the wall, you might be able to lean on it for support.
5 to the eye with stars r.a.p. ferreira rap ferreira’s newest album doesn’t stray from his core sound of jazzy boom bap, but his candid writing brings out the lucidity and urgency of his music.

they’re all gonna laugh at you! adam sandler rock each sunday, pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. today, we revisit a 1993 comedy album full of dick and fart jokes, and the brilliant, self-effacing man who made them work.

mondays at the enfield tennis academy jeff parker jazz recorded across a few intimate evenings at a cozy l.a. cocktail bar, these four side-long tracks of bass, drums, sax, and guitar dissolve revelatory improvisation into mesmerizing ambient atmospheres.
myself in the way turnover rock a patchwork of lethargic guitar riffs, dying-bulb synth glow, and generic disco beats, the virginia band’s newest album feels strangely emotionally detached.
clan way 3 bluebucksclan rap on the third edition of the los angeles duo brings back the laugh-out-loud antics. it’s breezy and fun, bolstered by the pair’s flawless chemistry.

only the strong survive bruce springsteen rock bruce brings heaps of feeling to a new set of some of his favorite, largely obscure soul songs, giving them a confident, faithful, and occasionally synthetic sound.
club godfather bandmanrill rap the first album from the breakout star of new jersey club rap isn’t quite the revelation its title suggests, but his breakneck sound remains intoxicating.
amateurs laura jean pop/r&b the australian songwriter’s intermittently funny and mournful folk-pop confronts the improbable task of commercial success and decides that art is worth making anyway.
hayday feeble little horse rock the pittsburgh rock quartet’s newly reissued debut is a relentless, intentionally chaotic document of twentysomething existential dread.
alpha zulu phoenix rock the french indie rock stalwarts’ fun and fizzy seventh album rejuvenates a proven formula while protecting its true feelings behind glass.
animal drowning knifeplay rock with a mixture of shoegaze and dream pop, the philadelphia band offers a dramatic soundtrack to dark introspection.

a swollen river, a well overflowing tenci folk/country, rock the second album from the chicago singer-songwriter jess shoman brings in the band for a noise-country-ish sound that both spotlights and strengthens their vocals.

black panther: wakanda forever - music from and inspired by various artists the soundtrack from the new marvel blockbuster has a staggering sonic diversity, but the absence of a curator is felt in how loosely songs are tied to the movie.

comradely objects horse lords experimental on the group’s fourth album, carefully controlled minimalism gives way to a playful expressionistic streak, suggesting a utopian balance between social harmony and personal freedom.

pigments dawn richard pop/r&b, rock setting dawn richard’s agile voice against spencer zahn’s lush chamber arrangements, the two musicians push each other into an atmospheric zone that’s new for both.

through a room bill nace experimental on his second solo album for drag city, the philadelphia guitarist continues to develop his singular style, incorporating tape loops, taishōgoto, and hurdy-gurdy into his sculptural approach.

endure special interest rock on their remarkable third album, the new orleans band pushes their sound to both its bleakest and its sweetest brinks. pop, disco, and house all melt into their raucous, revolutionary glam punk.

protector aoife nessa frances folk/country inspired by the rugged yet serene beauty of ireland’s west coast, the singer-songwriter’s tranquil psych-folk explores communion with nature, family, and ourselves.

is it going to get any deeper than this? the soft pink truth electronic matmos’ drew daniel extends the collaborative thrust of his solo project, imbuing dynamic, shape-shifting disco and deep-house tracks with a warm sense of community.

perspective molly joyce experimental layering spoken interviews about the experience of disability with pulsing minimalist fugues, is a powerful work of love and empathy that underscores the poison of ableism in american culture.
sexy coco & clair clair pop/r&b with a playful mood and a wide range of collaborators, the debut full-length from the outlandish pop duo subverts trends with ease.
memphis massacre iii duke deuce rap the rapper’s hard-knocking horrorcore is classic memphis trunk music, and only other artists from the 901 are invited along for the ride.

her loss drake rap the album-length collaboration between the pop star of the north and the rap star of the south seems like a good match, but it turns into a drastically uneven project in almost every way.

back home big joanie rock on the uk trio’s first lp for kill rock stars, the band fleshes out its riot-grrrl-meets-girl-group sound with electronics and strings while singing of strength and vulnerability.

fashion nugget cake rock each sunday, pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. today, we revisit cake’s second album, a wry, earnest, and oft-misunderstood outlier of ’90s alt-rock.

( ) 20th anniversary edition sigur rós rock the icelandic group celebrates the 20th anniversary of its third album with an expanded edition. sung entirely in the made-up language of hopelandic, it sounds as sumptuous and suggestive as ever.
air guitar sobs pop/r&b the singaporean indie pop trio’s second album sparkles, but under all the glitter, there are somber truths about love’s uncertainties.

sap okay kaya pop/r&b on her third album, kaya wilkins’ arrangements have finally caught up with her free-roaming mind; the music has gathered weight and mass, bringing her distinctive insights into focus.
bluenothing ep worm metal drawing inspiration from symphonic black metal, the enigmatic band’s new mini-album is a gothic dreamworld where virtuosic shredding rules above all.
reason in decline archers of loaf rock on their first studio album in 24 years, the long-reunited southern indie rockers make mighty, angry songs better suited for now than then.

hadja bangoura hawa pop/r&b, rap on her debut album, the brooklyn-based producer and singer smartly and subtly remakes her sound, meshing r&b and new york drill in melodically refined and technically daring ways.
outofbody dazy rock the richmond-based artist collides big riffs, sweet melodies, and thick fuzz into crisp, cathartic songs about life’s uncertainties.
ilysm wild pink rock john ross leads his band through a richly detailed and expectedly sentimental album that wrestles with all the life and death that exists in the midst of a cancer diagnosis.
svengali cakes da killa rap the new york rapper is known for his breathless flows and punchy hip-house beats. his second album is just as slick, but this time there’s a little tenderness.

astral fortress darkthrone metal the apparent effortlessness (and occasional silliness) of the metal band’s 20th album could make it feel tossed off, but the duo’s enthusiasm mostly prevents that from happening.
light moving time babehoven rock the full-length debut from the new york folk-rock duo addresses the nonlinear nature of healing with a gentle and deliberate touch.

cold cuts wiki rap where 2021’s was a farewell to the manhattan of wiki’s youth, the follow-up lacks that record’s deliberate agenda, channeling its freewheeling energy into a free-associative writing style.
luv 4 rent smino rap the rapper’s third album is an invitation into his domestic sphere in all of its messiness, controversies, and communal joy.
crybaby tegan and sara rock the duo’s latest album reaches back into their past but gets stuck in a strange middle ground between big-budget indie and low-budget pop.

wyld love songs david john morris folk/country both playful and spare, the second solo lp from the red river dialect songwriter and ordained buddhist chaplain finds warmth and comfort in scenes of decay.
cyclorama ariel zetina electronic on her debut album, the rising chicago dj spins thrilling, multifaceted club music into a celebration of her belizean heritage and trans identity.

actual life 3 (january 1 - september 9 2022) fred again.. pop/r&b, rap, electronic on his third album in 18 months, the uk hitmaker applies a scrapbooker’s instincts to festival-ready house anthems. but despite the diaristic hints, we learn little about the artist.

akọle ep loshh electronic the nigerian-born artist collages highlife, afrobeats, and electronics into his bravely experimental second ep. while the medley is audacious and impressive, it sometimes feels unfinished.

waiting game junior boys electronic, rock the canadian duo cuts out drums and vocals from long stretches of their first album in six years. that it feels of a piece with their past work is a testament to the solid foundation of their music.

snow flakes 2022 elite gymnastics electronic after a decade-long pause, jaime brooks revives her elite gymnastics project. the record feels like an elegy for a time when the internet provided refuge for misfit kids seeking out like-minded souls.

human futures dear nora rock on the follow-up to 2018’s , the portland group delivers pointed late-capitalist critiques, using coarser melodies and more vivid lyrics to express gnawing existential anxiety.

dj-kicks: theo parrish theo parrish electronic on a landmark mix album, the detroit icon gathers together multiple generations of the city’s dance-music faithful in a celebration of history, community, and possibility.
nacarile ile pop/r&b adopting an oblique, exploratory approach to bolero, hip-hop, and synth pop, the puerto rican artist’s third studio album meditates candidly on political and personal endurance.

trouble the water show me the body rock on an adventurous new album, the new york hardcore band populates a swamp of chugs with weird creatures of electronica and sudden clearings of melodic, galloping punk.

noon twain experimental, folk/country the songwriter and multi-instrumentalist who’s collaborated with big thief, the deslondes, and the low anthem returns with a sparse, earnest collection that occasionally overstates its message.
dirt femme tove lo pop/r&b on her first independent release, the pop star pivots to tamer themes and gives more lethargic performances, losing a lot of her spark in the process.
cometa nick hakim rock the brooklyn-based crooner’s abundant talent vanishes behind hazy production and indistinct writing.

from a story now lost anja lauvdal jazz on her solo debut, the norwegian electronic musician uses synthesizer and piano to sketch suggestively abstracted scenes veiled in fog. the songs can feel like they’re transcribed from a forgotten language.
paste moin rock the trio of drummer valentina magaletti and raime’s joe andrews and tom halstead subtly reinvent post-hardcore by plundering the past and making familiar tropes sound fresh again.

stumpwork dry cleaning rock the london quartet moves beyond the sardonic post-punk of its debut, exploring new sounds and moods while florence shaw reveals hitherto unheard subtleties in her famously low-key delivery.
se ve desde aquí mabe fratti experimental on her new album, the guatemalan cellist trades her lush, verdant style for moments of austere beauty. she feels more intuitive and confident than ever.
guitar music courting rock the liverpool band’s debut looks at rock music and quotidian life through their own bizarre, distorted pop lens.

bolts hagop tchaparian electronic assembled from years of recordings made on the road, the armenian british producer’s debut lp for four tet’s text label flips traditional instruments and captured moments into dancefloor thrills.
paraglow ep 파란노을 (parannoul) rock a new joint release from the seoul artists feels like a true collaboration, fusing their distinct styles with shoegaze production and alt-rock guitars.

building something beautiful for me loraine james electronic as part of an ongoing reassessment of pioneering composer julius eastman’s work, the london electronic musician presents originals loosely inspired by signature pieces like “stay on it” and “femenine.”

streetlands burial electronic, experimental continuing in the vein of january’s ep, burial’s latest three-tracker dispenses with the drums entirely, instead exploring an ambient expanse of choir and strings.
the liz 2 armani caesar rap sounding effortlessly in command of her money and her sexuality, the griselda rapper’s new album oozes seductive pleasure.

dig me in: a dig me out covers album sleater-kinney rock st. vincent, low, courtney barnett, the linda lindas and more highlight the enduring influence of sleater-kinney on this track-by-track tribute to the band’s breakthrough 1997 album.
malign hex meat wave rock the chicago band’s new album balances punk aggression and sisyphean striving, so wide and claustrophobic that it leaves you disoriented.
steady sloan rock on their 13th album, the canadian indie lifers play to their strengths with classic rock worship and power-pop hooks.
midnights taylor swift pop/r&b more interested in setting atmosphere than chasing trends, taylor swift’s 10th album pursues a newly subdued and amorphous pop sound.

up the bracket (20th anniversary edition) the libertines rock the london band’s thrillingly seedy 2002 debut receives a reissue, accompanied by a stack of demos and studio outtakes that illuminate its sprawling, chaotic romance.
the car arctic monkeys rock the english band returns with an adventurous, heavily orchestrated album filled with enigmatic songs of love, longing, and doubt.
amor hardcore isabella lovestory pop/r&b playful, maximalist, and flirtatious to the core, isabella lovestory’s debut album is a defiant celebration of sexual agency.

non-stop erotic cabaret soft cell electronic, rock each sunday, pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. today, we revisit the english duo’s 1981 debut, a daring landmark of synth pop that went unexpectedly mainstream.

all blue julianna riolino rock, pop/r&b, folk/country the toronto singer-songwriter channels cosmic country on her debut album. recorded live in the studio, it’s a promising showcase of both her nimble voice and her band’s dynamic playing.
inner world peace frankie cosmos rock with loose, psych-pop grooves and empathetic lyrics about growing up, greta kline and her band enter a phase of tenured inquisitiveness.
laughing so hard, it hurts mavi rap intimate by design but expansive in scope, the rapper’s latest project is an inventive and unnerving evolution of his singular style.
playgirl lolo zouaï pop/r&b the pop artist’s second record is a bold attempt at lightening up her sound, featuring a cyber-future narrative and three distinct personas.
gris klein birds in row rock the french trio’s third album trends towards accessibility without losing its taste for the visceral pleasures of more technical post-hardcore.

the loneliest time carly rae jepsen pop/r&b more interested in earmarking ideas than in formulating an overarching aesthetic proposition, carly rae jepsen’s fifth album diversifies her portfolio of 1980s pop sounds.

only built for infinity links quavo rap the migos members’ new collaboration is longer than it needs to be, but quavo and takeoff can make most scenarios sound exciting, whether life-changing or mundane.

i walked with you a ways plains folk/country katie crutchfield and jess williamson’s debut as plains sends it back to the ’90s with a thoughtful, personalized interpretation of old-school country-pop.

quiet the room skullcrusher folk/country blending misty ambience with introspective folk songwriting, the los angeles artist’s full-length debut is less about specifics than the way it all smears together.

return of the dream canteen red hot chili peppers rock the funk-rock band’s second album of the year is a surprisingly introspective set filled with references to forgotten actors, classic bands, and, most tellingly, decades-old chili peppers songs.
momentary presence gift rock drawing on several decades of psychedelic music, the debut album from the brooklyn project grapples with introspective feelings through expansive, transportive sounds.
yti⅃aǝя bill callahan rock on his third solo album in as many years, the wise and stoic singer-writer extolls the virtues of the sacred and the mundane.
church billy woods rap the rapper’s second album of 2022 is a dark memoir about love, memory, and faith. with a meticulous but loose style, it amplifies his capacity for vulnerability.

nothing special will sheff rock the okkervil river frontman has long taken a sledgehammer to the fourth wall; on his self-aware solo debut, he takes stock of the troubled state of the industry and delivers a eulogy for his band.

it’s only me lil baby rap the atlanta rapper sounds comfortable, uninspired, and indifferent on his latest album. it’s a missed opportunity to flaunt his talent for vocal manipulation and emotional delivery.
now is rival consoles electronic the london electronic musician’s painterly, atmospheric production style yields deftly layered headphone music adorned with occasional dancefloor flourishes.

foreverandevernomore brian eno electronic confronting the climate crisis and the prospect of humankind’s demise, the veteran experimental musician takes an unconventional approach: he gets in touch with his feelings.

live in cuxhaven 1976 can experimental the third installment in an ongoing series of live recordings contains some of the krautrock titans’ most unbridled moments yet, but the whittled-down highlights preclude any sense of flow.
<copingmechanism> willow rock the gen z philosopher’s hard-rock era continues with an album about love and hurt, pain and healing, done with great nuance but not quite enough originality.

being funny in a foreign language the 1975 rock matty healy taps jack antonoff to help produce a concise, meaningful, pop-focused album about love. it’s cliché, it’s obvious, it’s slyly profound—it’s the 1975.
blueblue sam gendel jazz on a softly melancholic new album, the los angeles musician offers a concentration of his strengths in service of one sharpened, sustained mood.
ruffs kenny mason rap in kenny mason’s world, puppies are royalty and contemporary southern rap and rock go hand-in-hand.

¡ay! lucrecia dalt experimental the colombian musician sketches a sci-fi vision of bolero, son, and other classic genres she grew up with. it’s philosophically daring, technically ambitious, and a joy to experience.

loose future courtney marie andrews folk/country the grammy-nominated singer-songwriter teams up with producer sam evian for an assured, exploratory, and warm record that mirrors a newly opened heart.

rolling golden holy bonny light horseman rock, folk/country on their second album as a trio, anaïs mitchell, eric d. johnson, and josh kaufman build fresh narratives from the fabled history of folk music.

en är för mycket och tusen aldrig nog dungen rock the swedish psych-rock pioneers’ songs are usually like odysseys, but their first full-length studio album in seven years is more of a pleasure cruise.

the velvet rope (deluxe edition) janet jackson pop/r&b after three blockbuster albums, the megastar turned introspective, plumbing the depths of depression. considered a disappointment at the time, it’s become one of her most beloved lps.

reinventing axl rose against me! rock each sunday, pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. today, we revisit laura jane grace’s 2002 folk-punk salvo, an album that yearns for an escape from and through rock’n’roll.

grow your hair long if you​’​re wanting to see something that you can change field medic folk/country singer-songwriter kevin patrick sullivan exchanges straight-to-tape simplicity for full-band arrangements, bringing a warm americana glow to bedroom ballads full of sadness and yearning.

3800 degrees youngboy never broke again rap on his fourth solo album of the year, the louisiana rapper wears his regional roots with brash defiance. it’s a reminder of how thrilling he can be when he’s focused and cohesive.

nicks and grazes palm rock on its third album, the philadelphia quartet hones the studio techniques—as well as the knowledge of when to hold back—required to do justice to the group’s adventurous spirit.

living sky sun ra arkestra jazz a veteran of sun ra’s band of astral travelers, saxophonist and bandleader marshall allen carries on the jazz legend’s legacy of uplifting spirits and upending musical expectations.

cherry daphni electronic dan snaith’s joyous new album as daphni lets its first-thought-best-thought spirit shine. bar for bar, this might be the most fun there is to be had on a dance record this year.

component system with the auto reverse open mike eagle rap the rapper’s eighth solo album is a stroll down memory lane, summoning the ’90s boom bap aesthetics he grew up on. it’s a nostalgic trip that further cements his witty, introspective, and singular style.
desperately imagining someplace quiet disq rock the madison, wisconsin band’s second album melds 1960s pop melodies and ’90s indie rock distortion into feel-good tunes rich in existential angst.

most normal gilla band rock the irish band’s unrelenting third album, made with an arcade of pedals and processors, surges with electricity. inside all of its noise is an indignant, surreal mania that gives it a twisted pop soul.

languoria sofie birch experimental composer sofie birch’s lush ambient creations and experimental singer antonina nowacka’s indelible vocal melodies meet on a record that ebbs and flows as naturally as breathing.

capricorn sun tsha pop/r&b, electronic the uk producer casually throws house, uk garage, r&b, pop, and breakbeats into varied songs that are as emotionally relatable as they are instinctively danceable.
doubles basher jazz having added a second drummer and a synth player since its 2018 debut, new orleans’ self-described “free-jazz party band” vacillates between abandon and unease.

i will not use the body’s eyes today. fire-toolz experimental on an independently released 30-minute ep, angel marcloid slightly recalibrates her uber-maximalist sound to be both lighter and heavier at its extreme poles.

bobby weir & wolf bros: live in colorado, vol. 2 bob weir rock on a striking live set, the grateful dead rhythm guitarist and vocalist stages some of the band’s most beloved material with passion and reverence.
blue rev alvvays rock the toronto band’s third album is a triumph of power pop, a densely layered, witty, blithe, and beautiful record that sets a new benchmark for the genre.

orange 2 macula dog jazz, experimental the second album from the enigmatic duo is equally nauseating and joyous, like binging on several decades of euphoric pop and hurling it onto the floor of a tilt-a-whirl.
anywhere but here sorry rock on its second album, the london band folds classic pop tropes into its songwriting—just the latest surprise from a group that has always kept listeners on their toes.
kiss the ring rome streetz rap the new york city rapper heads upstate for a steely westside gunn production with all the hallmarks of a griselda blockbuster.

world spirituality classics 3: the muslim highlife of alhaji waziri oshomah alhaji waziri oshomah pop/r&b the third volume in luaka bop’s world spirituality classics series spotlights a nigerian musician who fuses traditional rhythms and pan-nigerian highlife with the teachings of islam.
pocket fantasy mamalarky rock on its second album, the indie rock quartet balances complicated arrangements with playful moments of levity.

enter the wu-tang (36 chambers) wu-tang clan rap today on pitchfork, we are celebrating the messy, game-changing, era-defining genius of the wu-tang clan with five new reviews: two albums, two solo projects, and a film score.

nymph shygirl electronic sensuous, funny, and smartly produced, the london artist’s full-length debut transforms dusky electronic beats and trending pop sounds into a singular celebration of sexual agency.

ghost dog: the way of the samurai rza rap today on pitchfork, we are celebrating the messy, game-changing, era-defining genius of the wu-tang clan with five new reviews: two albums, two solo projects, and a film score.
let’s have a dream (1974 one step festival) yoko ono experimental, rock released for the first time, a recording of the opening night of ono’s 1974 japanese tour captures her at her mischievous peak.
doggerel pixies rock on the fourth album from their reunited lineup, the alt-rock lifers choose to embrace the slowing of their step.

ironman ghostface killah rap today on pitchfork, we are celebrating the messy, game-changing, era-defining genius of the wu-tang clan with five new reviews: two albums, two solo projects, and a film score.
at scaramouche joseph shabason jazz, rock on their second collaborative album, the toronto saxophonist and vancouver singer find common ground in the beauty of mundane moments and minuscule gestures.

wu-tang forever wu-tang clan rap today on pitchfork, we are celebrating the messy, game-changing, era-defining genius of the wu-tang clan with five new reviews: two albums, two solo projects, and a film score.

shebang oren ambarchi experimental the experimental guitarist’s latest piece thrives on tension—between pulse and drone, repetition and variance, and, particularly, between the naturalism of the musicians’ playing and the artifice of the mix.
tical method man rap today on pitchfork, we are celebrating the messy, game-changing, era-defining genius of the wu-tang clan with five new reviews: two albums, two solo projects, and a film score.

solar bridge emeralds electronic newly reissued by ghostly, this 2008 release from the influential experimental trio represents the zenith of their early drone excursions, and hints at the more meticulous compositions that were to come.

spiderr bladee rap, pop/r&b with celestial synth arrangements and heavy-lidded streams of consciousness, bladee’s newest album offers a vision of pop that’s grounded in real emotion but shrouded in otherworldly mystery.

dreamkiller sumerlands metal producer arthur rizk’s band plays heavy metal in the traditional sense: catchy, operatic choruses and chugging riffs that you only need to hear once before you can air-guitar along.
hysteria indigo sparke folk/country the australian folk artist’s second album is glossier and broader than its predecessor, but the most stunning moments are still ones of hushed reverence.

$oul $old $eparately freddie gibbs rap inviting producers like kaytranada, james blake, and dj paul into the fold offers a refreshing canvas for a rapper whose technical prowess and stark songwriting deserve a varied landscape to thrive in.

the will to live titus andronicus rock the new jersey band’s seventh album is a hero’s journey powered by indomitable lifeforce and spirited, classic rock-inspired songwriting. it’s a rollicking good time and their best record in years.

entergalactic kid cudi rap, rock released in conjunction with an animated netflix film, kid cudi’s latest is a pleasant surprise—a minor project that features some of his most purely enjoyable music in a decade.
makes me sick makes me smile pretty sick rock sabrina fuentes’ debut album offers a flashback of adolescence in new york, filtering teenage themes through a studied imitation of ’90s grunge.
fossora björk electronic, pop/r&b with her 10th album, björk is grounded back on earth, searching for hope in death, mushrooms, and matriarchy, and finding it in bass clarinet and gabber beats.

the sun still seems to move shannen moser folk/country accompanied by cello, lap steel, and other acoustic instruments, the philadelphia singer-songwriter creates abstract soundscapes that envelop even their loneliest songs in a soft, expansive warmth.
i got issues yg rap the veteran west coast rapper toggles between kickback anthems and pertinent reflections on his life and growth, but he’s missing the hunger and innovation of his best work.

diner coffee mamaleek metal, rock, experimental on an eerie new record, the anonymous collective strays from its metal roots and takes influence from jazz, telling stories of life on america’s class margins.
i never felt nun est gee rap on his latest album, the kentucky rapper addresses his demons head-on with startling bluntness and raw desperation.
functional designs deepchord electronic on his first album as deepchord in four years, rod modell continues to refine his bustling, urban, singular take on dub techno.
older (super deluxe) george michael pop/r&b arriving at a moment when his worldwide stardom was in eclipse, this 1996 album was the most daringly personal statement of george michael’s career.

the charm of the highway strip the magnetic fields rock each sunday, pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. today, we revisit stephin merrit’s 1994 meta-country album, an idiosyncratic, lo-fi travelogue bursting with gothic wit and pathos.

weather alive beth orton rock the eighth album from the english songwriter is the best work of her career. soothing, immersive, and self-produced, it conjures a dreamlike atmosphere with songs that spiral out into the ether.
the hum goes on forever the wonder years rock the pop-punk band ages gracefully on a heart-achingly earnest record about parenthood.

cool it down yeah yeah yeahs rock the trio’s first album in nine years ushers in a patient new era for the band, gracefully shedding the electrifying hunger of its early days to make room for tempered joy.

paradise of replica after dinner experimental the japanese avant-garde pop band strove to create a “sacred ambiance” on their second album, fusing unconventional arrangements with bouncing volleyballs and an eyes-wide air of wonder.
morbidity triumphant autopsy metal energized by the presence of a new bassist, the death metal pioneers still stand apart from the pack.

evergreen caroline shaw experimental the new york-based composer’s newest project with the attacca quartet highlights the significance of language while exploring the narrative potential of contemporary classical music.

running in waves george riley pop/r&b over flickering jungle breaks and gentle electronic soul, the london singer-songwriter who broke through with anz’s ebullient “you could be” turns her focus inward.
in these times makaya mccraven jazz the hybrid jazz drummer and producer’s latest album uses his familiar post-production techniques but feels more deftly orchestrated and rhythmically complex.

tyrannical vibes kolb experimental, rock the new york singer-songwriter infuses aesthetics of indie pop with the rigor of his opera training. sung by a small crew of friends, his cryptic lyrics feel like a snapshot of his social circle.
still, here marisa anderson folk/country on an alternately deliberate and exploratory new record, the guitarist and composer finds flashes of beauty at the heart of each instrumental tale.
the bible lambchop rock the latest from kurt wagner’s shapeshifting group is its darkest yet: a haunting ode to everyday american pain and the small ways we make it through.

est. 2003 dj q electronic now two decades into his career, the huddersfield native balances the brashness of bassline house with the swing of 2-step, demonstrating his own quiet mastery of uk garage’s many strands.
exister the soft moon rock sharper songwriting, unbridled vocal performances, and more austere industrial textures give luis vasquez’s fifth album a new level of depth and candor.
u wasn’t there cam’ron rap, electronic the harlem veteran’s long-promised collaboration with producer a-trak is a laid-back shot of charisma.
legendary anti da menace rap on his newest mixtape, the young atlanta rapper succeeds at sounding like a vague, one-note nba youngboy and very little else.
blending high vis rock the london quintet’s second album takes a softer approach to britpop-infused post-punk and a more emotional perspective on working-class consciousness.
languish arts ka rap
last spa on earth divino niño rock the chicago-based band sheds its psychedelic garage-pop for intrepid experiments in reggaeton, synth-pop, and club music.
denim & diamonds nikki lane folk/country, rock frank, honest, and irreverent, the songwriter’s fourth album attempts to subvert the should-bes of a woman making a country record.
moss maya hawke folk/country the minimalist acoustic palette of the 24-year-old actor and singer’s second album makes a calming backdrop for her diaristic songwriting and white-smoke soprano.

music for animals nils frahm electronic trading his customary piano for a mostly electronic palette, the berlin composer conjures an air of stillness and solitude. the results are both meditative and, at three hours long, sprawling.
yankee hotel foxtrot (super deluxe edition) wilco rock a sprawling new box set full of demos and alternate takes suggests a dazzling array of paths the chicago group have taken on their masterpiece.

skindiver nona hendryx pop/r&b each sunday, pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. today, we revisit a buried treasure, the 1989 experimental new age solo album from the r&b legend, a black queer epic where technology mediates tenderness.
harlequin sofie royer rock, pop/r&b the vienna-based singer and musician’s second album turns to high-concept cabaret pop, exuding a cool melancholy that complements its textured production.

god save the animals alex g rock placing its faith in the healing power of animals and auto-tune, alex giannascoli’s most hopeful record stands out for its grounded patience and moments of sharp lyrical simplicity.

shepherd head young jesus rock following the dissolution of the group’s lineup, founding member john rossiter plays alone for the first time, working up an intimate set of songs using just mic, laptop, and field recordings.

the mars volta the mars volta rock on the duo’s first album in 10 years, omar rodríguez-lópez and cedric bixler-zavala mellow out, abandoning their unhinged prog opuses for a kind of airy, caribbean yacht rock.
darklife death’s dynamic shroud electronic on a new double album, the experimental collective continues its journey from vaporwave toward fractured, maximalist pop music.
decide djo rock on his second solo album, actor joe keery fights his way through the simulation with winking, off-kilter synth-pop.
demon time mura masa electronic the london producer loosens the reins for a guest-heavy, party-starting album that doesn’t feel pressured to do or say too much
spark whitney rock the chicago duo’s inert new album has a gorgeous sound, but it comes at the cost of depth and spontaneity.

girl of my dreams fletcher pop/r&b, rock on her debut album, fletcher aims to champion vulnerability in queer love. instead, she delivers generic, one-dimensional pop anthems that never fully articulate her experience of love and heartbreak.

asphalt meadows death cab for cutie rock at last, the band’s 10th album restores their creative momentum. if the songs don’t feel as lived-in, at least they unlock the repressed memory of what it was like to be deeply moved by death cab for cutie.
the trouble with fever michelle branch pop/r&b the musical output of michelle branch and patrick carney’s embattled partnership suffers from muddled songwriting and meandering arrangements.

that’s what happened 1982-1985: the bootleg series vol. 7 miles davis jazz a new three-disc set surveys the trumpeter’s most critically reviled era. the unreleased studio material is a mixed bag, but a 1983 live recording is revelatory.

♡ ep ela minus electronic pairing the colombian singer’s voice with the new york producer’s wistful electronic hybrids, this brief but endearing ep feels like a set of missives sent from the depths of a daydream.
heaven is no fun sick thoughts the new orleans-based punk artist crafts broad caricatures of chaos and destruction with giddy hooks, flashy musicianship, and self-mythologizing humor.

beauty is useless james devane electronic, experimental pairing undulating synthesizers with cycling grooves, the bay area electronic musician’s first album in 14 years calls back to the ambient techno of the late 1990s.
born pink blackpink pop/r&b the k-pop quartet’s highly anticipated second album leans into an image of authority that’s undercut by familiar ideas and stale musical concepts.

when the wind forgets your name built to spill rock dotted with cool surprises and intricately plotted melodies, the veteran indie band’s sub pop debut shakes things up without breaking their pattern of low-key, late-period releases.
mosquito lyzza electronic the brazilian-born, amsterdam-based producer’s new mixtape presents shapeshifting, pop-minded club tracks that showcase her dense production and versatile singing.
(self-titled) marcus mumford folk/country with production from blake mills, the mumford & sons frontman goes solo with a hushed, searching record anchored in trauma.
lyfë yeat rap rage rap can be rote and exhausting, but in small doses—like on the portland rapper’s new pared-down and hypnotic album—the style can be ridiculous fun, electrifying, and hyperreal.
hydration tenka experimental the japanese ambient artist’s new album is an immersive textural exercise that demands full use of the senses. it is some of his most magnetic work yet.
age/sex/location ari lennox pop/r&b grown, sexy, and horny on main, the dreamville singer’s second album pursues pleasure without compromising on self-love.
butcher brown presents triple trey butcher brown jazz the collective’s new album is their most focused yet, possessing the soul of a beat tape and the larger-than-life feel of big band jazz.
legend john legend pop/r&b on an 81-minute double album, the egot singer-songwriter enlists an impressive roster of guests to help bring more fun—and funk—to his music than he has in years.

hold the girl rina sawayama pop/r&b seeking empathy for a younger self, rina sawayama’s second album pirouettes through pop-punk and power ballads, trance and stadium rock. it’s ambitious in the same way as putting on all the clothes in your closet.

demons protected by angels nav rap the canadian rapper’s latest album finds moments of real depth and humanity. the rest of the time, his verses register as monotonous and tame, his energy dictated by a-list collaborators.
people helping people no age rock the la duo’s sixth album is notably abstract and eccentric, showcasing a renewed sense of possibility.

words & music, may 1965 lou reed rock featuring the earliest known renditions of several velvet underground classics, this archival set of acoustic demos highlights a formative period in lou reed and john cale’s artistic partnership.

expert in a dying field the beths rock the third album from the new zealand quartet blends openhearted lyrics about post-breakup regret with a sugar-rush immediacy and a craftsman-like attention to detail.

arrangements preoccupations rock grim, grey, and dour, the canadian band’s fourth album offers a bleak look at the world and delivers some new textures but lacks some of the musical tension to really create sparks.

houdini melvins metal, rock each sunday, pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. today, we revisit the major-label debut from the sludge-metal pioneers, an album that marked their transition from rockers to experimentalists.
dimensional bleed holy fawn rock, metal with a slightly subtler approach, the post-metal band relies on familiar tricks, gesturing at widescreen emotions in an endless sea of sine wave swells.

invisibility is an unnatural disaster sswan experimental, jazz the jazz supergroup of free-improvising heavyweights—patrick shiroishi, jessica ackerley, chris williams, luke stewart, and jason nazary—veers between frenetic roar and microscopic textures.

natural brown prom queen sudan archives pop/r&b with daring lyricism and technical ingenuity, singer-songwriter and multi-instrumentalist brittney parks’ second album conjures a frenzied energy as emotionally soothing as it is physically crushing.

as above, so below sampa the great rap the rapper continues to explore identity and belonging on her second album. recorded in her native zambia, it folds together zamrock, polyrhythmic percussion, and choral harmonies.

step on step charles stepney pop/r&b famous for his widescreen imagination, the legendary r&b producer and arranger helped define chicago soul. this anthology of home recordings uncovered by his daughters reveals his more intimate side.

nothing’s shocking jane’s addiction rock each sunday, pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. today, we revisit the los angeles band’s 1988 debut, which infused the nascent alt-rock movement with a surreal vision of hollywood hedonism.
hideous bastard oliver sim rock the solo debut from the xx vocalist is a quiet work of personal exploration. rife with growing pains, it occasionally hints at real beauty.

krökta tankar och brända vanor amateur hour rock, electronic gothenburg trio amateur hour translate their hometown’s diy ethos into an hour-long dream-pop epic, balancing lo-fi scuzz with welcoming intimacy.

andrew mcintosh: little jimmy yarn/wire experimental the piano-and-percussion quartet performs a series of pieces by the los angeles composer that wrestle with the aftermath of 2020’s wildfires; mcintosh’s own field recordings flesh out a sense of place.

jingul ustad noor bakhsh folk/country a revered musician in balochistan, pakistan, ustad noor bahksh debuts internationally with a twangy, enveloping collection of reinterpreted and original compositions for the benju.
2007 miya folick rock the los angeles-based pop singer's new ep plunges into her psyche with quiet desperation, producing some of her most vulnerable music yet.
spirituals santigold pop/r&b on her first album in six years, santigold reimagines the type of music that can comfort people in times of grief and stagnation.

god did dj khaled rap dj khaled is a savvy curator; too often, that’s all he is. his latest collection of star-studded rap party bangers offers the rare opportunity to isolate what, exactly, he adds to a track.

louie kenny beats rap an in-demand beatmaker who has worked with denzel curry, vince staples, and more, the producer finally releases his solo debut—a dynamic record bursting with soul samples and complicated emotions.

diagonals born under a rhyming planet electronic, rock nineties heads know chicago’s jamie hodge for his leftfield productions on plus 8 and source. sifting through his old dats, demdike stare came up with a grip of vintage ambient-techno abstractions.
yungblud yungblud rock the english singer’s third album promises eccentricity and personal revelation but delivers anonymous, uninspired pop-rock.
good movie pi’erre bourne rap on his third solo album, the new york producer finally proves he’s a proficient rapper, but his audacious beats take a backseat in the process.

white girl wasted sonnyjim rap with appearances from mf doom, jay electronica, madlib, and dj premier, the full-length collaborative debut from the rapper and producer is a nostalgic ode to druggy hedonism and classic boom-bap.

black vladimir meyhem lauren rap buffalo producer daringer’s austere music spotlights meyhem lauren’s phonetic idiosyncrasies. for the first time in years, the queens rapper is an unequivocal headliner.

my boy marlon williams folk/country with actorly affect and an orbinsonesque croon, the new zealand singer-songwriter uses the bright, artificial gloss of 1980s pop to evoke an uncanny, self-protective brand of masculinity.

two sisters sarah davachi electronic on her new album, the canadian artist collages 18th-century pipe organs and cavernous drone music. it is a dark encounter between the past and present, revealing the full range of her gifts as a composer.

how do you burn? the afghan whigs rock greg dulli and co. return with an eclectic, haunted set that feels untethered to their past work. they seem less interested in living up to expectations than upending them.

i love you jennifer b jockstrap electronic, experimental, pop/r&b the full-length debut from the shapeshifting uk duo is a virtuosic display of theatrical mayhem, dazzling production, and surprisingly lustrous pop music.
sides lean year rock the virginia duo’s sparse, meditative indie folk songs grapple with the impermanence of life and the disorientation of grief, evoking an aching stillness.
clouds of joy badge époque ensemble jazz enthusiastic, meticulous, and decidedly analog, is am radio music for a late-’70s moment that may only exist in bandleader max turnbull’s imagination.
keep on smiling two door cinema club rock efficient and impersonal, the rock band’s latest album is filled with sunny-side platitudes and peppy tempos that scan as forced fun.
someday is today living hour rock the canadian band’s third album is a wistful and familiar soundtrack to winter malaise.

pulse of the early brain (switched on, vol. 5) stereolab experimental the avant-pop group offers a comprehensive if inessential career overview on what may be the final edition of its long-running compilation series.

whipped stream and other earthly delights moth cock electronic, experimental, jazz indulgent, arcane, and often hilarious, the ohio noise-jazz improvisers’ new three-and-a-half-hour cassette collection is too weird to be boring.

heaven come crashing rachika nayar experimental the brooklyn composer injects the ambient wash of her past work with flashes of dancefloor emotionality, striking a balance between reflective contemplation and the ego-melting thrills of a warehouse party.
mtv mo troper rock on his fifth album, the portland power-pop musician embraces a spontaneous, home-recorded approach that exudes a playful charm.

guy guy pop/r&b each sunday, pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. today, we revisit guy’s self-titled debut, the album that solidified the sound of new jack swing and established teddy riley as the most influential r&b producer of the late 1980s.
separation ylayali rock the philadelphia musician’s new album resembles the indelible emotional resonance of a dream, allowing his idiosyncrasies as a storyteller to shine.
bajascillators bitchin bajas experimental the chicago psych trio’s loops and layers seem to play tricks on time: long songs fly by quickly, and short pieces feel expansive.
guilty pleasure cheem rock the hartford, connecticut five-piece repurpose what many consider the worst parts of 2000s scene culture and rap-rock into a 22-minute ode to unpretentiousness.

will of the people muse rock working under the auspices of another vague, dystopian narrative, the uk band slaps a shiny new label on the grafted remains of better songs and calls it the ninth muse album.
the forever story jid rap the atlanta rapper’s latest lp is an ambitious and overwhelming experience, a bridge between his upbringing and his place within hip-hop canon and black history at large.

carpet cocoon iceblink electronic, experimental following her ambient collaboration with cole pulice earlier this year, lynn avery’s newly reissued 2020 lp is charmingly offbeat and shrouded in snowy intimacy.
icarus cryalot pop/r&b balancing the familiar sweetness of her vocals against bruised club beats, the debut ep from kero kero bonito’s sarah midori perry traverses newly dark emotional terrain.
higgs boson runhild gammelsæter experimental, rock
touch the lock uto pop/r&b the parisian duo’s debut full-length harnesses controlled chaos, offering an engrossing introduction to their prismatic synth pop.

music for four guitars bill orcutt experimental the veteran improviser creates a virtual quartet indebted to classical minimalism and avant-garde guitar ensembles, sculpting multitracked figures into complex systems.
honeybee table at the butterfly feast teen suicide rock teen suicide return with a sprawling new album that meditates on the anxiety and indifference of love and mortality.
a spirit appears to a pair of lovers gryphon rue experimental the new york curator and multimedia artist uses droning farfisa organs and arpeggiated synths to tap into a tripped-out spirit of wonder.

significant soil mister water wet experimental kansas city producer iggy romeu’s strange, evocative second album for west mineral feels so divorced from musical convention, there’s the thrilling sense that anything could happen.

11:11 regina spektor rock a new box set collects the singer-songwriter’s 2001 debut alongside a set of live recordings from her early days in new york, showcasing the intimate performance style and vivid, theatrical lyrics that ignited her career.
garden gaia pantha du prince electronic on pantha du prince’s sixth album, the organic tumult is so thick that electronic tones and rhythms bend and buckle around it.

pre pleasure julia jacklin rock the australian songwriter’s empathetic, understated rock songs sift through a litany of relationships and beliefs, seeking a balance between thinking about life and actually living it.
dollar menu 4 mach-hommy rap variously lively and listless, the latest entry in mach-hommy and tha god fahim’s series highlights the flaws in the formula even as it celebrates their bond.

against the odds: 1974 - 1982 blondie rock a new archival box set collecting blondie’s first six albums and assorted rarities and outtakes makes the case for their singular presence in american music.

evolution here we come chris forsyth experimental, rock taking influence from the rock music of the early 1980s, the experimental guitarist settles into the role of a traditional frontman on a sharp, guest-heavy new record.

the painter william orbit electronic an icon of ’90s pop-dance crossover who produced madonna’s , the uk musician returns with his first album in eight years, but the record’s endless-sunset vibes quickly turn cloying.

duty now for the future devo rock each sunday, pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. today, we revisit a spirited but uneven salvo from the ohio pranksters’ campaign to reprogram american minds.
flood stella donnelly rock grounding her second album in moments of real vulnerability, the australian singer-songwriter zeroes in on her guiding concern as a musician: how we seek and create safety.
earth patterns szun waves experimental, jazz on its most cohesive album to date, the improvisatory jazz trio finds new power in silence and restraint.

broken gargoyles diamanda galás experimental based upon early 1900s german poetry about sick patients and maimed soldiers, these two side-long tracks of experimental vocalizations highlight the singer’s conceptual, confrontational heft.

all of us flames ezra furman rock returning to familiar sounds of vintage girl groups and rock’n’roll, ezra furman writes trans pride and existential fear into an album that reveals the full strength of her vulnerabilities.

from there / to here: uk/us recordings 1974-1982 bridget st. john folk/country animated by a sense of endless potential and patchwork charm, a new box set collects the influential british songwriter’s work during a transitional period.

let’s turn it into sound kaitlyn aurelia smith experimental with tangled, stop-start arrangements that open to unexpected trap doors, the composer and synthesizer musician brings playfulness to the fore. you might call this her “pop” album.

the elephant man’s bones roc marciano rap toned down but no less penitent, nostalgic but ready to stake a claim to a new future, the duo’s long-awaited full-length is one of the most indulgently sinister rap records of the year.

spaceships on the blade larry june rap the san francisco rapper’s laid-back presence is the perfect foil to tales of luxury rides and big-money moves. on his latest album, he slips into a more romantic mode.
pillow talk tink pop/r&b collaborating with producer hitmaka, the r&b artist abandons her concept-album ambitions for a free-flowing collage of simple, irresistible pleasures.
bleed out the mountain goats rock john darnielle’s band returns to visceral guitar-rock directness for a collection of songs that embrace and humanize the familiar tropes of action cinema.
gnosis russian circles metal, rock on its dauntless and electrifying eighth album, the post-metal trio recharges its familiar sound.

heartmind cass mccombs folk/country across a casually sublime album, cass mccombs is at his most confident and intentional, constantly returning to the imagery of music and the casualties of a life devoted to making and sharing art.
freakout/release hot chip electronic treating music as something like a homeopathic remedy, joins doubt with deliverance over the cleansing pulse of a disco beat.

killer in neverland 4s4ki experimental blending melodic rap, explosive pop-punk, and languid electro-pop, the japanese singer and producer’s adventurous new album is fueled by an impassioned wish to escape reality.

drillmatic heart vs. mind the game rap the veteran rapper’s 29-track, 112-minute album is a bloated attempt to remind everyone he’s a great mc, flitting between styles without rendering any of them memorable.
how do i get that star zannie rock brooklyn songwriter zannie owens’ debut is a loose concept album about a lost alien—and an opaque inquiry into the shifting nature of reality.
v o r t e x terence etc. jazz the debut full-length from the celebrated filmmaker collages genres with abstract ambition, but it often lands with unnerving headiness.

greatest hits ’88 - ’16 wench experimental this collaboration between arca and shayne oliver looks back at a scene where queer and trans artists of color birthed avant-garde club sounds that continue to hold sway today.

duo geloso arnold dreyblatt experimental performing live in 1987, the avant-garde composers extracted complexity from simple designs and novel instrumentation. a new release captures their meditative and playful collaboration.
only built 4 diamond links peezy rap following his release from jail, the michigan rapper expands the aperture of his street tales with cinematic storytelling and post-prison clarity.
90 in november why bonnie rock led by singer-songwriter blair howerton, the debut from the sun-baked indie band sounds cozy but yearns for open spaces.
success oneida rock the long-running experimental band ends the longest gap of its career with a set of urgent, direct, and celebratory songs.
profound mysteries ii röyksopp electronic, pop/r&b the norwegian duo sets out to honor their forebears in electronic music, but they end up falling back on derivative, uninspired clichés.
was it ever real? the soft pink truth electronic on his latest ep as the soft pink truth, drew daniel of matmos offers a luxe version of deep house that leans into the carnal qualities of club music.
holy fvck demi lovato pop/r&b demi lovato has long sung about rebirth. on , she enacts it by jettisoning the pop-r&b palette that has defined her records for a decade.
unravelled: 1981-2002 tall dwarfs rock the new zealand duo of chris knox and alec bathgate have influenced generations of lo-fi rockers. this 55-track box set reminds us why.
get fucked the chats rock like bassist and vocalist eamon sandwith’s already iconic bowl-cut/mullet combo, is militaristic severity up front, party in the back.

squeezing out sparks graham parker rock each sunday, pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. today, we revisit an underappreciated icon of new wave and his best album, a clinic in lean, sardonic, emotive pop songwriting.

physical thrills silversun pickups rock it’s no return to form, but the alt-rock band’s sixth album taps into a well of quarantine-bound inspiration for some of their most varied and carefree songs in over a decade.

matriarchy now pussy riot rock, experimental the russian collective’s dance-pop protest mixtape arrives a decade after their guerrilla performances went viral across the globe. but its message is lackluster and belated, conforming to a shallow vision of feminist pop.

au suisse au suisse electronic, pop/r&b morgan geist and mike kelley’s first outing as a duo takes in a broad sweep of early-’80s reference points—disco, new romantic, sophistipop—that come together in an opalescent swirl.

eli winter eli winter folk/country, experimental joined by an illustrious lineup of players including yasmin williams, ryley walker, and jaimie branch, the chicago-based guitarist constructs wistful, evocative psychic landscapes.
ea monster young nudy rap the east atlanta rapper and his producers distill their sci-fi flows and alien sensibilities into their most cohesive project yet.

the distance between heart and mouth elaine howley experimental, pop/r&b the irish musician’s solo debut draws on the aesthetics of field recordings for understated, slow-burning experimental pop that prompts its own meditation on the creative process.

traumazine megan thee stallion rap on her second album, meg dishes out disses, gets political, and grapples with her personal life. it’s an ambitious and uneven attempt to step into her most challenging role yet: herself.

visions from the bridge jouska rock originally intended for release in 2018, the second album from the short-lived philadelphia-via-albany diy band is a pristine time capsule powered by lo-fi ingenuity.
beautiful mind rod wave rap the florida rapper’s latest “sad ass album” sticks to the same tried and true formula, at times actually sounding a little more hopeful.
no rules sandy sylvan esso pop/r&b recorded over a few weeks earlier this year, the electronic pop duo’s latest album takes a diffuse, improvisational approach that comes off feeling sterile.

bigger. messier. danny elfman following his long-delayed return to rock with last year’s —and this year’s much-memed coachella performance—the oingo boingo frontman delivers a characteristically chaotic set of remixes.
apricot angel flung pop/r&b on her latest album, the eclectic bay area artist weaves introspective themes into frantic, experimental pop music.
eccentric soul: the shiptown label various artists the numero group’s latest installment in the series paints a vivid portrait of the norfolk sound and its unsung influence.
gold arc tomato flower rock

songs of slavery and emancipation various artists faithfully recreating the music of slave organizers, freedom fighters, and abolitionists, a recent compilation sheds light on the politics of collective liberation at the root of 19th-century american folk and bluegrass.

link hoàng thùy linh pop/r&b the latest album from the vietnamese pop artist is an empowering statement of purpose, at its best when pairing evocative storytelling with theatrical, large-scale production.

cheat codes danger mouse rap after nearly two decades of on-off collaborations, the veteran musicians finally reach the finish line with their first full-length together, yielding a dozen tracks of solid, bare-bones hip-hop.
reset panda bear electronic sharing equal billing for the first time, longtime collaborators noah lennox and peter kember achieve an intoxicating mind meld over a sample-heavy tribute to 1960s pop.
unwanted pale waves rock the manchester band’s catchy, well-executed pop-punk stumbles on generic songwriting and bland ballads.
chopper kiwi jr. rock produced by wolf parade’s dan boeckner, the latest from the toronto band accompanies manic, referential lyrics with neon-tinted, futurist power-pop.

forever 1 girls’ generation pop/r&b thirteen years after their breakthrough hit, the k-pop icons are now elders in the scene. on their first album in five years, they combine effortlessness with versatility.

alam no hris (10th anniversary reissue) krill rock remastered for its 10th anniversary, the debut album from the cult boston diy trio is the sound of racing thoughts spiraling into numbness—and the restorative power of connection.

artpop lady gaga pop/r&b each sunday, pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. today, we revisit lady gaga’s most divisive and conceptually ambitious album.
a foul form osees rock the prolific band returns with a brief and seething left-turn: a furious homage to the scummiest, crustiest hardcore of the early ’80s.

half moon bay tomu dj experimental fusing club music’s dynamism with ambient’s tenderness, west coast producer tomu dj’s sophomore album calls to mind classic electronic full-lengths while offering something fresh in the process.
you take the credit, we’ll take the check jay worthy rap the rapper and producer team for a set of elaborate compositions with energetic, unpretentious writing.

pastlife day wave rock hewing faithfully to jackson phillips’ characteristically crisp, concise guitar pop, is a coming-of-age album for 30-year-olds, concerned with newfound commitments and misbegotten ambitions.

my name is hell kal marks rock following the dissolution of the longstanding boston power trio in 2020, carl shane reassembles the group as a quartet and pushes at the limits of its dense, cantankerous sound.
playboy fireboy dml pop/r&b on his third album, the 26-year-old afrobeats phenom grapples with newfound fame and attempts to trade his loverboy reputation for the role of suave rock star.
trifecta 2 shittyboyz rap with heaps of classic samples and pop culture references, the michigan rap crew keeps things breezy and showcases their tight-knit power.

cry sugar hudson mohawke electronic hudson mohawke embraces dystopian trash-pop imagery on his first album in seven years, maintaining his trademark clarity while bleeding and oozing over a larger canvas than ever.

fleeting adventure andrew tuttle folk/country, electronic the australian composer weaves ambient music and banjo strums into a meditative record, one that gazes upon the natural world with whimsy and joy.

kemo-sabe masao nakajima quartet jazz newly reissued by the bbe label’s j jazz series, the tokyo pianist’s 1979 album is more traditional than its contemporaries in the japanese jazz scene, but it overflows with character.

the last slimeto youngboy never broke again rap isolating his various traits into easily defined tracks, the baton rouge rap star’s new 30-song album suppresses the knotty, uncomfortable nuances that make his best music distinct.
art moore art moore rock a new project from boy scouts songwriter taylor vick expands her homespun sound into spectral, immersive dream pop.
my diary ep gyakie pop/r&b the rising afrobeats artist refines her style on a glossy, tightly woven ep.
fairy rust wombo rock the louisville indie rock trio takes a gloomy, fantastical turn on its third album.

funk wav bounces vol. 2 calvin harris pop/r&b, electronic borrowing from disco, electro-soul, boogie, and 1980s r&b, vibe commissioner calvin harris’ second volume of frictionless summer jams has the staying power of vape smoke at coachella.

don’t rush the process kaidi tatham electronic, jazz equally suited for headphones or the cookout, this is the uk multi-instrumentalist’s most expansive record yet, reaching beyond broken beat to incorporate boogie, disco, boom bap, jazz, and more.
not tight domi & jd beck jazz the debut album from the virtuosic duo is undeniably accomplished, a smooth but frenetic set aimed at bringing jazz fusion to a new hyper-brained generation.
at some point you stop phony rock on a scrappy solo album inspired by grief and personal upheaval, singer-songwriter and joyce manor guitarist neil berthier explores new musical outlets for emo.

she / her / black bitch doechii rap, pop/r&b the “yucky blucky fruitcake” rapper’s major label debut showcases her versatility but loses some of the vibrant personality that made her breakout hit so appealing.

out front booker little jazz each sunday, pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. today, we revisit a crucial jazz record from 1961, led by a lyrical trumpeter and composer who captured the many overlapping currents of the genre.

castle in the sky jennifer vanilla pop/r&b, experimental using their dance music alter ego, former ava luna vocalist becca kauffman gets more personal and philosophical while maintaining their whimsical sense of humor.
elio’s inferno elio pop/r&b with help from charli xcx, the toronto-based singer stretches big-tent pop music in her own image on a messy but tuneful mixtape.

what i breathe mall grab electronic australian producer jordon alexander threads rabble-rousing rave and late-night ruminations into a debut that purports to pay tribute to dance music history but has remarkably little to say.

intros, outros & interludes domo genesis rap on his second joint effort with producer evidence, and with his habitual loop-based rap now dominating the independent sphere, the odd future member sounds more confident than he has in years.

at grm peter rehberg electronic a posthumous release from the experimental musician and editions mego label founder includes two live performances that function as scale models of his singular sound world.
they fear us ithaca metal the london hardcore band’s second album takes a bolder, brighter approach. its embrace of self-love and community feels radical and hard-earned.
renaissance beyoncé pop/r&b beyoncé’s seventh album is not just a pop star’s immaculate dance record, but a rich celebration of club music and its sweaty, emancipatory spirit.
bodboy bobby shmurda rap as he makes a long-awaited return to music, bobby shmurda’s irrepressible charisma comes up against foggy raps and some sloppy production choices.

curtain call 2 eminem rap the rapper’s second greatest hits compilation collects some nice singles, but mostly feels like the portrait of a wayward artist who’s spent the last 13 years going in every direction.

waiting for columbus (super deluxe edition) little feat rock newly expanded with three complete concerts, this 1978 double live album captured the elastic, elusive charms of little feat and proved foundational for jam bands to come.
take it like a man amanda shires folk/country the singer-songwriter, fiddle player, and highwoman’s latest solo album dwells in the space between grand pop balladry and memphis soul.
panorama hayley kiyoko pop/r&b the singer and activist’s second album hides behind well-trodden pop star guises. even when the lyrics point towards desperation, there’s no frisson.

miracle in transit naked flames electronic peeling back the lo-fi veil of his previous work, the 23-year-old bristol producer channels classic club sounds and y2k video-game aesthetics into breathtaking new hybrids.
love the stranger friendship folk/country the philadelphia quartet’s first album for merge is a communal attempt to make magic out of the mundane.
freewave lucifer f<ck f^ck f>ck of montreal rock the band’s latest is geeky, restless, and stuffed with enough barnesian minutiae to satisfy even the most dedicated fan.

hold on baby king princess pop/r&b exploring the tensions of a long-term relationship, the pop artist’s second album is the work of a keen-eared musician coming into their own as a producer and stylist.

infinite window kuedo electronic on jamie teasdale’s third solo album, the uk musician balances razor-sharp bass music with beatless electronic sketches that could double as science-fiction soundtracks.
pool kids pool kids rock filled with gut punch hooks, the tallahassee band’s second album is carried by their battle-tested friendship and irrepressible chemistry.
la rareza los rarxs rap, pop/r&b the puerto rican trio’s debut album is a sleek collage of reggaetón, indie rock, and r&b, heralding a vivid new era of caribbean syncretism.
scorpion eyes bandgang lonnie bands rap on his new project, the detroit rapper lets his bleakest thoughts pour out. his nuanced renditions of pain make it hard to turn away.
isthisforreal? the koreatown oddity rap on an expansive new album, the los angeles rapper filters current events through the distorting fuzz of memes, late-night cable, and barbershop chatter.

florist florist folk/country recorded in a rented house in the hudson valley, and weaving together found sounds with spontaneous music-making, the quartet’s self-titled album is as much an audio documentary as it is a folk album.
happening launder rock john cudlip’s shoegaze band evokes the eyes-closed, blown-out atmospheric rock of the 1990s with studied precision and genuine passion.

extra presence carlos niño & friends jazz, experimental reworking his 2020 album , the los angeles percussionist links up with friends like deantoni parks and miguel atwood-ferguson, while laraaji and iasos lend new-age gravitas.
sun’s signature sun’s signature rock working alongside her partner damon reece, the cocteau twins’ elizabeth fraser delivers her most substantial musical statement in a quarter century.

ultra depeche mode electronic, rock each sunday, pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. today, we revisit depeche mode’s lush and electronic 1997 album, a bridge between the increasing ambition of their early years and the easy confidence of their later ones.
survivor’s guilt mozzy rap through blunt lyricism and melodic delivery, the veteran rapper’s first album for yo gotti’s cmg label opens up about trauma and mental health.

fantasy gateway cuco pop/r&b the bedroom-pop breakout star steps up his craft on his second album, experimenting with a bigger, more opulently produced sound, but his emotional attunement remains key to his appeal.
riderless horse nina nastasia rock after a 12-year absence, the singer-songwriter returns with a raw, unadorned celebration of survival.
las ruinas rico nasty rap rico nasty’s latest project skews wider and weirder, even for her. combining patented rage raps and tender singing, its variety is overwhelming in every sense of the word.

god’s country chat pile rock terrifying and thrilling in equal measure, the debut album from the oklahoma city sludge-metal band is a vivid rendering of the towering piles of poison littering america’s psychic landscape.
the last goodbye odesza electronic on their first album in five years, odesza are at their most introspective, yet their production remains tailored to fill stadiums and trigger pyrotechnics.

the social network trent reznor rock, experimental each sunday, pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. today, we revisit trent reznor and atticus ross’ first film score, a groundbreaking collaboration that gave its icy, unsettling tone.

rza presents: bobby digital and the pit of snakes rza rap revisiting his bobby digital character in the soundtrack to a forthcoming graphic novel, the typically freewheeling wu-tang rapper-producer sounds frustratingly restrained.
surrender maggie rogers pop/r&b the “alaska” star’s second album, which shares its title with her harvard divinity school thesis, asks big questions about life through confident pop anthems.

melt away: a tribute to brian wilson she & him rock zooey deschanel and m. ward’s first album together in six years is a low-stakes set of beach boys covers, toggling between merely pleasant and overly precious.
you still here, ho ? flo milli rap the alabama rapper’s official debut brings her sharp-tongued bars and bassy 808s into a glittery world of early-’00s pop culture and reality tv nostalgia.
entering heaven alive jack white rock the follow-up to this year’s wild is a stripped-down songwriter record, but often the songs don’t resonate as deeply as the sounds.

high reality rusty santos experimental with warbly melodies and cozy instrumentation, the songwriter and producer’s first solo album in 16 years finds an intimate sanctuary. the messiness is a feature, not a flaw.

rich off pints 3 icewear vezzo rap the detroit rap stalwart makes hard-hitting music with no frills. his latest project basks in the idea that an album this regionally specific can still have nationwide appeal.
sons of sam prekop electronic, rock the first duo record from the longtime sea and cake bandmates exemplifies the ramshackle, improvisatory spirit that’s at the heart of modular synthesis.
quinn quinn experimental, electronic the former hyperpop star’s new album is refreshingly warm and musical, characterized by an unvarnished left-field funkiness lacking in her online contemporaries.
gemini rights steve lacy pop/r&b on his second full-length album, the guitarist and producer’s songs are engorged and confident, powered by deft performances and focused storytelling.
b-sides ep julien baker rock three tracks from the singer-songwriter’s sessions further detail her dread, suffering, and sadness with great beauty and little reprieve.
aveilut scarcity metal, experimental the debut collaboration from classical composer brendon randall-myers and metal vocalist doug moore is an unflinching testimonial on grief and endurance.
hour of green evening goon rock the los angeles quartet’s new record turns to nature and childhood past by blending plaintive psychedelic rock with sweet folk melodies.

30 something orbital electronic the iconic uk rave duo belatedly celebrates its 30th anniversary with a mixture of new songs, re-recordings of classic tracks, and remixes from the artists they’ve inspired.
xi: bleed here now ...and you will know us by the trail of dead rock the austin band returns with its longest and loosest record, characterized by a new sense of lightness.

american rituals cheri knight experimental a new anthology uncovers a forgotten history from early 1980s olympia: a set of playful, experimental, wholly original recordings based on skeletal multi-tracking and looped vocals.
special lizzo pop/r&b, rap as the relentlessly positive artist ascends to pop culture ubiquity, her hook-filled and saccharine music feels increasingly boxed in by the lizzo brand.
