yesterday is heavy lil silva electronic, rap the uk producer’s debut album, 12 years into his career, bridges his popstar songwriting with his work in the uk funky scene.

the course of the inevitable 2 lloyd banks rap the former g-unit rapper is not as dynamic or adventurous as many of his contemporaries, but his wisdom and skill make it hard not to get caught up in his second act.

expressed, i noticed silence m. geddes gengras experimental this is a relatively low-key offering, compared to the prolific synth musician’s psychedelic standards, but it still abounds with a wealth of crunchy textures and trippy atmospheres.
emotional creature beach bunny rock with a newly polished sound, the indie pop group’s latest is a neatly packaged document of quarter-life angst.
“hello, hi” ty segall rock the prolific songwriter’s latest is an acoustic detour, a quiet soundtrack for overcast days.
spectral madeleine cocolas experimental atop a base of field recordings made near her home, the australian composer layers pensive piano and electronics into a meditation on perception and memory.

pain is love ja rule rap each sunday, pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. today, we revisit ja rule’s fleeting moment in the sun, a chart-topping 2001 album whose magnetic pop crossovers foreshadowed the future of melodic rap.

2000 joey bada$$ rap the brooklyn rapper’s first new studio album in five years puts a plush bad boy veneer over corner-bred rhyme schemes. wide-ranging production makes it easy to ignore the rough spots.
thyrsis of etna miszczyk rock the ontario producer turns to a deep bench of guests—stereolab’s laetitia sadier, pylon’s vanessa briscoe hay—for a debut album steeped in krautrock’s murky throb.
hellfire black midi rock the preposterously talented english band’s third record is pitched between clinical precision and crazed abandon.

spider season nick dunston experimental after the complex structures of his quintet’s debut, the rising brooklyn jazz musician strips down to a trio of bass, trombone, and gayageum to explore fluid arrangements and textural interplay.

beatopia beabadoobee pop/r&b inspired by a childhood dreamworld and the pop radio hits of the 2000s, bea kristi’s second album is simultaneously heavy and light, dense and playful, melodic and dissonant.

new pleasures arp electronic on the follow-up to 2018’s warm, naturalistic , alexis georgopoulos veers in the opposite direction, constructing a glassy paradise out of ’80s-inspired drum machines and analog synths.
pink room wet pop/r&b the alt-pop trio’s stripped-down ep plays almost like a series of demos, abandoning anything that gets in the way of singer kelly zutrau’s hushed melodies.

earl’s closet: the lost archive of earl mcgrath, 1970-1980 various artists capturing the sound and spirit of its time, this compilation of demos and home recordings showcases the mellow, genre-blurring taste of ’70s record man earl mcgrath.

isoviha vladislav delay electronic continues in the harsh, blistering vein of the finnish producer’s 2020 album and its sequel. but while the sensory onslaught once felt purifying, the new lp is deliberately disruptive.

lexicon lynyn electronic on his debut album under a new alias, chicago’s conor mackey focuses his varied interests on knotty electronic music, merging a panoply of subgenres into one pummeling package.
the other side of make-believe interpol rock with slight changes in disposition and geography, the new york band strives toward a refreshed sound and outlook on its seventh record.

formentera metric rock on their eighth album, the canadian new wave torchbearers interrogate their career and mourn the death of a kind of rockstar success even as they celebrate their achievement of it.

living torch kali malone experimental the stockholm-based composer is best known for her pipe-organ compositions, but here, she uses trombone, bass clarinet, and arp 2500 to explore the strange radiance of just intonation.
x ken carson rap on his latest album, the atlanta rapper lacks curiosity, imagination, and charisma. it’s like being whacked with a slab of styrofoam.
scrutiny fashion club rock los angeles musician pascal stevenson’s solo debut harkens to ’80s goth rock, but at the album’s core lies a righteous intellectual ennui.

cave world viagra boys rock satirizing the mindset of the alt-right internet troll requires more gravitas than these swedish punks can pull off consistently. but what lacks in bite, it tends to make up for in groove.

this is america johnny gandelsman experimental on an ambitious three-disc project, the violinist collaborates with a wide array of bright, younger composers, crystallizing a new vision for american classical music.
wasteland brent faiyaz pop/r&b the singer’s latest album is both overbearing and underbaked, smothering lovely vocals and intriguing ideas underneath blockbuster features and irritating interludes.
love, damini burna boy rap, pop/r&b on his fourth album, the afro-fusion giant drops his guard and invites listeners into his chaotic inner world, with mixed results.
peace “fly” god westside gunn rap the latest from the buffalo rapper is a lean, mean project cut in just two days, eschewing his usual attention to detail for a more ramshackle approach.
found light laura veirs rock the portland songwriter captures a mood of ordinary enchantment on her spacious and stirring 12th record.
tresor gwenno pop/r&b the singer and songwriter’s second album sung almost entirely in cornish is a document of a revived linguistic heritage with a breezy, ethereal touch.
softly tatsuro yamashita pop/r&b at 69, the japanese singer-songwriter and city-pop icon is still working in pursuit of the perfect pop song.
amplified guitar mat ball experimental working with a homemade instrument and utilizing unconventional techniques, the montreal musician carves vast, expansive forms out of guitar feedback.
save me empress of pop/r&b lorely rodriguez returns with a short collection of disco- and house-inflected pop songs about tormented emotions and burning desire.
drill music in zion lupe fiasco rap on his eighth album, lupe fiasco relinquishes his sanctimonious impulses and refocuses his vision on phonetic thrills and poignant reflection.
loggerhead wu-lu experimental on his first album for warp, the south london musician mixes grunge guitars with drum’n’bass breaks and claustrophobic atmospheres, seeking uneasy catharsis.
jazz codes moor mother experimental on her second solo album in nine months, the experimental poet and musician grapples with black musical histories and “the work of memory.”

spirit exit caterina barbieri experimental crafted at home in a period of unusual focus, the italian synthesist’s latest album feels like a reflection of a world gone haywire: one part prayer, one part screaming at the void.
toast neil young rock recorded in 2001, this previously unreleased lp from young and his most recognizable accompanists is a surprisingly slick, fans-only affair.

dirt alice in chains rock each sunday, pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. today, we revisit a hard-rock colossus, one of the heaviest and bleakest albums to come out of the early ’90s seattle scene.

the essential asha puthli asha puthli jazz a new compilation devoted to the charismatic, underappreciated indian jazz singer captures her sizzling spirit and illustrates the breadth of her musicianship.
medicine singers medicine singers rock the debut collaboration between the native american group and guitarist yonatan gat offers vivid new context for the sound of the powwow drum.
mesmerism tyshawn sorey trio jazz on a new piano trio album, the jazz visionary delights in reverent arrangements from the great american songbook and beyond.

groove theory groove theory pop/r&b each sunday, pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. today, we revisit the duo’s first and only album, a cool and atmospheric bomb thrown into the waters of ’90s r&b.

holy diver (super deluxe edition) dio metal the zenith of ronnie james dio’s formidable career, reissued on what would have been his 80th birthday, is a heavy metal holy grail —a beacon of iconic riffs and ecstatic, empowering anthems.
game time shaudy kash rap drawing on both his west coast influences and detroit hometown, the rapper’s third mixtape of the year ranges from hard-hitting and aggressive to chill and reflective.

image langage félicia atkinson experimental the french artist’s music absorbs and unsettles, juxtaposing whispers, wisps of atmospheric noise, and digitally rendered instruments that float around the auditory field in uncanny ways.
self oscillation nicola cruz electronic a drummer and sound engineer with wide-ranging influences, the franco-ecuadorian producer constructs dancefloor rhythms that snap with feral intensity.
give or take giveon pop/r&b giveon’s debut album seeks to scale the highs and lows of love and heartbreak, but more often sounds like he’s cruising on autopilot in the center lane.
step by step alan braxe electronic featuring a standout vocal performance from panda bear, the french house veterans’ new ep could almost be mistaken for a lost classic of the y2k era.

giant palm naima bock rock, pop/r&b the london singer-songwriter, formerly of goat girl, teams with producer joel burton and a host of musicians on a sharply observed, sumptuously arranged album of idiosyncratic folk.
faith like esther duwap kaine rap a sleek and bleary new project from the savannah rapper drifts toward r&b and pop, communicating as much through the sound as its lyrics.
new low greet death rock the flint, michigan, doomgazers’ follow-up to 2019’s dabbles in new styles while doubling down on the unrelenting misery.
reggae film star damien jurado rock while revisiting a treasured childhood tv show, the amber-voiced songwriter reaches back for the psychedelic majesty of his work with the late richard swift.

medallions monarchy planet asia rap the fresno, california veteran stakes a claim to his legacy by continuing to do what he does best: rolling out boasts, anecdotes, and smack talk like he’s working over a speed bag.
the spur joan shelley folk/country accompanied by a wide range of verdant textures, the kentucky songwriter deepens the emotional landscape of her earthy, reflective folk music.
hard industrial b.o.p. prison religion rap where the virginia duo’s previous records fused rap, techno, and other aggressive forms, its new album lumbers into a terrifying new realm of noise.

minions: the rise of gru (original motion picture soundtrack) various artists helmed by jack antonoff, the ’70s-themed soundtrack for the children’s film features covers and collaborations from phoebe bridgers, st. vincent, diana ross, tame impala, and more.
space age pimpin’ juicy j rap the debut collaborative project suffers from a lack of chemistry, as pi’erre bourne struggles to stand out within juicy j’s signature gothic sound.
sznz: summer weezer rock the second entry in the band’s vivaldi-inspired quartet of eps gives a perfunctory nod to the concept before resuming weezer-by-numbers.
azli ahmer rap where the kashmiri rapper’s debut album was a fist-waving call to arms, is a desolate post-mortem of a revolution stalled.
not mine carlos truly pop/r&b the ava luna singer delivers an excellent solo album of minimalist funk and r&b pared down to its barest essence.
meet the moonlight jack johnson rock collaborating with blake mills to make his best album yet, the gentle songwriter pushes beyond feel-good stereotypes to look for small joys amid vexing times.

barbarism katie alice greer rock the debut solo album from the former lead singer of priests feels caught between reality and nightmare, balancing dissonant soundscapes against an eerie, self-possessed sense of calm.
household name momma rock the brooklyn duo’s cheeky spin on gen-x slacker rock asks: what does it take to become a 1990s alt-rock star right this minute?
sometimes, forever soccer mommy rock as the shadows deepen on sophie allison’s third album, she sees into the lie on the other side of success: you can win, but you still have to live with yourself.

twenty twenty twenty twenty one spencer krug rock the anxieties of isolation and newfound fatherhood are reflected in home recordings the wolf parade co-founder made in his rural home studio during the doldrums of 2020 and 2021.

icons two shell electronic the cheeky london duo put their own spin on uk bass music, and their latest ep of compu-heaters is one of the most substantial releases of their young but already impressive career.
high school tim heidecker rock the comedian-turned-musician’s concept album about his adolescence tunnels toward a series of deeper truths about how we end up as the adults we are.

tilt scott walker rock each sunday, pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. today, we revisit scott walker’s 1995 turn to the avant-garde, a dense and operatic work of geopolitical and psychosexual pop music.
natural part horse jumper of love rock the boston rock trio’s latest attempts to reconnect with the songwriting focus of their early demos, pushing beyond slowcore in search of something more direct.
heaven is here candy metal the bi-coastal quartet fleshes out classic elements of hardcore and metal with industrial, shoegaze, and noise. even their love songs feel extreme.
happy hour hollie cook pop/r&b refining her muscular take on lovers rock, the latest from the uk singer is at its best when she’s veering from tradition.

not about to die wire rock decades after it surfaced as a bootleg, a collection of demos from the late 1970s reveals hidden threads running through a crucial moment in the uk post-punk legends’ evolution.
arkhon zola jesus electronic nika roza danilova’s sixth record is more collaborative, widening the scope of her music and taking big leaps while retaining its primal, gothic spirit.
honestly, nevermind drake rap a breezy drake dance album sounds great in concept, but the half-measure house beats and lackluster songwriting keep it from really popping off.

finally enough love madonna pop/r&b the dance-pop icon selects her favorites remixes from a back catalog stuffed with club reworks, but her picks offer a curiously distorted look back at her history on the dancefloor.
guv iv young guv rock fucked up guitarist ben cook’s latest installment of power pop ventures into laurel canyon and post-punk without clouding its permanent sunshine.
muna muna pop/r&b the los angeles trio steps fully into their role as pop stars and mentors, offering gentle instructions for falling in love, dusting yourself off, and joyfully living your truth.
closure / continuation porcupine tree rock on its first album in over a decade, the uk prog band embraces a newly collaborative process, setting an atmosphere of creeping tension and volatility.
estrela acesa sessa rock sergio sayeg’s unhurried nylon string guitar and softly danceable rhythms put a smooth, minimalist flourish on the vibrant musical heritage of brazil.
seven psalms nick cave rock a self-consciously minor work, this collection of spoken-word pieces is a brief but beatific respite during a particularly rewarding era of the songwriter’s long career.
farm to table bartees strange rock on his second album, bartees strange widens his stance and levels his gaze, staying grounded in his nimble genre-hopping and his dynamic songwriting.
more black superheroes westside boogie rap the compton rapper’s latest is a musical therapy session, a concept album filled with intimate writing and rich, varied production.
dripfield goose rock following an unlikely breakthrough, the connecticut quintet known for its euphoric live shows delivers a solid lp that avoids some major pitfalls of jam bands in the studio.
vinyl days logic rap both impressive and tiring, logic’s seventh studio album stuffs 30 tracks’ worth of throwback beats and technical rapping into overbearing conceptual frameworks.
what do the stars say to you ron trent electronic the veteran chicago dance producer sets aside club conventions in favor of an ultra-smooth hybrid of house, disco, jazz, and new age.
saturn child lil tracy rap the rapper’s latest is a cosmic synthesis of edm, emo rap, and cutesy pop refrains that echoes the rave fantasies of drain gang.
home, before and after regina spektor rock regina spektor’s first album in six years is weighty and ambitious, full of sweeping string arrangements and cosmic ruminations on love and loss.
magic sign martin courtney rock the second solo album from the real estate frontman defaults to carefree songwriting that explores sacred moments of adolescence in the jersey suburbs.
emerald sea sound of ceres the new york group recruits marina abramović to narrate a mythological dream-pop epic suffused in rich, swirling arrangements.

in amber hercules and love affair electronic stripping away the dancefloor euphoria of his most recognizable work, andy butler’s latest is a moody left-turn highlighted by some winning collaborations with anohni.
ugly season perfume genius pop/r&b the expansive spirit of mike hadreas’ terrific new album conjures and reimagines a mode of experimental pop music that is ecstatic, healing, modern, and queer.

the new four seasons - vivaldi recomposed max richter experimental a decade after his wildly successful rework of the baroque giant’s ubiquitous string concerti, the london composer revisits the material yet again, but the differences can be hard to pick out.
pink dolphins anteloper jazz, experimental trumpeter jaimie branch and drummer jason nazary team up with producer jeff parker on an album of electronic jazz fusion and aqueous psychedelia.

love is yours flasher rock four years after their debut, the d.c. band regroups as a duo for a more electronic guitar-pop album that keeps their preternatural sense of melody but sands down a few of their more unique touches.
i told bessie elucid rap the latest solo work from the armand hammer rapper is a tribute to his grandmother’s memory that doubles as a statement of identity.
life is yours foals rock foals’ streamlined seventh album does away with their trickier instrumental interplay and subtler emotions, leaving nothing at all open to interpretation.

remember your north star yaya bey pop/r&b the prismatic, outstanding new album from the brooklyn singer-songwriter moves gracefully through jazz, r&b, soul, and reggae. it’s a searching and specific exploration of connection, pain, and desire.

houses of the wind john luther adams experimental fashioned from an archival recording of an aeolian harp in the alaskan wilds, the environmental composer’s shimmering, wind-driven drones telegraph both majesty and dread.

now that’s what i call pride various artists the inexhaustible compilation series reaches the pot of gold at the end of rainbow capitalism with a bulging 84-track compendium for pride. even a cynical corporate package can’t quash the music’s joy.
revelators revelators sound system rock a new instrumental project from hiss golden messenger’s m.c. taylor and cameron ralston drifts between moments of tranquility and cosmic dissonance.

superstore sam gendel jazz the hyper-prolific los angeles saxophonist again opens his archive of ambient sketches, cloud-rap beats, and jazz experiments. it’s a far more compact package than last year’s sprawling .
up and away σtella pop/r&b with producer redinho, the greek pop artist smooths out some of her defining idiosyncrasies, embracing new sounds but lacking the vision to transcend her influences.
fresh pepper fresh pepper rock this culinary-themed toronto supergroup crafts languorous jazz-pop grooves that capture the ambiance of a bistro dying down at closing time.
time~lapse nature diatom deli experimental with intricate layers of field recordings, the new mexico-based artist lets small details become the pillars of her patient folk songs.
landscape and voice toshiya tsunoda experimental on a visceral new album, the japanese sound artist blends field recordings with glitches and loops to conjure the push-pull flow of a world in flux.

the versions neneh cherry pop/r&b robyn, sia, anohni, jamila woods, and more all try their hand at some of neneh cherry’s greatest hits revealing just how erratically wonderful the swedish singer has been across her four-decade career.

silent cities levon vincent electronic the berlin-based producer’s fourth full-length trades his customary techno for 78 minutes of grimly beautiful music. it’s a long, bleak, challenging album that envelops the listener in darkness and fog.
kaduwa free the robots electronic the underrated los angeles-based producer returns to his filipino roots on his latest album, a psychedelic collection of blunted tracks and club compositions.
harbor taylor deupree electronic the 14th solo release from the ambient musician and 12k label head is a refined display of his impeccable devotion to his craft.
mil coisas invisíveis tim bernardes rock the são paulo songwriter returns with a delicate, well-crafted collection that highlights his dynamic vocals and ear for melody and production.
ashbalkum salamanda electronic the electronic duo captures a spirit of childlike wonder with a playful, faintly psychedelic sound incorporating surreal vocals and mallet instruments.

editrix ii: editrix goes to hell editrix rock wendy eisenberg’s trio combines bludgeoning post-hardcore with off-kilter runs, hairpin turns, and deceptively nonchalant vocals. the subject matter is serious, but it’s clear they’re having fun.

19 masters saya gray pop/r&b on her debut album, the toronto-based singer radiates anxiety and yearning about love, offering an unadulterated document of a fluid creative process and truly weird, impulsive thoughts.

reflexions tony shhnow rap candy-colored plugg beats sharing space with sample-based production might cause whiplash in anybody else’s hands, but it all comes together with the confidence of shhnow’s voice
40 oz. to fresno joyce manor rock though less consciously ambitious than their previous two albums, the california power pop band’s latest is a pure refinement of their sound and feel.
i don’t tap in or tap out big sad 1900 rap the west l.a. rapper attempts to broaden his sound on his latest album, a breezy collection of songs that combines low-key anecdotes with hard-won wisdom.
trapnificent trapland pat rap the southern florida rapper’s new mixtape is a zippy distillation of his regional roots, mixed with a few standout wrinkles.

vanishing act benny bock jazz the solo debut of the los angeles composer and weeknd associate is a sobering, often surreal film reel of fleeting joy, made by a talent whose only agenda is to capture the sounds in his head.

teeth marks s.g. goodman folk/country on her self-produced second album, the kentucky songwriter offers vivid portraits of complex people, synthesizing decades of southern music into a singular vision.

janky star grace ives pop/r&b on her second album, the new york pop songwriter broadens her sound without sacrificing brevity, fitting grander ideas into the same compact frame. it’s one of the best little pop albums of the year.
the great awakening shearwater rock the first album in six years from jonathan meiburg and co. returns to the band’s patient style of baroque, naturalistic art-rock.
re: m field m field rock the south african singer-songwriter’s artful pop is full of wit and revelation. his second ep is evidence of an artist blossoming into form.
mercury the range electronic on his first album in six years, the vermont-based musician continues to flesh out lush, melancholy electronic music with amateur vocals sourced from the internet.
fault lines deliluh rock known for its restless ambition and diy spirit, the post-punk group evolves with unnerving ambience, spoken-word recitations, and industrial noise.

occasional rain terry callier pop/r&b each sunday, pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. today, we revisit the winding and mystic 1972 album from the chicago jazz and folk singer-songwriter.
magic pony ride µ-ziq electronic on his first full solo release on planet mu in nine years, veteran idm producer mike paradinas looks to the past, pairing jungle breaks with sugary synths.
madness poliça rock the synth-pop group’s latest album incorporates eerie, inventive production that sometimes overpowers their strengths.

nothing to declare 700 bliss experimental, rap, electronic on the duo’s debut full-length, dj haram’s east coast club influences meet moor mother’s shape-shifting wordplay. it’s a noisy, thrillingly confrontational album.
versions of modern performance horsegirl rock chicago’s horsegirl mines a loose-limbed indie rock sound on their debut album, with an assist from some members of sonic youth.
graves purity ring electronic on the follow-up to 2020’s , the duo is torn between looking back and moving forward. mostly, they add layers of polish to their familiar electro-pop sound.

this is brian jackson brian jackson jazz the former gil scott-heron collaborator’s first solo album in over 20 years is forged in the vein of his work with the late poet, and rewrites some unfair narratives.
heart under just mustard rock the irish shoegaze band plunges into darkness on its brilliantly textured second album, led by the eerie vocals of katie ball.
themselves al riggs folk/country the north carolina songwriter summons a vast network of real-life characters for an empathetic, intensely personal record about death, rebirth, and transformation.
east haiti baby big moochie grape rap steeped in the memphis underground tradition, the young dolph associate’s latest album is full of hard-working hustler music that never lets up.

you can’t kill me 070 shake rap on her second album, the new jersey singer-songwriter recenters her romantic anguish through a more muted delivery, but her plaintive songwriting hasn’t lost its intoxicating touch.

twelve carat toothache post malone rap post malone’s fourth studio album is slick, streamlined, and a little less vulgar and ostentatious than his earlier work—a sign that he’s taking himself more seriously, for better or worse.

inside problems andrew bird rock working with a few key collaborators, the singer-songwriter delves into inner turmoil and late-night anxieties. but they play with a relaxed touch, creating a cozy, inviting atmosphere.

epicus doomicus metallicus candlemass metal the swedish band’s 1986 debut balanced lumbering riffs and operatic drama, spawning the genre of epic doom metal. this reissue pairs its crushing, rough-hewn songs with demos and rehearsal recordings.
universal credit jeshi rap arriving during the uk’s worst cost-of-living crisis since the 1950s, the north london rapper’s debut album is an artfully told portrait of life on the dole.

i used to think i could fly tate mcrae pop/r&b even when she’s singing about self-loathing, the 18-year-old pop star and dancer exudes a swagger. her full-length debut proves she’s capable of transcending online virality.

nancy & lee nancy sinatra pop/r&b, folk/country full of vivid detail and imagination, this defining 1968 album by nancy sinatra and lee hazlewood gets its first official reissue, highlighting their peculiar alchemy and otherworldly sound.
hyaline maria bc rock, experimental the defining strength of the oakland-based artist’s debut album is its mood: an overarching melancholy that shadows everything like heavy storm clouds.

holotropica sofie birch experimental while her work has always had a kind of horizontal drift, the danish composer’s latest is more song-like and elaborate. it is the most intricate and ambitious music she has released.
big time angel olsen rock angel olsen taps deeper into her country influences on a warm, self-assured album whose fluid narration unites love and grief, past and present.

world in world julia reidy experimental on these ruminative solo guitar pieces, the berlin-based artist takes an idiosyncratic and emotionally expressive approach, making even the most ordinary gestures sound mutated and strange.

midnight is comin’ ¥øu$uk€ ¥uk1mat$u electronic, experimental the osaka dj favors long, gradual mixes and careful pairings. his new mix album for singapore’s midnight shift is a hypnotic descent into ambient, drone, and noise.

welfare / practice lucy liyou electronic, experimental listening to the philadelphia-based artist’s music can be an intense, discomforting experience, but their sparse sounds and diaristic text-to-speech vocals reveal a world of conflicting emotions.

men (original motion picture soundtrack) ben salisbury electronic, rock on their latest collaboration with director alex garland, geoff barrow and ben salisbury craft an unsettling vocal-driven score to match the creepy idyll of .

prince and the revolution: live prince pop/r&b, rock remastered, rescanned, and color corrected after years languishing in paisley park’s vault, the 1985 concert film and its soundtrack receive the deluxe reissue treatment they’ve long deserved.

wish the cure rock each sunday, pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. today, we revisit the cure’s commercial peak in 1992, a pivotal, fantastic, and often overlooked album in the band’s catalog.

flood they might be giants rock each sunday, pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. today, we revisit the breakthrough lp from a pair of proud eccentrics whose arcane preoccupations and clever songwriting made them unlikely stars.
blue skies dehd rock the chicago three-piece hasn’t changed a thing about its streamlined indie rock, evoking youthful abandon and the ache of distantly-recalled bliss.
deep in view cola rock featuring members of the recently disbanded ought, the post-punk trio makes its debut with skeletal songs of modern anxiety and isolation.
raw data feel everything everything rock peppered with star trek references, meme humor, and lyrics generated by an ai trained on and 4chan, the english band’s sixth album is its nerdiest yet.
hitgirl dreezy rap the chicago rapper’s collaborative album with hit-boy is confident and playful, balancing her lyrical prowess with more vulnerable, r&b-influenced material.
billboard for my feelings ep hovvdy rock on a new ep, the texas indie-pop duo refines its approach with striking details and emotional tension.

forest in the city umi pop/r&b on her full-length debut, the r&b singer expands her musicality and lyrical confidence. the album is ambitious in its scope even as it treads the oft-wandered territories.
baby, we’re ascending haai electronic teneil throssell’s full-length debut is break-neck techno that tries to transcend the club without turning its back on it.
cruel country wilco rock on a 21-track double album recorded live in the studio, wilco embrace a simple, buoyant approach that hearkens back to jeff tweedy’s earliest work.

a presentation andrew bernstein experimental the horse lords saxophonist uses overdubbing to recast his instrument as a virtual organ. the quest of its making is as much part of the appeal as the music itself.

pripyat marina herlop electronic the catalan composer’s third album creates an immersive and at times thrilling world out of piano, electronics, and her remarkably agile voice, which is processed, stretched, and pulled apart at will.

regards / ukłony dla bogusław schaeffer matmos experimental m.c. schmidt and drew daniel reassemble the works of polish composer bogusław schaeffer into a playful fusion of electroacoustic music and electronic pop.
wegahta tapes vol. 1 sideshow rap the washington, d.c. rapper burrows further into his subdued sound, creating a vivid panorama of his existence with each deadpan bar.
finally, new they hate change rap the latest album from the tampa duo is a hard rap record made by and for music geeks.
afrikan culture ep shabaka jazz on his debut ep as a solo artist, the jazz musician and composer weaves various wind instruments through eight tracks that thrum with kinetic energy.
hypnos ravyn lenae pop/r&b the 23-year-old chicago singer’s long-awaited debut makes a close study of r&b history, floating through weightless vocal arrangements with uncommon poise.

guitar studies i-iii zimoun experimental this suite of three intricate, hour-long guitar drones from the swiss experimental musician suggests no ends or beginnings, just an unfathomable expanse of immersive sound.

sheryl: music from the feature documentary sheryl crow rock this double-album soundtrack functions like a greatest-hits set, with a focus on the singer-songwriter’s early material and some recent collaborations.
a legacy of rentals craig finn rock on his latest solo collection, the hold steady frontman summons vast emotions from different points along the way to rock bottom.

sunshine factory uffie electronic, pop/r&b bright, noisy, and 10 years in the making, the long-awaited second album from the internet’s original viral pop star leaves little impression beyond smooth-brained confusion.
palaces flume electronic although not without its inspired moments, harley streten’s third lp confirms that he’s most creatively free outside the album format.
the loser gospel rock after more than a decade away, the new york screamo band draws inspiration from keyboard-led, laser-show prog on this challenging and rewarding reunion album.
face the wall jordana rock, folk/country maryland singer-songwriter jordana nye’s bright, gauzy indie pop puts a sharp percussive edge on familiar melancholy.

niineta joe rainey experimental the debut album from the midwestern pow wow singer is arresting and unruly, centering his remarkable voice amid blasts of digital distortion, field recordings, and unrelenting rhythms.
butterfly blue mallrat pop/r&b australian singer-songwriter grace shaw floats between cloud rap and dream pop with the tossed-off affectations of a weary internet princess.

west kensington mary lattimore experimental with 2020’s lockdown measures in place, the los angeles neighbors passed the time playing harp and guitar together. the results capture the melancholy strangeness of those days.
the echoing shell dean spunt experimental, rock the first full-length collaboration between the no age drummer and the harsh noise musician plays like a simmering, abstract hallucination.
harry’s house harry styles pop/r&b harry styles’ melodious third solo album sometimes lacks substance, but style always abounds.

i’m the sky: studio and demo recordings, 1964-1971 norma tanega a new anthology of the ’60s folk singer suggests that she could have been a bigger star, had her label known what to do with her—and had she taken her career as seriously as her independence.

ghetto music eddie gale jazz each sunday, pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. today, we revisit a spiritually charged masterpiece from 1968, a controlled and chaotic blend of free jazz, meditative soul, and gospel.
carry me home mavis staples pop/r&b, rock captured live a year before helm’s death, this reunion of old friends and kindred icons is a testament to perseverance, faith, and mighty backing bands.
eyeye lykke li pop/r&b lykke li’s intimate, ghostly fifth album takes a stripped-down approach to the all-too-familiar devastation of heartbreak.

the zug yves jarvis rock made up of acoustic instrumentation and primitive electronics, the montreal-based psych-folk auteur’s latest navigates a world of discord with wide-eyed optimism and withering wit.
killing nothing boldy james rap the prolific detroit rapper continues his dazzling run with yet another album of detail-rich, tightly-constructed street rap.

nervous at night charlie hickey rock on the latest release from phoebe bridgers’ new label, the california singer-songwriter takes an anxious yet clear-eyed look at the slings and arrows of late adolescence.

preacher’s daughter ethel cain rock on her debut album, the 24-year-old tallahassee native briefly makes good on her instinct for mass-appeal pop anthems, but most of the 76-minute album dwells on roiling gloom and smoldering americana.
entitled hodgy rap the former odd future rapper’s latest solo ep shows his strengths but ultimately loses steam due to his basic bars and formless lyrics.

waterslide, diving board, ladder to the sky porridge radio rock broadening its sound and tightening its lyrical focus, the brighton post-punk band conjures mantras of despair and anthems of pure frustration.
monologues ogi pop/r&b the debut ep from upcoming singer ogi ifediora introduces a gifted vocalist and charismatic performer who’s still finding her feet as a songwriter.
shape up leikeli47 rap the anonymous brooklyn rapper’s third album is a little bolder and a little rawer, but it’s her versatility—across hip-hop, ballroom, house, and r&b—that keeps her sound fresh.
amaryllis / belladonna mary halvorson jazz
communion sister ray rock the edmonton-born, métis singer-songwriter’s debut album is a complex study of webs of interpersonal hurt, and a celebration of emotional survival.

jesus was an alien perel electronic armed with arpeggiated synths, electro-disco drum machines, and some light heresy, the german electronic musician sets her sights on dancefloor provocation, but too often, she’s preaching to the choir.
live a little sam gendel jazz young singer antonia cytrynowicz brings uncanny presence to the jazz composer and saxophonist’s pop-conscious mixture of improvisation and studio overdubs.

so far so good the chainsmokers electronic andrew taggart and alex pall isolate the essential elements of their edm-pop style and cut out everything else, including guest features. the result is easily their most enjoyable front-to-back listen.
deathfame quelle chris rap balancing broad comedy with pointed political satire, the detroit rapper continues his evolution from skilled mc to producer polymath on his latest album.
this is a photograph kevin morby rock the singer-songwriter’s seventh record is a memphis vision quest—an earnest, ambitious collection that touches on family, nostalgia, and mortality.

mr. morale & the big steppers kendrick lamar rap on his fifth album, kendrick retreats from the limelight and turns to himself, highlighting his insecurities and beliefs. it’s ambitious, impressive, and a bit unwieldy.
ama gogela phelimuncasi the south african gqom trio explores the joy and disorder of sensory overload on its vibrant second album.

pc music, vol. 3 various artists six years after vol. 2, the latest label compilation obliterates the notion that there’s any one pc music sound. it’s the work of producers interested in self-expression and the shifting grounds of pop music.

a light for attracting attention the smile rock the debut from thom yorke, jonny greenwood, and drummer tom skinner’s new group is instantly, unmistakably the best album yet by a radiohead side project.
053 tsvi electronic on this introspective collaborative ep, the electronic artists find an uneasy symbiosis of their distinctive styles.

heart on my sleeve ella mai pop/r&b with lush instrumentation and some welcome guest appearances, the follow-up to the uk singer’s breakout debut highlights her sumptuous voice and attention to detail.

un verano sin ti bad bunny rap, pop/r&b much more than a caribbean summer playlist, bad bunny’s latest album is a melodic discourse that questions the powers that be and a call to action that encourages diasporic joy, perreo, and rest.
the last thing left say sue me rock making peace with the passing of their late drummer, the south korean indie rockers lean into their gentler side as they channel noise-pop greats of yore.

eurybia francesca heart despite her new-age leanings, the milan musician refuses to let her music fade into the wallpaper. with a playful, enveloping touch, she makes the most of the genre’s whimsical possibilities.

music from grizzly man richard thompson folk/country with help from jim o’rourke and henry kaiser, the british guitarist supplies the bittersweet backdrop to werner herzog’s 2005 film about humans’ doomed desire to conquer nature.

dance fever florence and the machine pop/r&b florence welch’s pandemic album turns her intensity inward, interrogating her relationship to performance and public image. these are her most personal lyrics, and among her most poignant.
dropout boogie the black keys rock even with the help of outside songwriters and zz top’s billy gibbons, the blues-rock duo can’t help reverting to the same old same old.

breakaway kelly clarkson pop/r&b each sunday, pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. today, we revisit the soaring 2004 album from the first winner, whose earnest charm and everywoman appeal charted a brand new course for pop stars.
3 cheromani+ rap the georgia teenager’s oddball digicore tracks reflect the creative freedom of rap on tiktok. his debut ep opts for a more traditionally hard sound to diminishing returns.
spell 31 ibeyi pop/r&b lisa-kaindé and naomi díaz’s rhythm-forward third album is a syncretic celebration of sounds and traditions that shimmers with color and joy.
how to let go sigrid pop/r&b the norwegian pop singer’s second album never met a problem it couldn’t solve by the first chorus. it’s a feel-good formula of uncomplicated emotions and easy endings.
headful of sugar sunflower bean rock on its latest album, the new york band works hard to sound effortless, hindered by inert performances and unconvincing lyrics.

we’ve been going about this all wrong sharon van etten rock produced in her home studio in los angeles, sharon van etten’s sixth album embraces the complications of the past two years. it is her most epic record, yet lyrically it is her most insular.
blue hours bear’s den rock the british folk duo returns with a heartfelt collection whose polished production belies the emotional complexity of the lyrics.

come home the kids miss you jack harlow rap the charismatic rapper’s second album captures absolutely none of his real-life persona. it is among the most insipid, vacuous statements in recent pop history.

let it be blue !!! rock !!! were always a ray of california sunshine piercing the paranoid gloom of their dance-punk milieu. their ninth album shows how dashingly they’ve ripened into their vintage influences.
pop it don’t stop it johnny cinco rap featuring lightweight lyrics and moody melodies, the latest mixtape from the atlanta rapper is a solid entry point to his revamped style.

no fear of time black star rap the long-awaited sequel to the duo’s classic debut contains bursts of inspired lyricism, but a lack of chemistry and uninspired production make this a disappointing follow-up.
profound morality heriot rock the debut ep from the uk metalcore revivalists is a triumph of concision. whatever you like about the genre, you can find it here.

volcano volcano steven lambke on his seventh solo album, the constantines member trades straight-ahead country rock for joyful, junk-shop irreverence, reveling in his peculiarities while offering an unmistakably homey atmosphere.
we arcade fire rock the band’s sixth album pivots back to a more melodic, sincere, and effortful style, attempting once again to find a genuine connection.

car therapy sessions faye webster folk/country faye webster adds gorgeous orchestral arrangements to songs from her most recent albums, drawing on old hollywood drama to expose the emotion in her words.
murmurations // winds bells falls ben vida experimental
super champon otoboke beaver rock the japanese quartet returns louder, faster, and fiercer, tearing through 18 hilarious and ferocious songs in 20 minutes.

a bit of previous belle and sebastian rock the scottish band’s first studio album in seven years considers the importance of togetherness with clear, aphoristic language and a few musical experiments.
boat songs mj lenderman rock on his breakthrough solo album, the asheville songwriter and guitarist polishes his alt-country vignettes with disarming insight and an immersive, fuzz-stacked sound.

forevernevermore moodymann electronic each sunday, pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. today, we revisit the quintessential release from the detroit producer, a 2000 mix of house and techno that forms a capacious document of the sounds of his city.
cocodrillo turbo action bronson rap the rapper and professional gourmand’s latest album is a hallucinatory, fuzzed-out journey into the wilderness.
alpha games bloc party rock taking cues from their early records, bloc party’s sixth album successfully marries post-punk with dance grooves—and confusingly devotes a lot of its energy to spite.

kumoyo island kikagaku moyo rock on their final album, the japanese psych rockers push beyond the horizons of their previous records. the songs are compact in comparison to their side-long odysseys, but they continually keep you guessing.

endless rooms rolling blackouts coastal fever rock still drawing from the canon of jangly, guitar-centric 1980s college rock, the melbourne band’s latest infuses the easygoing vibe with nuanced political songwriting.
1992 saâda bonaire electronic, pop/r&b a second collection of unheard material from the german new wave band reveals its voguish attempt to transition into the 1990s.
true north caroline spence folk/country on her latest collection of wise, lucid songwriting, the nashville artist brings a sense of depth and directness to her songs.
i never liked you future rap stymied by formulaic collaborations and unmemorable beats, the rapper’s latest has the ingredients of a really good future album but lacks the depth of one.

two ribbons let’s eat grandma pop/r&b retaining all of the light-hearted surreality that made its first two records so bewitching, the uk synth-pop duo makes the sound of grief and joy glimmer on the dancefloor.
julie & dany julie doiron rock on a collaborative album, the canadian indie stalwarts draw inspiration from domestic life during lockdown, penetrating the familiar haze with sharp insight.

lp.8 kelly lee owens electronic collaborating with noise musician lasse marhaug, the welsh producer doubles down on both the spirituality and the mechanical ferocity of her work. it feels both like a left turn and a culmination.

forgiveness girlpool rock the fourth album by the los angeles duo is more sonically adventurous and lyrically direct while still drawing on themes of looking for faith in other people and coming up short.

profound mysteries röyksopp electronic, pop/r&b eight years after bidding farewell to the traditional album format, the norwegian duo returns with a sprawling multimedia project whose best material feels, ironically, like a return to form.

blue water road kehlani pop/r&b kehlani’s most mature and thematically challenging album is steamy and committed, more eager than ever to bet it all on love. they’ve never sounded more comfortable in their own skin.
mahal toro y moi electronic chaz bear’s latest is a loose and lively psych-funk melange—the sound of a one-man band learning how to jam.
limen kmru electronic, experimental ambient musician kmru and experimental producer aho ssan balance tectonic rumbling and grinding steel against whispering white noise and synthetic choirs.
ghosted oren ambarchi experimental, jazz recorded live at stockholm’s studio rymden in late 2018, the trio showcases a carefully stripped-down, psych-jazz sound where the groove reigns supreme.
i don’t know who needs to hear this… tomberlin rock sweeter and more inviting than anything she’s done before, the second-full length by sarah beth tomberlin finds peace in the unraveling.

omnium gatherum king gizzard & the lizard wizard rock dusting off practice-room staples and writing more new songs to go with them, the hyper-prolific aussie rockers scrap their conceptual inclinations in favor of shredding for the sheer pleasure of it.
palomino miranda lambert folk/country the country icon’s latest is a loose concept album about the american road, a scattershot travelogue that houses some of her best-ever songwriting.

throwing muses throwing muses rock each sunday, pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. today, we revisit the essential 1986 debut from the vibrant and visceral rhode island indie rock band, the first american group signed to 4ad.
for you who are the wronged kathryn joseph against soft keys and faint wells of synth, the scottish singer-songwriter’s intense, intimate songs sound like unmediated transpositions of feeling.
gen wo lai (come with me) dama scout nearly five years after their debut, the uk indie rockers return with a cinematic new sound and a determination to turn old hurt into healing catharsis.

唱着那无人问津的歌谣 / chang zhe na wu ren wen jin de ge yao organ tapes experimental the british-chinese musician trades the club tropes of previous albums for unadorned guitars and surreal soundscaping. it’s some of his most emotionally nuanced work yet.

. . . on reflection william basinski experimental, electronic, rock the experimental musicians’ first full-length collaboration gives the impression of life, fertility, and verdancy. it’s one of the most sumptuous works of either artist’s career.

faster than i can take jane inc. rock toronto musician and u.s. girls associate carlyn bezic’s disco meditations and euphoric, mechanical dreamscapes hint at the mysteries of linear time and perception.

void scalping experimental, rock on stage, the bristol quartet combines a dj’s instinct for pacing with a rock band’s penchant for volume. the group’s debut lp strikes a trickier balance between control and abandon.

lady for sale lola kirke rock committing to a bit that isn’t entirely convincing, the actor and singer-songwriter takes performative pleasure in the broke-down love affairs and ritzy sound of 1980s and ’90s country pop.
shunka ryougen haru nemuri blending elements of j-pop, rap, and hardcore, the experimental japanese artist’s latest album presents a convincing balance of nihilism and hope.
don’t wait for a sign jeanines rock the brooklyn indie-pop duo’s second lp plays like the cloud-covered foil to an endless california summer.
192 erica eso rock the new york band takes the downtempo r&b so familiar from mood-based playlists and makes it strange, using microtonal tunings and fretless bass to tweak synth pop’s conventions.
it’s time… to rise from the grave undeath metal zombie armies, mortal standoffs, gravesite robberies: on its ecstatic second album, the rochester metal band has fun with death.

prince daddy & the hyena prince daddy & the hyena the albany emo band takes a big swing with a concept album about the meaning of death, reimagining mall-emo, alt-rock, and pop-punk with a theatrical flourish that all works surprisingly well.
break me open s. carey rock the multi-instrumentalist and songwriter’s latest album is somber and searching, filtering personal vulnerability through his familiar delicate melodies and vocal effects.

cry mfer my idea rock the debut from the experimental indie pop duo of lily konigsberg and nate amos is a textured, intimate, blurry account of being in the throes of a relationship and having it fall apart.

everything perfect is already here claire rousay experimental, electronic the san antonio musician’s longform ambient compositions honor the timeworn strategy of soundtracking imaginary films, but their cinematic expanses have the raw immediacy of status updates.

just like that... bonnie raitt rock six years since her last studio album, the veteran singer-songwriter and slide guitarist returnswith a collection of robust professional rock that may inspire deep dives into her back catalog.

portals kirk hammett metal the first-ever proper side project from a metallica member indulges the guitarist’s cinematic aspirations over sweeping compositions that could accompany zombie westerns or apocalyptic sci-fi.

glass effect ben marc jazz the london multi-instrumentalist and producer’s debut solo lp is subtle and oblique, rejecting the ordering logics of containment by melding house, jazz, classical, and electronic music.
noughty by nature digga d rap the drill rapper sets juvenile joy against the harshest realities that some of the uk’s young people face, encapsulating the stiff push and pull of street violence.
neon blue joshua hedley folk/country the nashville songwriter brings country back to the barroom on a vibrant set that pays tribute to ’90s stars like brooks & dunn and garth brooks.

it’s almost dry pusha t rap the virginia rapper’s latest is musically varied and vocally impressive, revealing an artist who continues to cut extraneous elements out of his songwriting and drill closer to the core of his style.
skinty fia fontaines d.c. rock the irish post-punk band’s most demanding and musically adventurous album is also its most open-hearted, striking a perfect balance between tough and tender.

air sault experimental in a dramatic departure from their previous output, the uk collective taps into the spirituality of choral music and contemporary classical in an uplifting, celebratory, utterly gorgeous album.

revelations: the complete ortf 1970 fondations maeght recordings albert ayler jazz in 1970, just four months before his death, the avant-jazz saxophonist played two concerts to a rapturous crowd in france. a new 5xlp set collects the complete recordings for the first time.
everything was beautiful spiritualized rock j spaceman’s latest opus is gloriously satisfying and self-referential, refining his orchestral space rock with alchemical power.
giving the world away hatchie rock the australian dream-pop artist’s second album widens her sparkly shoegaze into a brasher, more ambitious sound, locating the edge between noise and melody.
solar editions green-house electronic, experimental the los angeles ambient musician returns to the new-age sounds of last year’s , but some of the richness and whimsy of past releases is missing.

the turning year roger eno experimental a frequent collaborator of ambient musicians like laraaji and his brother brian eno, the british composer presents a collection of wistful solo piano pieces shaded by strings.
serenity koloah electronic with soft synth pads and fathomless echo, ukrainian electronic musician dmitriy avksentiev creates a mournful ambient meditation on wartime upheaval.

opening tord gustavsen trio jazz the latest work from the norwegian jazz pianist and composer draws inspiration from classical music and folk songs, but the focus remains on the trio’s delicate and muted interplay.

everything everywhere all at once son lux rock featuring mitski, david byrne, moses sumney, and randy newman, the synth-rock trio’s score for the sprawling action film embraces chaos with an audacious range and unremitting sincerity.

when disaster strikes… busta rhymes rap each sunday, pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. today, we revisit the 1997 album from a hype-man turned mtv star whose kinetic flows and boundless energy electrified the world of ’90s hip-hop.

neurotelepathy dopplereffekt electronic on their first album in five years, drexciya’s gerald donald and his long-time collaborator to-nhan allow their habitually chilly electro to thaw a little, unexpectedly making way for a glimmer of human emotion.

moten/lópez/cleaver fred moten jazz, experimental critic and theorist fred moten joins bassist brandon ​lópez​ and drummer gerald cleaver for a conceptually rich, politically weighty album that asks timeless questions without overexplaining.
bummer year good looks rock on its debut album, the country-influenced austin quartet raises open-ended questions about worry, doubt, and making a living in the gig economy.
luz / quest for fire axel boman electronic

whatever the weather whatever the weather electronic adopting a new alias, uk electronic musician loraine james swaps out jagged beats for ambient textures and sketch-like improvisations mapped to different lines on the thermometer.
learn 2 swim redveil rap the maryland rapper’s latest album soars on a sense of melancholic triumph, ordaining a new star to watch in the process.

everything is alright finn electronic embracing the spirit of simplicity that has long characterized the best house music, the manchester producer’s album knows the transformative power of a lean groove and a catchy sample.

we’re all going to the world’s fair (original motion picture soundtrack) alex g rock both creepy and cozy, the pennsylvania singer-songwriter’s original score amplifies the melancholic beauty that hovers at the edges of director jane schoenbrun’s deeply online horror.

ephemeral camera feed astrid sonne electronic, experimental in a recording from berlin’s atonal festival captured on camera mics in the crowd, the danish electronic musician melds the sanctity of live music with the profanity of eavesdropping on strangers.
tilt confidence man electronic the dance-pop quartet pays tribute to a canon of airhead classics on a fleet-footed record that prioritizes sheer pleasure and fun above all else.

ivory omar apollo pop/r&b the singer-songwriter’s debut expands beyond bedroom r&b to traverse genres with dimension and control. he can shift from wizened soul belter to ’90s boy band innocence in a heartbeat.
harp pendant rock, electronic california musician christopher adams fuses shoegaze, house music, breakbeats, and hip-hop into an ever-morphing sound world as complex and irreducible as grief.
stardust yung lean rap the swedish artist’s new mixtape is the next step in his shedding the mantle of wannabe rapper and fully embracing a more comfortable role as a pop experimentalist.
familia camila cabello pop/r&b camila cabello’s third album embarks on an exploration of her musical heritage while holding onto familiar themes of love and anxiety. she swings big and often hits.

free time jerry paper electronic, experimental on their third album for stones throw, the l.a. avant-pop practitioner juggles themes of identity and physicality with music that reclaims the eccentric aplomb of their early records.
attention: miley live miley cyrus pop/r&b the pop star’s first live album is a collage of miley’s various eras and personas, not all of which have aged well or translate coherently to a live setting.
last ones left 42 dugg rap the fast-rising rappers team for a fun but inconsistent joint album that’s most effective when their verses weave together to feel like one.

(watch my moves) kurt vile rock kurt vile now builds albums the way other artists might compile demo collections. his latest lp conjures images of dreaming and traveling without worrying where they lead.
second nature lucius pop/r&b holly laessig and jess wolfe are skilled harmonists and sought-after collaborators. their latest album searches for its own identity in the neon haze of the dancefloor.

full court press girl talk electronic, rap the former mash-up maker suggests that he could build a second career as a backpack-scale rick rubin, rejuvenating rap veterans by reconnecting them with their most dependable muses.

paradise again swedish house mafia electronic the powerhouse dj trio returns with a sprawling 17-track album and a solid weeknd collaboration, though the forays into menacing, murkier sounds prove less satisfying.

moving pictures (40th anniversary) rush rock in 1981, rush fully transformed from a prog-rock trio to a mainstay of classic rock. a 40th-anniversary reissue of captures the band at their absolute peak.

blood karaoke james krivchenia experimental assembled from samples of unwatched youtube videos, the big thief drummer’s solo album harnesses a harsh and overwhelming torrent of information to convey how the internet skews reality.

ramona park broke my heart vince staples rap the companion piece to his 2021 self-titled record diverges from the innovation and technical proficiency in favor of introspection and contemplation. it is a richly detailed, deadpan elegy for his stolen youth.

wrecking ball emmylou harris rock each sunday, pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. today, we revisit the ambitious and masterful 1995 album from the legendary country singer, one that came at a pivotal moment in her restless life.

at fillmore east the allman brothers band rock each sunday, pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. today, we revisit the 1971 live double-lp from the allman brothers band, a snapshot of a pure and joyous moment in rock’n’roll.
warping all by yourself wet tuna rock the latest from free-folk journeyman matt valentine delves into lysergic funk and psychedelic self-reflection.
rave & roses rema pop/r&b, global on his promising debut, the nigerian star has figured out exactly how he wants to sound, but he hasn’t quite nailed what he wants to say.
aethiopes billy woods rap the rapper’s latest album is a clear mid-career apex that shoves his always outlandish style into territories further afield than ever before.
turn it on! romero rock led by charismatic vocalist alanna oliver, the australian rock band draws on vintage references with enthusiasm and pomp, shooting their songs into the stratosphere.
live at shea stadium desaparecidos rock this 2015 live set at the brooklyn all-ages venue captures conor oberst’s reunited punk band digging into its scrappy, diy roots.
the parts i dread pictoria vark rock summoning the communal energy of a live band, the indie rock songwriter’s debut explores uneasy emotions, anxiety spirals, and perseverance.
b.i.b.l.e. fivio foreign rap the brooklyn rapper’s official debut is focused on creating the type of inoffensive watered-down drill that would make a certain mayor happy.
together duster rock the trio’s second album post-hiatus matches the clarity of its arrangements with an unexpected spiritual lightness. rarely has duster sounded so pleasant and peaceful.
trendsetter coi leray rap the new jersey rapper and singer’s full-length debut is wide-ranging and unfocused—but it never lacks for energy.

the line is a curve kae tempest rap the london-based literary polymath’s fourth album fuses spoken-word poetry with skeletal production, painting a picture of contemporary uk culture in imagistic, intricately wrought verse.
broken hearts club syd pop/r&b syd reshapes heartbreak into pillowy, ’80s-nodding r&b on her second album, softening her sound while maintaining vulnerability in her songwriting.

fear of the dawn jack white rock on his first of two solo albums planned for this year, jack white earns his eccentricity. an illogical fusion of blues-rock and carnival prog, this music is genuinely, imaginatively weird.
oneiric more eaze experimental the austin experimental musician’s grand, romantic ambient album is inspired by dreams’ blissful connotations and cryptic communications.

terror twilight: farewell horizontal pavement rock pavement’s swan song finally gets the full reissue treatment, with various demos, alternate versions, and a new track sequence. it remains a fascinatingly ambivalent note to finish on for one of the most influential indie rock bands of their era.
growing up the linda lindas rock on their debut album, the teen (and pre-teen) punk rockers turn adolescent angst and razor-sharp hooks into heartwarming pop-punk with ample charm.

cash romantic overmono electronic tom and ed russell continue to test various hybrids of techno, uk garage, and for the first time, drum’n’bass, but the ep’s most promising moment looks beyond the dancefloor.
parrhesia animals as leaders metal on their third album as a trio, the prog metal band refines their interplay and finds a sweet spot between technical precision and human flourish.

you belong there daniel rossen experimental with intricate guitar playing, vulnerable songwriting, and a surprising turn toward free-jazz exploration, the grizzly bear multi-instrumentalist reintroduces himself on his full-length solo debut.
en átomos volando ezmeralda electronic using corroded samples and languid tempos, bogotá artist nicolás vallejo casts an eerie and sorrowful light on colombia’s hidden traumas.

bronco orville peck folk/country working with producer jay joyce and nashville session musicians, the masked cult figure adopts the widescreen scale of mainstream country while stretching his eccentricities to their limits.

picnic in the dark renata zeiguer rock, pop/r&b having traded city life for the catskills, the new york artist explores a more relaxed sound on the follow-up to 2018’s , finding new purpose in her soft-focus optimism.

chloë and the next 20th century father john misty rock singer-songwriter josh tillman reaches far, far back to the golden age of hollywood for a dreamy, lushly orchestrated, wryly comic collection of vignettes that all depend upon the timelessness of a love song.
i just want to be a good man pastor champion pop/r&b the debut album from the late oakland pastor is a powerful showcase for his guitar work, his singing, and his ministry.

wet leg wet leg rock the british indie rock duo have hooks stuffed with bait and a keen eye for assessing self-delusion. their debut is the sound of two women stoking mutiny from a slow descent into madness.
777 latto rap the atlanta rapper’s second album asserts her confidence and versatility, rounding out the trap beats with tracks that draw on pop, gospel, and r&b sounds.

leave the light on pillow queens pop/r&b, rock the dublin rock quartet’s second album considers the toll of living up to expectations—romantic, platonic, and societal—with a new gravitas that smothers some of the band’s fire.

mr mixondo dj travella electronic though still suited for delirious outdoor parties, the 19-year-old tanzanian musician’s take on singeli is as much about the spiritual connection between producer and laptop as it is the dancefloor.

quitters christian lee hutson rock with help from phoebe bridgers and conor oberst, the california songwriter tells conversational, painfully precise stories of sad sacks, lost souls, hopeless drunks, and ex-boyfriends.
mainstream sellout machine gun kelly rap the enfant terrible of the pop-rock revival wades deeper into the genre, coming back with even less than before.

the specials the specials rock each sunday, pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. today, we revisit the 1979 debut from the rambunctious and politically charged uk group the specials, a marquee document of the ska revival.

i don’t like you christian alexander pop/r&b on his proper debut, the 24-year-old artist dabbles in generic singer-songwriter pastiche, flattening what made his intimate, solitary music so promising in the first place.
the reve festival 2022 - feel my rhythm red velvet pop/r&b on a new mini-album, the k-pop group known for bold summer hits returns with refined, verdant dance-pop better suited for springtime.
tuqoos julmud the ramallah producer-rapper’s debut is a border-agnostic collection of beats that participates in a global dialogue while retaining a distinctly palestinian identity.
maida vale sessions / microtonics / mother is the milky way broadcast electronic
us ephemeral vitesse x electronic the 100% electronica affiliate channels bits of techo, trance, 2-step, and jungle into contemporary rave hybrids tempered with a hint of vaporwave’s self-awareness.

unlimited love red hot chili peppers rock after more than a decade away, guitarist john frusciante returns for the band’s first album in six years, a restrained and familiar effort to recapture an old spark in a new era.

gold - go forward in the courage of your love alabaster deplume jazz the mancunian saxophonist and poet’s warm and wise album is a balm of spoken word and spiritual jazz, both strangely uncomfortable and strangely comforting.
the unraveling of puptheband pup rock the toronto band returns with a supremely hooky, slightly more polished album about harnessing dread to make music to harness dread to.
i don’t know my words anand wilder the former yeasayer member returns with a refreshingly uninhibited, occasionally undercooked set of 1970s-style singer-songwriter music.
barbara barrie pop/r&b brooklyn’s barrie lindsay makes lush, dance-inflected indie pop whose unorthodox influences and imaginative twists shine brighter than the lyrics.
opening the door jack j electronic the mood hut co-founder’s full-length debut and first release in seven years is a lighthearted collection of deep house, dub, yacht rock, and ambient sketches.

country coming down paul cauthen folk/country on his new set of late-night country disco, the texas singer known as “big velvet” leans into the cartoonish undertones of his booming baritone. he always sounded oversized—now he makes music to match.

i know nigo! nigo rap the japanese fashion designer’s passion project is characteristically stylish and star-studded, featuring contributions from pharrell, kanye west, tyler the creator, and the late pop smoke.
diaspora problems soul glo rock on their groundbreaking new album, the philadelphia hardcore group mixes actionable rhetoric, absurdist humor, and breathtaking vulnerability like no band before them.
american gurl kilo kish pop/r&b the shapeshifting multimedia artist ventures into pop with a concept album that stages arch critiques of art and consumerism within a retro arcade game.
warm chris aldous harding folk/country the new zealand songwriter returns with a sparse and oblique album whose gentle psychedelic folk and beguiling free association proudly resist interpretation.

maxinquaye tricky electronic each sunday, pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. today, we revisit the massive attack associate’s 1995 debut, a gloomy unicorn of contemporary uk pop.
candydrip lucky daye pop/r&b the new orleans singer’s lush, sultry soul-pop goes down almost too easy.
third album kittin electronic, pop/r&b thirteen years after their last album together, the electroclash icons return to their roots.
famously alive guerilla toss rock the trio’s latest is a beautiful mess of squelchy psych-pop—emphasis on pop—where effervescent instrumentals soundtrack an earnest and hard-earned lust for life.
humble quest maren morris the nashville songwriter returns with a comfortable set of country-pop, colored by grief and new motherhood. it feels matter-of-factly masterful.
get wet.radio zelooperz rap with a newfound penchant for slow jams, the detroit rapper’s latest emphasizes his emotional depth, cartoonish humor, and attention to detail.
new preoccupations caracara rock the philly band takes influence from the earnest, unfashionable alt-rock of the 1990s on a moving set about sobriety and freedom.

in february isik kural experimental combining synthesizers, field recordings, nylon-string guitar, and hushed singing, the istanbul-born, glasgow-based musician creates an intimate take on laptop folk.
melt my eyez see your future denzel curry rap the south florida rapper internalizes his skeptical gaze, yielding music that’s more deliberately self-reflective, with few ragers or bangers.
running with the hurricane camp cope rock shifting away from the gnawing, emo-inflected power-pop of their first two albums, the melbourne trio ask: can softness be as invigorating as fury?
sznz: spring weezer rock rivers cuomo toys with renaissance faire shtick on the first of four planned eps inspired by vivaldi’s .
interior monologues asha sheshadri experimental mixing speech and singing, the new york-based sound poet and experimental musician meditates on meaning, context, and impermanence.
gifted koffee pop/r&b breezy, uplifting, and never forced, the jamaican reggae star’s debut imbues the ennui and uncertainty of this epoch with much-needed positivity.
adolescence baynk electronic pushing beyond his playlist origins, the new zealand producer’s debut album revels in eccentric details while adhering to traditional pop structures.

weavings various artists nicolás jaar’s collaborative project for the 2020 unsound festival gathers angel bat dawid, laraaji, senyawa, and a dozen more artists in a pensive, shapeshifting piece of pandemic-era live improvisation.
in/out/in sonic youth rock on these five mostly instrumental recordings from between 2000 and 2010, sonic youth dig in and stretch out.

labyrinthitis destroyer rock dan bejar’s marvelously inscrutable songwriting reaches beyond meaning. on his most live-sounding record in years, he finds clarity when language recedes and the music takes over.
the bear walter martin rock on a bittersweet and impressionistic solo album, the former walkmen member confronts the joys and humiliations of a life devoted to music.
nightclub daydreaming ed schrader’s music beat rock on the baltimore duo’s fourth album, ed schrader and devlin rice trade their formerly frenetic energy for ’80s sounds and danceable beats.
electricity ibibio sound machine global, pop/r&b the london-based ensemble taps hot chip to flesh out the dimensions of its cosmopolitan blend of west african funk and electronic bass music.
kongestion shxcxchcxsh the swedish duo continues to find new ways of mangling techno’s lexicon.

crest bladee rap, pop/r&b, electronic the drain gang collaboration is one of the best projects to come out of the rap and hyperpop-adjacent swedish collective. it’s a softly textured and sweetly spiritual quest for something bigger than ourselves.
in dimes we trust mike dimes rap the san antonio-based rapper rides menacing, three-dimensional beats with steely confidence and creative flows, but he’s most interesting as a storyteller.

recordings from the åland islands jeremiah chiu experimental, electronic with trickles of piano, synth, and viola, the los angeles-based collaborators shape a tranquil vision of a nordic landscape that feels just beyond the edge of reality.

motomami rosalía pop/r&b the spanish superstar’s third album is a showcase for rosalía’s exceptional range. it aspires to stretch itself out across genres and play with form, and attains exactly what it sets out to achieve.
are you happy now? jensen mcrae pop/r&b, rock the singer-songwriter brings a more considered levity to her full-length debut, striking a balance between heartache and resolve.
frank fly anakin rap on his proper debut album, the underground virginia rapper sounds both flashy and laconic, seeming at once like an everyman and cooler than you.
a journey… hinako omori electronic, experimental using field recordings and modular synths, the uk-based electronic musician channels the holistic energies of forest bathing.
forever phife dawg rap the posthumous phife dawg album, a showcase for his dexterous vocal style, reveals what had become most important to the rapper’s life in his post-tribe years.
alpha shenseea pop/r&b blending dancehall with pop-rap, 1980s soul, and 2000s r&b, the jamaican singer’s full-length debut makes a flashy play for the mainstream.

kazemachi roman happy end folk/country, rock each sunday, pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. today, we revisit an overlooked masterpiece from 1971, one that helped define the essence of japanese rock.
plants singing punko pop/r&b on her debut album, the newcastle-via-melbourne songwriter works slowly and methodically, lamenting her past and praying for the future.
eat your food witsmusic pop/r&b, rap though the duo’s joint project feels tethered to tradition, there is something fairly radical about a pair of earnest rap nerds so devoted to the nuts and bolts.

mowing the leaves instead of piling ’em up wednesday rock the asheville indie-rock quintet delivers an album’s worth of covers, revealing their influences via songs by drive-by truckers, smashing pumpkins, and roger miller.
better luck next time. midwxst rap the 18-year-old rapper continues to polish his frenetic breed of pop-trap while maintaining a fundamental weirdness that’s neither too loud nor too discreet.

grindhard e vs ysr gramz grindhard e rap styled like a boxing match until they get bored with the concept and abandon it, the raucous mixtape still proves flint, michigan has another rap duo worth talking about.
hygiene drug church rock the latest album from the chameleonic hardcore band is filled with pithy one-liners and gigantic hooks. mired in anxiety, this music builds intimacy from commiseration.

broken equipment bodega rock the brooklyn punks remain focused on the ceaseless challenges of living in the big city, but their overdriven guitars no longer sound quite as bitter or fed up—particularly when they shift to love songs.

kiren yasuaki shimizu electronic, pop/r&b shimizu’s long career has encompassed jazz fusion, city pop, and the omnivorous experiments of his group mariah. this unreleased 1984 album showcases his electronic work at its most experimental.

good and green again jake xerxes fussell folk/country the folk musician’s latest album is a bittersweet collection full of silence and space. delivered with empathy, his historical subject matter feels rooted in the present.

occam xxv éliane radigue electronic, experimental sustains a single organ drone for nearly 45 minutes, tracing a long, gradual arc of fluttering harmonics and microtonal pulses, sounding as alien as the french composer’s synthesizer work.

sore thumb oso oso rock the long island emo band’s adventurous new album is a document of abstract experiments and stoned afternoons, stranger than their previous work while still buzzing with the pursuit of bliss.
7220 lil durk rap durk’s latest offers some of the best and most honest crooning bars over smooth piano lines, but the formula is starting to wear thin.
dark matters maneka rock on his third album, the former speedy ortiz guitarist continues to carve out space for black perspectives in indie rock while expanding his musical range in surprising ways.

a couple of good days fennec electronic playing fast and loose with his samples, the austin, texas, producer seems to ask: why stick to any one genre or era when you can submit to the decadence of pure vibes?
tana talk 4 benny the butcher rap the buffalo rapper digs deeper into his established lore, savoring his victories while further stewing in past regrets.

skærgårdslyd astrid øster mortensen experimental the denmark-born, sweden-based experimentalist works with humble, home-recorded materials, but the richly expressive dimensions of her 4-track creations transcend their threadbare origins.
crash charli xcx pop/r&b charli’s best full-length project since is a canny embrace of modern and vintage pop styles by one of its most sincere students.
zhigeist elzhi pop/r&b, rap the duo’s collaborative project feels like an interstellar jam session that doesn’t push either of them too far from their comfort zones.
