this world is going to ruin you vein.fm metal the second album from the boston hardcore group is a tentative push toward accessibility, exploding its sound in new directions while nodding to familiar touchstones.
peace places: kenyan memories nyokabi kariũki experimental on her latest ep, the kenyan composer explores concepts of home and memory through a series of melodic sound collages.

the bed is in the ocean karate rock the latest entry in a vital reissue series from numero group lives at the nexus of the boston jazz-rock band’s strange evolution. their daring interplay sounds as if the songs are still being constructed as you listen.

forbidden feelingz nia archives electronic running influences from classic jungle, reggae, and r&b through pop music’s pithy filter, the manchester producer is extending uk hardcore’s legacy to a new generation.

classic objects jenny hval experimental the norwegian artist presents her most unified mind-body work to date, melody-filled art-pop that deals with the nature of self and the freedom of the unconscious.

below the heavens blu & exile rap each sunday, pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. today, we revisit the 2007 debut from the l.a. duo, an enchanting hip-hop classic with an almost mythological history.
it was a home kaina pop/r&b on her soulful second album, chicago singer-songwriter kaina castillo reconciles childhood memories and future dreams with the hard work of getting through today.
keep on with falling the boo radleys rock the english band’s first album in over 20 years lacks the fuel and fire to elevate it from a good britpop record into a great boo radleys record.

mark vi tony price rock armed with a bag full of vintage mixtapes that he discovered in the trunk of a used car, the toronto producer and u.s. girls affiliate whips up a lo-fi tribute to ’80s house, techno, and electro.

dream river henry earnest electronic, experimental the irish musician’s spacious, shapeshifting synth pop submerges acoustic strums and babbling streams into a tender exploration of life’s inherent chaos.
oxy music alex cameron rock the impish artist’s fourth record attempts all of the same tricks that made his music so compelling earlier in his career, but with far less success.
the great regression ditz rock the english punks’ debut is a rage-forward bulldozer of poetic wordplay and experimental hardcore.
squeeze sasami rock sasami ashworth’s second solo album melds two distinctively 1990s sound worlds as it asks: can a song ever make it all the way to another person?

things are great band of horses rock band of horses’ sixth album unexpectedly delivers on all the qualities that defined their initial success: soaring emotions, crunchy guitars, and ben bridwell’s cotton-candy whine.

hunter on the wing k. freund electronic, experimental a member of trouble books, aqueduct ensemble, and lemon quartet, akron’s keith freund combines found sounds, acoustic instruments, and wonky electronics into evocative ambient miniatures.

topical dancer charlotte adigéry experimental, electronic the belgian duo’s debut album pairs punchy, propulsive electro pop with inventive sound design, absurdist wit, and sly jabs at racism and xenophobia.
multitude stromae electronic with biting humor and striking intimacy, the belgian pop singer’s adventurous third album examines how we humans care for one another—or don’t.
invite your eye ilhan ersahin jazz, electronic on their first album as a trio, these jazz-rooted musicians create a luxurious atmosphere drawing from funk, krautrock, and noirish electronica.
sunk babehoven rock a new ep of soft, slowcore music from maya bon and ryan albert arrives like a postscript, elaborating on past themes of grief and accountability with a darker scrawl.
sonescent matchess experimental inspired by a stint in silent meditation, these two sidelong pieces attempt to wrest orchestral order from real-life chaos.

to live & die in space & time lynn avery electronic, experimental, jazz as gentle as cherry blossoms on a spring breeze, the minnesota musicians’ lush compositions for saxophone, piano, and synthesizer convey a wealth of feeling.
trap cake, vol. 2 rauw alejandro pop/r&b, rap the puerto rican singer’s ep is a mix of robot soul and trap beats that sound like he’s just having fun making expensive-sounding records.
growthfully developed chris crack rap crack’s latest album is a delicate balance of fresh and familiar from one of the funniest and most thoughtful rappers working today.

diplo diplo electronic having recently gone through his country, psychedelic pop, and even ambient phases, the omnivorous edm dj turns his attention to house music on his first solo full-length in 18 years.

ghetto gods earthgang rap on their latest album, the atlanta duo paints a more intimate portrait of their city but struggles to personalize their homages. they hit their stride when they speak directly to the people.

only love from now on carmen villain experimental the experimental artist’s latest project is the most dynamic, unpredictable album of her career—a collection of instrumental music that flows like an interconnected suite.
love on my mind bambara rock the brooklyn post-punk band’s latest is a novella-like ep whose shoegaze blur and metallic twang animate a dreamlike world of seedy characters and half-forgotten pasts.

timewave zero blood incantation metal the denver death-metal quartet’s wordless, old-school, analog synth music flips the genre’s atmospheric interstitials into towering showstoppers that invite deep concentration.
painless nilüfer yanya pop/r&b the singer-songwriter’s striking second album excels at a kind of subtle disclosure, relying less on power than it does texture and immaculately sparing detail.
there in spirit homeboy sandman rap the queens native brings a directness and precision to his latest album, an unassuming notebook of observations from a mature rapper with nothing left to prove.

ocean child: songs of yoko ono various artists rock curated by ben gibbard and featuring sharon van etten, david byrne, japanese breakfast and more, this tribute album fares best when the artists match yoko ono’s fearless spirit.
duality luna li rock early in the pandemic, the toronto multi-instrumentalist’s bedroom videos made her a viral sensation. now, her debut album puts a widescreen spin on those whimsical miniatures.
once upon a time romance electronic, experimental the anonymous uk act construct a vast, vaporous tribute to the patron saint of love and heartbreak: céline dion.

get lifted john legend pop/r&b each sunday, pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. today, we revisit the 2004 debut from john legend, one of hip-hop and r&b’s most soulful synergies.

raum tangerine dream electronic on their second album since founding member edgar froese’s death in 2015, the german electronic maestros continue to supersize their signature brand of cosmic synth music.

how is it that i should look at the stars the weather station folk/country performed almost entirely at the piano, the follow-up to tamara lindeman’s 2021 breakthrough raises dizzying questions with sensitivity and quiet hope.

i’m not sorry, i was just being me king hannah rock on its debut album, the uk duo spins deadpan tales about the mundanities of existence over a desolate, desert backdrop recalling pj harvey and nick cave.

i need a job​.​.​.​so i can buy more auto​-​tune swamp dogg pop/r&b on the third album since his justin vernon-assisted 2018 comeback, the mischievous singer heaps on the auto-tune, but his songwriting has more in common with his southern-fried soul of the 1970s.
jupiter’s purse mattie electronic the dallas-based producer and musician sings an ode to the dissected self on their fully-formed debut ep, a metallic amalgam of trip-hop and electronic soul.

forget your own face black dresses electronic the toronto noise-pop duo specialize in harsh music and heavy topics. their latest record can be lighthearted, but the resentment at its heart feels more outwardly pointed than ever.

donda 2 kanye west rap released exclusively on a device called the stem player, the first version of kanye’s 11th album is lackluster and undercooked. it does not bode well for any future updates or revamps.
innervisions stevie wonder pop/r&b today on pitchfork, we are celebrating the artistic bounty of stevie wonder with five new album reviews that span the breadth of his remarkable career.

wild loneliness superchunk rock the indie band’s 12th album uses a moodier, more subdued palette to get to the heart of some fun topics like fear and ambivalence in the face of environmental and societal ruin.
talking book stevie wonder pop/r&b today on pitchfork, we are celebrating the artistic bounty of stevie wonder with five new album reviews that span the breadth of his remarkable career.
regards to the end emily wells the complex, referential new album from the new york-based composer responds to historical crises with sprawling orchestral pop.

the tipping point tears for fears rock the legendary pop duo’s first new album in 18 years approaches the challenges of middle life with familiar sensitivity and shared intimacy. it’s a strikingly unguarded and forthright record.
continuance curren$y rap on their third collaborative project, the duo makes minor but strong tweaks to a reliable system.

flute music james newton jazz, experimental on his 1977 solo debut, the american flutist probes the possibilities of his instrument: multi-tracking it, pairing it with harpsichord, and playing alien, unadorned ellington standards.

caroline caroline rock five years in the making, the uk band’s debut accomplishes something nearly impossible for a largely instrumental post-rock album: to project urgency and timelessness simultaneously.
becoming undone adult. electronic inspired by the grimness of the present moment and grief over a loved one’s death, the detroit electro duo is at the height of its dark powers.

ballad of a tryhard scott hardware rock, electronic accompanied by strings, sax, and piano, the toronto musician sorts through his past on an intimate collection of orchestral pop, bursting with hooks.
god don’t make mistakes conway the machine rap on his most personal project to date, the buffalo rapper laces intimate narratives with battle-ready barbs over an ornate collage of haunting boom-bap.

boundary object gábor lázár electronic recorded in real time and released without further edits, the hungarian musician’s dizzyingly unstable experiments in rhythm and timbre revel in the plasticity of sound.
hotter than july stevie wonder pop/r&b today on pitchfork, we are celebrating the artistic bounty of stevie wonder with five new album reviews that span the breadth of his remarkable career.

angel in realtime. gang of youths rock led by the charismatic dave le’aupepe, the stadium rock quintet’s wildly ambitious third album is intimate in its details but rarely anything other than imax-sized in its proportions.
blurry rip swirl electronic on his debut album, the berlin musician sets aside his techno proclivities in favor of a moody journey into a more innocent era of electronic music.

4 hands hans-joachim roedelius & tim story after decades of making music together, the two friends sit down to an unusual collaboration: a series of duets recorded on a single piano, in alternating takes.
plonk huerco s. experimental on his first album as huerco s. in six years, the kansas musician trades his customary ambient textures for an hour’s worth of intricate, off-center head trips.
up-tight stevie wonder pop/r&b today on pitchfork, we are celebrating the artistic bounty of stevie wonder with five new album reviews that span the breadth of his remarkable career.
a time to love stevie wonder pop/r&b today on pitchfork, we are celebrating the artistic bounty of stevie wonder with five new album reviews that span the breadth of his remarkable career.

limbs keeley forsyth experimental the english musician and actor’s second album places her spectacular vibrato front and center, shadowed by subtle but effective orchestration. listening feels like a bracing walk through winter moorland.

2 alivë yeat rap the 21-year-old portland rapper isn’t doing anything all that new, but he has a refreshing album-focused approach, best listened to as one continuous stream, getting lost in the noisy madness.

everything was forever sea power rock more than two decades into its career, the band formerly known as british sea power sounds newly energized, eagerly plotting new routes to familiar emotional peaks.
starfruit moonchild pop/r&b the trio’s fifth album further smooths out their neo-soul sound while celebrating the voices that inspired them along the way.

sad cities sally shapiro pop/r&b, electronic the semi-anonymous singer has changed her mind about retirement, but almost nothing else. her first album since 2013 sets emotional miniatures to widescreen italo disco and dinner-for-one city pop.

suburban lawns suburban lawns rock each sunday, pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. today, we revisit the 1981 debut from the mysterious los angeles post-punk band, who developed a cult following and vanished just as quickly.
cowboy tears oliver tree pop/r&b back from retirement again, the polarizing, meme-powered pop singer takes up “cowboy emo”: breakup songs with a cartoonish twang and schlocky western aesthetics.

cm10: free game yo gotti rap the memphis rapper takes a well-earned victory lap on the latest edition of his cocaine muzik series, a consistent double album filled with reliable raps and familiar beats.

the long count debit experimental, electronic the chilling and provocative new album from the electroacoustic producer is a work of speculative sonic fiction, reimagining the sounds of ancient mayan musical history.
chain of command wifigawd rap the soundcloud rapper’s latest album offers a natural point of entry to his gripping aesthetic, distilling his virtuosity in a series of distinct, yet successful cuts.
prey//iv alice glass electronic the full-length solo debut from the former crystal castles singer is a dark, extreme pop record about abuse, power, and regaining control.

good morning gorgeous mary j. blige pop/r&b the sheer strength and breadth of mary j. blige’s voice is like comfort food. her 14th studio album mixes soaring, soulful affirmations with some confusing collaborations.
digital roses don’t die big k.r.i.t. rap though the rapper takes questionable creative risks on his fifth album, he’s still capable of bringing scenes to life with a wide eye and a sharp pen.

soundtrack [313] the detroit escalator company electronic gleaming with ambient intent, melodic classicism, and clean lines, this 1996 classic bridges the gap between detroit techno and tangerine dream.

heaux tales, mo’ tales: the deluxe jazmine sullivan pop/r&b on a triumphant deluxe edition of her 2021 opus, the philadelphia singer lays the groundwork for growth with several new songs and interludes, including an appearance from issa rae.
just for you cousin stizz rap on his latest album, the massachusetts rapper recognizes the value of sticking to a formula and gently retooling what works instead of drawing attention to what doesn’t.

blackberry rose lavender country folk/country nearly 50 years after he recorded perhaps the first country album by an openly gay person, seattle folk singer patrick haggerty returns with a follow-up. in all of his songs, he’s equal parts empath and scold, a soft touch with a sharp tongue.
pike vs the automaton pike vs the automaton metal on his first solo album, the sleep and high on fire guitarist hits the garage for a comfortable blend of his signature heavy metal sounds.

bobby weir & wolf bros: live in colorado bob weir rock where dead & company emphasize the grateful dead’s psychedelic spectacle, bob weir’s rootsy trio offers a more intimate reimagining of his former group’s historic countercultural songbook.

once twice melody beach house rock with panoramic proportions and gleaming finishes, the band’s sprawling eighth album luxuriates in the rhapsody of sensation itself. you don’t listen to , you dissolve into it.

harold and maude (original motion picture soundtrack) yusuf / cat stevens rock to celebrate the cult classic’s 50th anniversary, a new collection of cat stevens’ music for the film—including songs later covered by elliott smith and others—finally becomes widely available.

b flat a trupa trupa rock the polish band’s latest shows that they don’t make protest music so much as process music, indulging the ugliest aspects of post-punk and post-hardcore as a means to protect what’s good and beautiful in this world.

life on earth hurray for the riff raff rock alynda segarra’s powerful eighth album exudes a glorious irreverence. their self-described “nature punk” songs are both intimate and immense, and they’ve never sounded more honest or self-possessed.

drive my car - original soundtrack eiko ishibashi pop/r&b the japanese experimental musician’s score for the lauded new film by ryusuke hamaguchi possesses a cool remove, mirroring the film’s glacial profundity with organic nuance and contemplative improvisation.

ngbaka fulu miziki experimental known for elaborate handmade instruments and stage costumes, the veteran congolese eco-punks commit their frenetic, highly collaborative sound to record for the first time.
visitor empath rock the second album from the philadelphia noise-pop band comes with some great new sounds, but dials down some of the thrill and fervor that made their debut so exceptional.
lighten up erin rae folk/country taking influence from the legends of laurel canyon, the nashville songwriter crafts an earnest, tranquil listen that opens up a rich world of detail.

give me the future bastille the pop-rock superstars attempt a concept album about virtual reality that is almost perverse in its inability or unwillingness to develop its premise beyond the most basic and obvious elements.

symbolic death metal each sunday, pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. today, we revisit the 1995 album by the incalculably influential florida death metal band, the most melodic and refined album of their career.

glitch princess yeule pop/r&b the pioneering second album from the avant-pop artist is a darkly nuanced look at identity and technology, where personal disasters occur at the same scale as the actual apocalypse.
disrespectful bad boy chiller crew rap brash, rude, and definitely not sober, the yorkshire bassline trio return with a new mixtape full of soulful house samples and performance-art level idiocy.
lucifer on the sofa spoon rock two decades into their career, spoon return with loud, low-down, melodious rock record almost without sacrificing any of their savory nuance and inscrutability.

asha’s awakening raveena pop/r&b incorporating south asian instruments and singing in english and hindi, the new york singer-songwriter crafts a concept album from the perspective of a punjabi space princess.

badモード hikaru utada electronic, pop/r&b decades into their career, this j-pop superstar continues to evolve—both musically and personally. reads like a friend’s gentle reminder that we’re always coming into our own.
krüller author & punisher metal the san diego artist incorporates a grungy alt-rock influence into his grinding industrial music, revealing a tuneful, human side to his work.

catch me if you can adekunle gold global the nigerian singer has the writing and vocal chops to best most of the leading men of afropop. but his self-proclaimed transformation feels like a talented artist simply conforming to trends.

heterosexuality shamir pop/r&b backed by industrial noise, drum machines, and synths, the philadelphia-based songwriter rages at systems of oppression on a bleak, troubling record of nearly unrelenting hostility.

iré combo chimbita rock the new york-based colombian rock band updates its powerful live chops with careful studio experimentation, balancing psychedelic sounds with a sense of sociopolitical urgency.

where you are teno afrika electronic the south african 23-year-old follows up his scene-sketching debut with this taut eight-track collection of luxurious amapiano designed for the genre’s growing mainstream audience.

dftk yung kayo rap the debut album from the young thug protégé is an exhilarating opening salvo by an artist who only occasionally seems in full control of his considerable talent—which is half the fun.

ants from up there black country, new road experimental, rock the exceptional second album from the london group plays like a slow burn to a triumphant finale. softer and more melodic, the band remains just as challenging and delightfully confounding as ever.

never stop texting me claire rousay experimental, electronic the texas experimentalists set aside their drone and asmr proclivities in favor of auto-tuned riffs on hyperpop, indulging in plenty of deadpan jokes and self-deprecating swagger along the way.
earthling eddie vedder rock the pearl jam leader’s first solo album in over a decade is an amiable, tuneful set with appearances from stevie wonder, ringo starr, and elton john.
shortwave memories biosphere experimental geir jenssen’s return to ambient techno captures him at his frostiest. it’s his largest-scale and most meticulously crafted release in some time.

dragon new warm mountain i believe in you big thief rock big thief’s ambitious yet unburdened fifth album is a 20-song epic of kaleidoscopic invention, striking beauty, and wigged-out humor, rambling far beyond the bounds of their previous work.
w boris metal, rock on the minimalist companion to 2020’s , the japanese trio lands a delicate balance of dream pop and drone. it feels like a sanctuary.

electroacoustic works iannis xenakis experimental the composer’s electronic music dates back to the 1950s yet still sounds radical today. this five-disc box set illustrates the spirit of possibility animating even his most forbidding pieces.
pompeii cate le bon rock cate le bon’s wondrous sixth album exists in a waking dreamscape whose locked-in grooves approach the unknowable at slanted angles.
jp5000 junglepussy rap with killer beat selections and a fresh sense of focus, the new york rapper’s latest project exudes the unnerving calm and clarity that come with years of refinement.

the highest in the land the jazz butcher rock the final album from the mercurial post-punk project offers a wellspring of quotable surrealism, showing the substance and self-definition of the late pat fish.
candid ivy sole rap the philly rapper examines growth and longing with a mature assuredness, imbuing her latest album with moments of modest warmth.
c91 various artists rock modeled after the ’s scene-making compilation, this 59-track collection captures the sound of british alternative rock in 1991, in all its glorious chaos.
daughter raum collaging field recordings and instrumental scraps, grouper and jefre cantu-ledesma construct an elegatic tribute to the life and work of their late friend, filmmaker paul clipson.
few good things saba rap on his latest carefree and careworn album, the chicago rapper turns softer and more melodic, exploring his provisional success and the unanswered questions it keeps raising.
dissolution wave cloakroom rock the indiana shoegaze trio returns with a songs-first, vibes-second concept album that’s both punchy and immersive.

dope don’t sell itself 2 chainz rap the atlanta rapper still has an ear and endless charisma on his latest album, but the songs are more like templates than novel creations. for the first time, he sounds predictable.

junkyard the birthday party rock each sunday, pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. today, we revisit nick cave’s early punk band and their pulpy, lurid, and legendary 1982 album.

let the festivities begin! los bitchos rock produced by franz ferdinand’s alex kapranos, the multi-national group fuses argentine cumbia, peruvian chicha, and turkish psych into a giddy sound that leans unabashedly retro.

time skiffs animal collective experimental after a prolific period of experimentation, animal collective return with an album that achieves a peaceful equilibrium between their immersive 3d soundscaping and innate melodic charms.
laurel hell mitski rock mitski’s sixth album is an austere, nuanced, and disaffected indie-pop record that, in part, addresses her turbulent relationship with her own career.

colors youngboy never broke again rap the prolific rapper continues to push himself to vocal extremes, but his new album seldom coalesces his virtuosity into something that surpasses his signature work.

motordrome mø pop/r&b the danish singer-songwriter’s powerhouse voice can wring genuine catharsis out of even the gaudiest pop, but on her third album, the muted, anonymous production too often holds her back.

round trip: ornette coleman on blue note ornette coleman jazz what happens after you set the world on fire? on six blue note lps following landmark albums and , the mercurial saxophonist endeavored to find out.

old gold a.r. wilson electronic, folk/country world-building takes precedence over the music on this melbourne producer’s concept album, a nuanced retelling of the 1850s victoria gold rush made up of midi banjos and artificial sounds.

nakama steve gunn folk/country collaborators including circuit des yeux’s haley fohr and members of mdou moctar’s band reinterpret the guitar virtuoso’s songs, reinforcing his growing stature as a singer-songwriter.
planet ep squirrel flower rock featuring demos, outtakes, and a quietly powerful björk cover, this ep from the massachusetts songwriter feels like a gentle exhale.
11:11 pinegrove rock the band’s open-armed fifth album looks to make amends, situating our human responsibilities within a natural world no less powerful and vulnerable than we are.
face babyface ray rap the detroit rapper’s world is bleak and flashy in equal measure. on the followup to 2021’s , he’s getting better at balancing his opposing tendencies.
the umbrella again damedot rap steered by his nasally voice and laid-back delivery, one of the original members of team eastside delivers a no-frills, 25-track detroit rap album.
little green house anxious rock the connecticut quintet’s debut is the work of pop-punk professionals, modeled after the genre’s mainstream breakthroughs in the early 2000s.

summer of soul (...or, when the revolution could not be televised) original motion picture soundtrack various artists the soundtrack to questlove’s excellent documentary on the 1969 harlem cultural festival tells a nuanced story of black creativity and perseverance at the end of a transformative decade.

three dimensions deep amber mark pop/r&b the pop-r&b singer’s long-awaited debut follows a line from crippling self-doubt to pure confidence, adopting a glossy and funky vibe fortified by her exceptional voice and songwriting.
anaïs mitchell anaïs mitchell folk/country, pop/r&b on her first album of all-new solo material since 2012, the vermont-based folk singer reflects on her life with measured reverence.

love of plastic shinichi atobe electronic neither arch nor brittle, this is the japanese electronic musician’s most approachable and generous collection to date: “plastic” as in “malleable,” not “artificial.”
shoals palace rock instead of a reinvention, the london band’s latest album jumps at the chance to blend in with every other rock act on the festival circuit.
camo ben bondy experimental the brooklyn producer’s heavily abstracted ambient music offers a choice between deep listening or blissful distraction. it’s equally gratifying either way.
havasu pedro the lion rock david bazan reflects on small-town adolescence with an insular and empathetic album about tedium, disappointment, and simmering tension.
for mccoy eiko ishibashi pop/r&b the japanese multi-instrumentalist enlists jim o’rourke for an unusual fusion of jazz improv, musique concrète, and plaintive pop that pays tribute to ’s jack mccoy.

forever music katie dey electronic on her fifth album, the australian singer-songwriter steps away from the bleak feelings of her early, glitch-scoured work, reflecting this newfound clarity with unadorned arrangements for voice and keys.

the listening little brother rap each sunday, pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. today, we revisit the 2003 debut by the north carolina rap trio, a ridiculously hard throwback album that plugged hip-hop’s golden era into the internet age.
let england shake - demos pj harvey rock the uk musician offers a revealing look at the making of her acclaimed 2011 album —just the latest in a growing series of behind-the-scenes demo collections.

island of noise modern nature rock, experimental jack cooper’s vision as a songwriter and bandleader comes into focus on the most cohesive album of his career: a fantasyland hybrid of elegant folk rock and understated free jazz.

last room waveform* rock the connecticut diy duo struggles to shed their influences on this newly remastered and reissued record, yet they still manage to bring a unique virtuosity and vitality to downcast guitar pop.
fantasy jacques greene electronic the montreal producer sounds liberated on his latest ep, an idealized evocation of the club made up of fleeting breakbeats and ribbony synths.

the runner (original soundtrack) boy harsher electronic on the soundtrack to an imagistic new film project, the darkwave duo’s limited palette verges on claustrophobia. their winning formula hasn’t changed, but the music lacks drive.

gangsta grillz: we set the trends jim jones pop/r&b, rap teaming up with dj drama, the dipset capo wins not by breaking new ground but by alternating between trying existing trends and throwing back to the sounds of his past.
sin miedo tambino pop/r&b, rock brooklyn-based musician kam tambini layers roaring guitars, latin rhythms, and his own low-pitched, sighing vocals to explore the mundanity of city life.
long live young dolph various artists rap on this compilation, artists in young dolph’s circle keep the rapper’s legacy of love and loyalty alive, giving the project a clear sense of purpose.

strictly a one-eyed jack john mellencamp rock featuring several collaborations with bruce springsteen, the self-produced new album from the 70-year-old songwriter is overwhelmingly bleak—but its best moments prove he can still surprise us.
on to better things iann dior pop/r&b the 22-year-old singer fits into a burgeoning pop niche where angsty emo rap, frothy trap-pop, sunny top 40 choruses, and punchy pop-punk riffs congeal.
brightside rich brian rap on an exhilarating but exhausting new ep, the indonesian rapper strives for maturity but remains at his best when he’s at his silliest.
club sentimientos, vol. 2 dj python electronic across three blissfully spaced-out tracks, the new york producer continues to explore the fusion of left-field dance music and reggaetón.

asakusa light soichi terada electronic his career revived by the 2015 anthology , the japanese electronic musician and video-game composer returns to the radiant deep house that won him fans like the late larry levan.

distance on ground martha skye murphy experimental, electronic the collaborative audio-visual project layers maxwell sterling’s double bass and martha skye murphy’s limber soprano with a variety of subtle tones and textures that lure the mind to journey where the body cannot.

tongues tanya tagaq experimental vivifying scenes from her debut novel, the inuk experimentalist and throat-singer marries fiery condemnations of oppression with tender words of protection for future generations.
acrobatic thoughts panoram electronic on his vivid and eccentric new album, the roman-born electronic producer smooths down some of his edges and sinks deeper into an air of wide-eyed rapture.

the intifada 1987 riad awwad global, jazz recorded in jerusalem in 1987, riad awwad’s protest album is part ode to the beauty of homeland, part historical document of palestinian struggle, and part instruction manual for revolution.

storm queen grace cummings folk/country on her self-produced second album, the melbourne folk singer embellishes her stark, bluesy songwriting with symphonic touches that occasionally get in the way of her daring vocal performances.
the boy named if elvis costello rock on his 32nd studio album, elvis costello treats the traditional rock quartet as the ideal medium for delicacy, concision, wit, and the occasional harangue.
dodging dues garcia peoples rock the new jersey sextet’s fifth studio album is an easeful tour of muscular riff-rock, noodly song suites, and curtsying pastoral folk.
from a bird’s eye view cordae rap cordae’s latest album proves he doesn’t have an ethos or a sense of excitement that separates his music from other rappers with a working-class view.
optimism jana horn folk/country with the boiled-down quality of a good short story collection, the debut album from the texas songwriter is cryptic, bewildering, and daringly simple.
age of apathy aoife o’donovan folk/country the irish american singer-songwriter taps into the propulsion of prime joni mitchell: a restless mind bouncing against the blur of one’s surroundings.
the overload yard act rock the leeds band’s mouthy and acerbic take on brexit-era post-punk has the humor, polish, and storytelling of classic britpop.

covers cat power rock featuring songs by frank ocean, lana del rey, nick cave, and more, chan marshall’s third collection of covers is her widest ranging yet, illustrating her talent for radical reinvention.
warmth: retrospective (2016-2021) warmth electronic, experimental this 20-track collection of music by the prolific spanish ambient producer feels like submerging into a warm bath for 95 minutes.
magic nas rap nas is a pointillist, better at writing couplets than albums, and proves he’s still a transcendent rapper when he allows himself to be.
sick! earl sweatshirt rap earl sweatshirt used to make you sift through the mud to find the gold. on his latest album, the nuggets are gleaming right on the surface.
ds4ever gunna rap the atlanta rapper’s latest album is monotonous, short on the quirks and out-of-body experiences of his better projects.

caprisongs fka twigs electronic, pop/r&b the singer’s new mixtape is a playful and adventurous flex, full of errant, shapeshifting compositions that flirt with choral music and afrobeats, schoolyard chants and squeak-rapping.

live at montreux jazz festival anna von hausswolff experimental this ensemble performance from 2018 offers an ideal introduction to the swedish songwriter’s work, showcasing her vocal virtuosity and gothic drama.

wandering pavel milyakov electronic taking influence from drone, metal, and noise, the latest project from the mercurial russian producer is a brooding collaborative album that relishes in its own bleakness.
fragments bonobo electronic, jazz as he evolves to match modern conceptions of chillout music, downtempo producer simon green lands on a sound that’s pleasant, current, and unoriginal.

nick of time bonnie raitt rock each sunday, pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. today, we revisit bonnie raitt’s 1989 blockbuster comeback, a genre-fluid album about love, disappointment, and aging.
nonante-cinq angèle pop/r&b the belgian singer’s second album explores her gift for imbuing joyful, self-possessed dance pop with bittersweet emotion.

archives volume 2: the reprise years (1968-1971) joni mitchell rock spanning the years between her debut and , this 122-song set documents the hard work of exploration, revision, and rejection that shaped the songwriter’s first masterpiece. it is a humanizing wonder.

old dead young: b-sides & rarities broken social scene rock the canadian indie rock band sorts through a largely subdued grab bag of material on this career-spanning set, highlighted by offbeat experiments and homespun, intimate moments.
dawn fm the weeknd pop/r&b conceptualized around listening to a retro-pop radio station in purgatory, abel tesfaye’s fifth album is the most thoughtful, melodic, and revealing project of his career.

carnegie hall 1970 neil young rock a captivating solo performance at manhattan’s most haunted showroom, the latest release in neil young’s ongoing archival project showcases a fascinating pivot point in his career.
wake up lucki lucki rap over synth-heavy beats by the co-founder of philadelphia's working on dying collective, the chicago rapper writes intensely diaristic songs delivered with numb detachment.

4nem chief keef rap almost three years since his last solo project, the 26-year-old rapper continues to reimagine and reinterpret his influences, which is part of what makes his new music feel so alive.

fabriclive.37 caspa electronic each sunday, pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. today, we revisit an infamous 2007 dj mix that helped transform dubstep from a bubbling scene to a global phenomenon.

antidawn burial electronic, experimental burial’s longest release in years doubles down on his signature sounds and downcast mood. a collaged chorus of voices holds together a windswept expanse of undulating nothingness.

sometimes i feel like i have no friends claire rousay experimental, electronic using her customary palette of field recordings, captured conversations, and instrumental contributions from friends, the texas composer lays bare her darkest thoughts about friendship and solitude.

xvi seafoam walls jazz, pop/r&b, rock on its thurston moore-boosted debut, the miami quartet offers an enchanting swirl of indie rock, dream pop, and acid-funk odysseys whose relaxed mood belies a restless philosophical spirit.

a world of service jasss electronic on her debut for berlin’s ostgut ton label, the spanish-born producer trades industrial techno for more unpredictable hybrids drawn from hyperpop, trip-hop, and idm.

breathe suite ep ben marc jazz the london jazz musician’s sprawling suite explores the vital function of breath in times of distress. the music can be tranquil, but it also formally mimics the act of calming down.

the nearer the fountain, more pure the stream flows damon albarn rock initially conceived as an orchestral tribute to iceland’s remote majesty, the blur and gorillaz frontman’s second solo album blossoms into a wide-angle commentary on grief, loss, and climate crisis.
came tran uy duc experimental on his shape-shifting second album, the 18-year-old vietnamese artist wrings beauty out of chaos with fractured, vignette-like compositions.

fiat lux tarta relena experimental drawing on mediterranean folk, georgian laments, and the 12th century mystic hildegard von bingen, the catalan duo’s debut album is musically unique yet emotionally familiar.
dartland worst party ever rock the seattle-based emo band longs for the unattainable with a sense of modesty and restraint that can be as frustrating as it is endearing.

mother of pearl sarah davachi electronic, experimental the los angeles–based musicians explore the spaces between their respective styles, yielding an ethereal, richly textured fusion of neo-classical and musique concréte.
barn neil young rock neil young’s decision to prioritize immediacy over craft in his later years means these tunes arrive lovingly weathered, but rarely go anywhere in particular.

blind date party bill callahan rock, folk/country featuring collaborators from across the drag city universe and a repertoire of gospel, country, pop, and rock covers, bill callahan and bonnie “prince” billy’s lockdown double-album is playful and spirited.
grizzly peak the dodos rock on its warm and reflective new album, the bay area duo offers the most plainly pretty songs of its career. the stakes are high but the mood is anything but tense.

moves: 5 years of culture - afrobeats / rap & drill various artists as uk drill and afrobeats stake their place in the mainstream, london’s moves recordings takes stock of a half-decade of innovations in black british music.

observatory aeon station rock the bittersweet solo debut from kevin whelan—formerly of the wrens—is a rousing, unabashedly sentimental indie rock album that stakes out a sweet spot between the anthemic and the intimate.

wildest dreams majid jordan pop/r&b once again fusing r&b and retro synth pop, the toronto duo’s third album revels in the impermanence of intimacy. the production and singing dazzle, even when the emotions feel hollow.
peace and offerings ep katy b electronic, rock the uk dance star downshifts on her first new collection in five years, embracing smoky, understated r&b with moody arrangements and a flirty touch.
live life fast roddy ricch rap the compton rapper’s second album occasionally showcases the magic he can make, but the music is largely static, a rollercoaster operating on a straight track.

scenic drive khalid pop/r&b with a stacked guest list, the 23-year-old singer’s latest mixtape showcases his curatorial instincts even as it cruises through a familiar landscape of soft, shapeless r&b.

cahoots (50th anniversary edition) the band rock unraveling from the pressure of success and celebrity, the band moved to a new studio in woodstock and made their fourth album, a stiff and scattershot record that is somewhat enlivened by a new reissue.
live from blackalachia moses sumney rock recorded in the blue ridge mountains with a seven-piece band, moses sumney’s first live album and film find freedom and beauty in the isolation of the forest.
from the bayou youngboy never broke again rap, pop/r&b birdman’s presence is largely intrusive on the pair’s joint project. it’s youngboy’s versatility that keeps the album afloat.
forfolks jeff parker jazz on his new solo album, the tortoise guitarist blends loops and improvisations in dazzling ways. it sounds like jazz but moves like a soft techno dream.

neuromantic yukihiro takahashi rock reissued on vinyl for the first time in four decades, the yellow magic orchestra drummer and vocalist’s 1981 solo album isolates his infectious hooks, powerful rhythms, and modern pop sensibility.

broken hearts & dirty windows: songs of john prine, vol. 2 various artists a second installment of john prine covers includes some of the legendary songwriter’s best-known material, illustrating how his legacy—and the definition of americana—has shifted since 2010.
stars ryan pollie rock with richly textured psychedelic folk music, the los angeles artist draws complex emotions out of simple love songs.

live in brighton 1975 can experimental the second album in mute’s planned series of archival can shows captures a group figuring things out in real time. after 30 tentative minutes, things turn transcendent.

resident alien spacehog rock each sunday, pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. today, we revisit spacehog’s 1995 debut, an architecturally sound, occasionally great, always amusing collection of transatlantic power pop.
fighting demons juice wrld rap juice wrld’s second posthumous album attempts to be more of the same, highlighting the best and worst qualities of a generational talent gone too soon.
richer than i ever been rick ross rap the miami rapper is still bringing you into his world of opulence and hustlers’ theme music, but the view is more refined.
balens cho mach-hommy rap the new jersey rapper makes haiti the main character of his latest project, balancing social context with a sense of intimacy and urgency.
concrete martha skye murphy experimental using sparse language and baroque instrumentation, the london artist explores captivity and control over this spectral three song ep.

embryo ep jlin electronic this grimy new ep from the gary, indiana producer has the unfinished edge of a sketch, pointing toward the dancefloor while showcasing her twin forces of invincibility and vulnerability.
big sleepover big boi rap shrewd beat choices (and killer mike) liven up a lopsided collaboration between two longtime dungeon family members who still share undeniable chemistry.

juju music king sunny adé global each sunday, pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. today, we revisit nigerian superstar king sunny adé’s 1982 international breakthrough, an album whose complex fusion of musical traditions produced a singularly captivating groove.

old friends new friends nils frahm electronic collecting 12 years of solo piano recordings, the berlin composer explores some of his quietest, most intimate material yet, in which the creaking of the pedal is often as audible as the notes.
romeo sega bodega electronic on his second album, the london producer summons the divine with intoxicating, emotional dance music fit for a crowded warehouse.

the time of foxgloves michael hurley folk/country as he approaches his eightieth year, the veteran folk craftsman embraces good times and creature comforts on a collection of homespun tunes that radiates his familiar charm and insight.
brilliant adventure (1992-2001) david bowie rock

der lange marsch gas electronic wolfgang voigt treats the seventh album from his beloved ambient techno moniker like a retrospective, filtering familiar tropes into a comforting pulse. but a disturbing hint of tinnitus lurks in the margins.

wave your moonlight hat for the snowfall train you’ll never get to heaven electronic the ambient dream-pop duo’s fourth album is split between fragile vocal meditations and instrumentals as delicate as origami cranes.
cong! cong josie rock nic oogjes’ lounge-lizard alter ego makes heady, gleefully ridiculous no wave pastiche held together by flamboyance and a predilection for showmanship.

i want to see the bright lights tonight richard and linda thompson rock each sunday, pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. today, we revisit the folk-rock duo's darkly holistic 1974 debut, a quixotic blend of the old and the new.

the romance of affliction seeyouspacecowboy metal borrowing the clean hooks of metalcore and scene-chewing flourishes of myspace emo, the san diego band’s second album takes an unflinchingly honest look at impending doom.
foreign exchange rx papi rap, electronic the duo offers a tight, cohesive project that binds gud’s experienced pop precision with papi’s uncontrolled intensity.

tide turns eternal dream unending metal on their lush, formidable debut, the “dream-doom” duo of tomb mold’s derrick vella and innumerable forms’ justin detore illustrate how emotionally boundless metal can be.
peace meter marissa paternoster rock on her debut solo album under her own name, the screaming females frontperson reintroduces herself, placing the focus on her remarkable singing voice.

julius eastman, vol. 1: femenine wild up experimental for the first installment of its proposed seven-album anthology of the late composer’s work, the california collective breathes new life into his ecstatic minimalist masterpiece.
kick ii / kick iii / kick iiii / kick iiiii arca experimental
rap? tierra whack rap the philadelphia rapper’s new ep may be more straightforward than usual, but even at her most conventional, whack is at least attempting to keep you off-balance.

it’s all smiles no rome pop/r&b on his full-length debut, the 24-year-old singer’s chameleonic tenor pierces through the dirty hit template and finds a natural fit in pouty pop-rock and gauzy trip-hop.

fabric presents sherelle sherelle electronic cruising at her habitual 160 beats per minute, the rising london dj mixes old-school jungle techno, acid rave, breakbeat hardcore, and footwork into an exhilarating 75-minute set.

all these years phil cook rock on these solo piano performances, the musician known for his work with justin vernon, hiss golden messenger, and more suggests that peaceful solitude can offer its own high.
open arms to open us ben lamar gay jazz the chicago multi-instrumentalist and composer’s second album crisscrosses genres and eras, sprawling in its ambition and surprisingly precise in its attack.
are you happy ep nnamdï experimental, rap collaborating with producer lynyn, the chameleonic chicago musician offers a toned-down vision of his exuberant experimental pop.

spencer (original motion picture soundtrack) jonny greenwood experimental the alternately beautiful and unnerving score to pablo larraín’s surreal film about princess diana captures the elegance of a royal holiday and the horror of feeling trapped inside of it.
queen of my world bat fangs rock the second album from guitarist betsy wright and drummer laura king revels in a good time, backing up their bite with instrumental brawn.

the sacrifice ep flora yin-wong electronic, experimental armed with field recordings and ancient folklore, the peripatetic electronic musician pauses to construct a resonant, mysterious portrait of the rugged welsh landscape.

ascension codes cynic jazz, metal following the deaths of two core members, the pioneering florida metal band searches for celestial answers to earthly woes. dense and visceral, it’s as close to a return-to-form as they’ve ever made.

the light-emitting diamond cutter scriptures r.a.p. ferreira rap ferreira’s latest album is rich and rewarding, the mark of a prolific artist arriving at the perfect unity between content and presentation.

ocean to ocean tori amos rock on her 16th album, begun early this year as the uk entered its third lockdown, the cornwall-based singer-songwriter grapples with personal loss, the cruelty of the world, and the will to keep going.
switched on ra bitchin bajas experimental after covering sun ra on 2017’s , the chicago trio fires up a passel of arcane vintage synths and interprets eight more songs by the cosmic jazz legend.

tell me what you miss the most tasha pop/r&b on her hushed second album, the chicago artist writes minimal, unpredictable songs that explore the in-between states of relationships with subtlety and grace.
giant + guitar omar khorshid a new reissue of the egyptian guitarist’s 1974 breakthrough showcases his virtuosic playing and groundbreaking blend of styles.
water lotic electronic after the comparatively bleak experimental club sounds of 2018’s , the berlin-based texan producer embraces the warmth and intimacy of slow-paced r&b, sounding newly at ease.

woke up right handed ep blawan electronic delivering his most interesting work in years, the uk techno producer throws convention to the winds while indulging a dark sense of humor that feeds off the preposterous and the grotesque.

henki richard dawson folk/country, rock the eccentric english songwriter and the prolific finnish rock group collaborate for an album that routes ancient plant life into deeply human stories of toil, tragedy, and the afterlife.
deciphering the message makaya mccraven jazz on his latest project, the jazz drummer and innovative producer brings the heart of the famous blue note catalog into the present.

soaked in indigo moonlight parris electronic long known for his dusty, slow-motion take on uk bass, the london producer makes a surprising turn toward pop on his debut album, without stifling any of his experimental instincts.

body/dilloway/head body/dilloway/head rock, experimental kim gordon and bill nace’s guitar duo collides with noise icon aaron dilloway’s inscrutable electronic methods, resulting in a thrilling mutation of all three artists’ signature sounds.

voyage to mars munya pop/r&b josianne boivin’s full-length debut gestures toward space opera, but her lonely disco and lo-fi aesthetic are better suited for sleepy introspection about your place on earth.

the power of the dog (music from the netflix film) jonny greenwood experimental like his scores for paul thomas anderson, the radiohead guitarist’s soundtrack to jane campion’s new film invokes the 20th-century avant-garde, full of noble brooding and tormented ecstasy.
buds ovlov rock for all their slacker-rock credentials, the connecticut group could rarely be described as loose. their third album is a short, hooky celebration of friendship and fuzz pedals.

dj-kicks jessy lanza pop/r&b balancing contemporary house and techno with detours into footwork, gqom, and more, the canadian musician’s mix reveals the range of influences behind her own singular brand of synth pop.

i thought of you julie doiron rock on the first new album under her own name since 2012, the canadian songwriter makes her voice the focus. her songs feel instantly familiar, like smaller pieces of a timeless story.
at my piano brian wilson rock featuring instrumental renditions of many of the beach boys’ greatest hits, this collection of solo piano performances feels disappointingly bare and anonymous.

diana diana ross pop/r&b each sunday, pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. today, we revisit a landmark disco and pop album, a dazzling and fabulous collaboration between chic and diana ross.

the clearing jjjjjerome ellis electronic the new york experimental musician takes his own stutter as the starting point for an album that is both a theoretical investigation of speech dysfluency and a piece of resistance art.
windswept adan ichiko aoba experimental released last year, this ambitious album by the japanese singer-songwriter utilizes lush instrumentation to create a dreamlike soundtrack to an imaginary film.
blacklight apollo brown rap a solid serving of meat-and-potatoes rap, the duo’s first full-length joint project thrives on a sense of comfort and familiarity more often than not.

reporting live (from the back of the roads) backroad gee rap the british-congolese rapper’s ambitious new mixtape proves there’s fertile ground to be found in the interplay between grime, uk drill, and velvety afropop.
monument portico quartet jazz on its second album of 2021, the london group fastidiously projects electronic music, pop, and jazz through the twin prisms of post-rock and classical minimalism.

30 adele pop/r&b once again, adele transforms her heartbreak into a searching, graceful, and incredibly moving album. but the complexity of her emotions and the nuanced production make this her most ambitious work to date.

another side leo nocentelli rock recorded in 1971, the lost solo album by the meters’ guitarist plays like a document of what happened, and also what could have happened—a heart-on-your-sleeve acoustic career from a funk icon whose feelings always seemed to be hidden in his riffs.

frailty jane remover experimental, pop/r&b the official debut from the young digicore producer and songwriter is riveting, a shapeshifting emo-electronic record that sounds like new worlds seeping out of a digital abyss.
... ep mandy, indiana experimental equally indebted to no wave and dance, the manchester, england-based trio’s debut ep walks a fine line between violent and groovy.

bloodmoon: i converge metal after 30 years together, the hardcore dynamos hit a nadir. their collaborative album with chelsea wolfe and stephen brodsky is exhausting and predictable, a ceaseless barrage of the banal.

the legendary 1979 no nukes concerts bruce springsteen rock with a setlist structured like a party, this new concert film and live album from a charity gig at madison square garden showcase bruce and the band at full roar.

mp da last don master p rap each sunday, pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. today, we revisit the gem of no limit records, one that’s as much a flex of power as it is a musical triumph.

crawler idles rock exploring personal subject matter and wider musical terrain, the bristol band’s fourth album plays like the dark origin story for how idles became the preeminent life coaches of modern post-punk.
madison sloppy jane rock recording deep underground in a west virginia cave, haley dahl creates vivid, ambitious chamber pop with a flair for the grotesque.

music for psychedelic therapy jon hopkins electronic inspired by an expedition into ecuador’s ancient caves, the vaunted techno producer presents an immersive ambient album designed to accompany guided trips.
twopointfive aminé rap the portland rapper’s buoyant new project sounds like a controlled sugar rush, folding elements of pop and dance into his bright raps.

open the gates irreversible entanglements jazz on their latest album, the free jazz collective expands their palette to great effect, channeling the hopes of the past to demand liberation in the present.

the death of speedy ortiz & cop kicker...forever speedy ortiz rock in addition to eight previously unreleased songs, this double lp remixes and remasters two early albums born from the macabre, witty, and wonderful mind of sadie dupuis.

deacon’s grove ep serpentwithfeet pop/r&b the experimental r&b artist tempers the ecstatic joy of his latest album with a breezy companion ep, offering subtle updates on its plainspoken songs of love and friendship.
an evening with silk sonic bruno mars pop/r&b bruno mars and anderson .paak’s faithful and loving ode to ’70s r&b has a distinctly light touch, which works both for and against the project.

son rosie lowe pop/r&b, experimental collaborating with rosie lowe, london-based multidisciplinary artist duval timothy translates his chordal sensibility to a short but expansive choral suite where sound means more than words.
al mundo azul mr twin sister pop/r&b the new york city quartet’s fourth album is classic and romantic, capturing the liberated frisson of disco and house in an ultra-saturated palette.
för allting makthaverskan rock on its adventurous new album, the gothenburg quintet expands on its pitch-perfect blend of post-punk, jangle pop, and shoegaze.

raise the roof robert plant rock, folk/country fourteen years after their first collaboration, the unlikely duo reunites for a well-curated selection of covers that spans generations, while adding their fascinating mystique to every one.

red (taylor’s version) taylor swift pop/r&b re-recorded in meticulous detail, along with a dozen songs cut from the 2012 original, taylor swift’s most pivotal album has still more to say about growing up and moving forward.

why look up, god’s in the mirror lukah rap a synthesis of outerborough album rap, five-percenter ideology, and southern gothic interiority, the memphis native’s latest album is a somber reflection on the place that made him.
a way forward nation of language rock the second album from the brooklyn synth-pop revivalists explores a broader emotional palette while hitting familiar pleasure points.
garbology aesop rock rap backed by blockhead’s spare production, the long island-bred rapper continues his creative evolution, writing more incisively about himself than ever before.
engine of hell emma ruth rundle rock with sparse acoustic arrangements and cryptic lyrics, the songwriter’s fifth solo album feels like a series of intimate dispatches from a personal purgatory.

silk degrees boz scaggs rock each sunday, pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. today, we revisit boz scaggs’ 1976 hit album, a record whose ineffable tragicomedy called for its own system of measurement.
in virus times ep lee ranaldo experimental, rock a brief ep from the sonic youth guitarist features ruminative, unadorned acoustic performances that convey a sense of anxiety and perseverance.
slave to the scalpel 200 stab wounds metal with a pitch-black sense of humor, the cleveland death metal quartet boils the genre down to its essence but lands just shy of its potential.

doran doran folk/country recorded in a virginia mountain town named rural retreat, the debut from this quartet of fringe-folk veterans beautifully articulates the weirdness and magic of life outside of the city.
yellow tape 2 key glock rap the sequel to the memphis rapper’s 2020 tape embodies the spirit of southern rap without trading in nostalgic aesthetics or noticeable samples.

rhythm and paranoia: the best of bush tetras bush tetras rock this 3xlp box set surveys the influential new york group’s long career, reinforcing their post-punk bona fides and tracing their evolution over the course of four decades.

on the edge mmm electronic the berlin-based duo of errorsmith and fiedel push toward the extreme lower limits of danceability on a debut lp that’s stranger, woozier, and slower than anything they’ve made before.

things take time, take time courtney barnett rock the australian singer-songwriter’s fourth album has the directness of a collection of demos. barnett sounds characteristically laconic; she’s at her best when she lets her guitar take the lead.

both feet en th infinite model home experimental, rap isolating the rhythm at the center of their work and tapping into a new physicality, the washington, d.c. experimental duo find joy in improvisation and liberation in the body.
vi/deo xeno & oaklander electronic liz wendelbo and sean mcbride remain committed to their tactile brand of minimal synth with a set of nostalgic rhapsodies that embrace a newfound warmth.

9 airs leif electronic the welsh electronic musician continues his run of home-listening albums with a quiet, unassuming record that splits the difference between low-key dance music and ethereal ambient.

thank you diana ross pop/r&b the singer’s first album in 15 years casts a fond glance back at the vintage sounds she made her name with, but a few new songs—including a jack antonoff production—bring her back to the present day.

still over it summer walker pop/r&b with her latest album, the singer cements herself as one of r&b’s most relatable storytellers, with an ear for melodrama that becomes monotonous. the best moments capture her soulfulness alongside her fury.

lee “scratch” perry’s guide to the universe new age doom experimental, global in one of his final recorded appearances, the late dub visionary trades the mixing desk for the mic on an album fusing parallel strains of heavy, psychedelic music.

christfucker portrayal of guilt rock channeling slasher flicks and dante’s , the austin band’s second album of 2021 is a roiling cauldron of scorched-earth sludge and hardcore that doesn’t take itself too seriously.
pluperfect mind dear laika experimental exploring the concept of “queer time,” classically trained musician isabelle thorn crafts a prodigiously ambitious, suite-like album that never quite rests.

valentine snail mail rock lindsey jordan’s exquisite second album documents love in all stages, but mostly in disrepair. she takes on a larger and poppier sound while keeping her songwriting dazzlingly sharp and passionate.

make drunk cool again rxk nephew rap while the rapper’s latest of multiple releases this year is too scattershot to sustain itself as a project, he’s landing more darts on the board than usual, and it’s fun to hear him experiment.
public storage hana vu pop/r&b the los angeles singer and songwriter’s full-length debut is grandiose and opaque, opting for intricacy over intimacy.
zigzag wombat foyer red rock the brooklyn art rock trio’s choppy harmonies and sweetly free-associative tunes are a little bit freaky and more than a little bit funny.

rhinestones htrk experimental, rock over the past decade, the melbourne group’s music has grown lighter, gentler, and more inviting with every release. here, they trade their minimal-wave roots for unexpected forays into gothic country.

kid a mnesia radiohead rock at the turn of the century, radiohead released two albums that forever altered their identity. now, and are reissued as a pair, along with whatever worthy b-sides, alternate versions, and outtakes they can find.
arm’s length ep leo bhanji the london producer’s second ep of the year is a nebulous collage of lo-fi r&b, hip-hop, and electronic. it feels like a sketchbook of ideas in search of their final forms.

raw demoon alchemy (a lone operation) darius jones jazz the new york saxophonist’s breakup album subverts what we’ve come to expect from the genre. covering songs by ornette coleman, sun ra, and others, he finds new emotions in familiar songs.
preserved in torment mortiferum metal on the olympia death/doom band’s unrelenting second album, everything sounds beefier. this music grabs you by the shoulders and shakes you to attention.

inglish shubh saran jazz with an ambitious fusion of hindustani classical, progressive rock, and jazz, the new york-based guitarist and composer offers an expansive, egalitarian vision of identity and belonging.

new adventures in hi-fi (25th anniversary edition) r.e.m. rock r.e.m.’s most unstable album never quite arrives in any one sound for more than a track at a time. born of a chaotic and stressful tour, it translated not only the energy of their shows but the transience and unreality of life on the road.

voyage abba pop/r&b returning with their first new album in 40 years, the swedish pop titans attempt the seemingly impossible: balancing the lure of nostalgia with the pull of the present day. amazingly, they pull it off.

hyd ep hyd pop/r&b once best known best as the cryptic pc music character qt, hayden dunham returns with an updated electro-pop sound that strips away some of the artifice from their previous project.
elephant in the room mick jenkins rap the fiercely ambitious chicago rapper turns in a scattered, familiar collection, ditching the epic scope of his past releases and sticking to what works.
house of confusion trace mountains rock on his latest album of country-influenced indie rock, dave benton takes surprising, subtle turns in songs of indecision, introspection, and alienation.
absolutely dijon pop/r&b the roaming, americana-obsessed songwriter brings a sense of purpose to his zigzagging on his debut album, a collaborator-filled collection of heartbreak tales.

women in technology white town rock each sunday, pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. today, we revisit jyoti mishra’s 1997 major-label debut, a collection of tender homemade synth-pop that spawned an unlikely global hit.
projector geese rock with impressive performances and a few promising moments, the young brooklyn post-punk band clearly knows all the right moves—but it’s hard to tell what moves them.

reticence / resistance pelt experimental, rock recorded over two nights at london’s café oto in 2017, this live performance from the group showcases the band’s unique ability to fuse folk traditionalism with drone experimentation.
mandatory enjoyment dummy rock the los angeles band nods to various corners of psychedelic music while transcending its influences on this blissful and spacious debut album.

lily we need to talk now lily konigsberg rock on her debut album, the new york polymath roams free across a map of the last 50 years of contemporary pop music, leading to her most accessible and purposeful record to date.
soul controller ak bandamont rap highlighting a new corner of michigan rap, this mixtape from the grand rapids rapper is a sustained rush of adrenaline that rarely loses steam.

= ed sheeran pop/r&b ed sheeran is older now; he’s married and newly a father. with all this change comes a new set of trite observations about love, life, and partying amid anonymous and synthetic pop music.
pohorylle margo cilker folk/country the debut album from the pacific northwest country songwriter showcases her distinct personality with vivid lyrics and lovely, thoughtful arrangements.

i don’t live here anymore the war on drugs rock the fifth album from adam granduciel and co. chips away some of their hazier edges in favor of sharper melodies, broadening the borders of the meticulous yet joyously simple sound he has perfected.

the path of the clouds marissa nadler folk/country inspired by true crime and accompanied by mary lattimore, emma ruth rundle, and others, the gothic songwriter’s latest feels newly textured and symphonic.
candy racer kyary pamyu pamyu pop/r&b the j-pop icon and hyperpop predecessor returns with an album that looks forward even as it longs for an imagined past.
something for thee hotties megan thee stallion rap with her latest batch of unreleased freestyles and loosies, the houston rapper reminds the world that breathless raps are her foundation.

extropy markus guentner electronic, experimental on the third album of an astronomically-inspired trilogy, the german producer suspends lonely, isolated instruments within a sweeping cosmos. it sounds appropriately epic and a little vacant.
petunia tonstartssbandht rock with a newfound sense of melancholy, the florida jam duo has crafted its tightest studio album without losing the ambling spirit that fuels its live performances.

come on over shania twain folk/country each sunday, pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. today, we revisit shania twain’s 1997 blockbuster, one that showed the world the power of a true pop-country crossover.

im hole aya electronic the boundless debut from the london-based artist is a delirious tug of war between pleasure and unease, shuttling between club sounds and psychedelic mind states with a steely, unbridled intensity.
intra-i theon cross jazz inviting guest vocalists into his fold for the first time, the london tuba player delivers a collection of taut pop songs deeply rooted in afro-caribbean soundsystem culture.
love black bktherula rap the atlanta rapper’s new album swings seamlessly from upbeat to disruptive without being one-note. it’s her best work yet.
lp! jpegmafia rap though just as charged and confrontational as any of his other projects, the rapper’s latest album is uninhibited and proud of it.

collected pieces ii mary lattimore experimental a companion piece to last year’s sparkling , the harpist’s latest dip into her archives assembles improvised sessions into intricately layered songs with a powerful emotional pull.

b-sides & rarities (part ii) nick cave & the bad seeds rock culled from a period of intense musical transition over the past decade-plus, these 27 songs offer an alternate window into the songwriter’s depravity and anxiety—and the quest to overcome both.
hushed and grim mastodon metal the atlanta metal band’s new double album is its least ambitious collection yet: an inoffensive, occasionally alluring, but overwhelmingly dull 90-minute slog.

far in helado negro electronic the follow-up to 2019’s is mellower and breezier than its predecessor; it feels less like a tour of roberto carlos lange’s psyche than an afternoon barbecue in his backyard.
-io circuit des yeux rock accompanied by strings, horns, and more, haley fohr has crafted her most expansive work to date, capturing a sprawl of emotions too complicated to be named.
crossover ep dua saleh pop/r&b transforming their past solemnity into swaggering confidence, the minneapolis-based singer-songwriter and rapper returns with an ep of thunderous club music.

actually, you can deerhoof experimental through a collection of songs that range from anxious garage funk to mercurial power pop, the san francisco experimentalists argue for an urgent remaking of the world.
fun house hand habits rock with stark, introspective lyrics and fuller production, meg duffy’s latest is a bold foray into poppier sounds. it feels like a fresh start.

is it time to eat the rich yet? the f16s rock the chennai quartet are indie-rock revival survivors making an overdue play for international recognition. their latest ep is packed with sunlit synths, neon grooves, and upbeat pop melodies.

my morning jacket my morning jacket rock concentrating hours of freeform takes into the baggy shape of 11 songs, my morning jacket’s ninth lp achieves the dubious goal of nailing a “jam band album” on the first try.

a love supreme: live in seattle john coltrane jazz a previously unknown recording from a small seattle club in 1965 documents one of the saxophonist’s signature works—spiritual, searching, unstoppable—as never heard before.

quivering in time eris drew electronic born of impromptu dj sets broadcast from a forest clearing in new hampshire, drew’s latest album distills decades of dance-music history into an hour of joyous new standards.

lull jessica pavone jazz writing for string octet plus soloists nate wooley and brian chase, the new york composer’s work is rooted in the ways that sound absorbed by the body can both reflect and influence emotional states.

source ⧺ we move nubya garcia jazz drawing on uk dance music, experimental r&b, and hip-hop, this remix album to the london saxophonist’s kaleidoscopic jazz record expands on the eclectic universe of the original.

big bend (an original soundtrack for public television) explosions in the sky rock on its first soundtrack in seven years, the texas band mirrors the subtle landscape and beauty of the national park that the namesake documentary captures.

shade grouper experimental recorded over the last 15 years, and alternating between stripped-down folk and thickets of distortion, takes grouper’s careful balance between intimacy and inscrutability to a new extreme.

a tear in the fabric of life knocked loose metal citing death metal and phil spector as influences, the kentucky metalcore band turn in an absurdly heavy ep that tells an even heavier story about death and grief.

sympathy for life parquet courts rock with sincere, resolute songwriting and a more accessible sound, the latest album from the new york quartet feels more suited than ever for the ecstasy of a crowded club.

dj-kicks disclosure electronic on their first official mix album, the lawrence brothers broaden their horizons, focusing on a selection of classic-sounding house. it’s a far more intimate vibe than their festival-stage fare.

chameleon anthony naples electronic on his first album in two years, the new york producer applies an exploratory approach to ambient techno, utilizing elements of dub and post-punk to sculpt a record that feels meditative but never maudlin.

simple, sweet, and smiling kacy hill pop/r&b the los angeles singer-songwriter’s charming third album is full of recurring worries, but her nods to ’80s synth pop and adult contemporary imbue the music with a sense of lightness.

heartbeats uniiqu3 electronic the breakout star of the regional subgenre known as jersey club harnesses its familiar driving grooves and libidinal energy while pushing the style forward with new sounds and moods.

punk young thug rap while young thug’s creative choices after about 2015 have had little sway over emerging trends, suggests that the space he now occupies is one that allows him more room to experiment.
fast idol black marble rock chris stewart continues his decade-long quest to rewrite ’80s synth-pop on his latest record, an enjoyable homage that struggles to reach the heights of its influences.
blue banisters lana del rey pop/r&b lana del rey’s second album of the year is a sweeping survey of her talent as a songwriter, stripped of the aesthetic borders she often places around her work.

combat rock the clash rock each sunday, pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. today, we revisit the clash’s famously complicated fifth album that contains some of their biggest songs as well as their moodiest and most impenetrable material.

ookii gekkou vanishing twin rock propelled by valentina magaletti’s masterful drumming and assisted by collaborators like stereolab’s laetitia sadier, the london group ventures further into its utopian parallel universe.

city of mirrors dos santos rock approaching the rich latinx musical tradition from intriguing new angles, the chicago quintet’s album evokes the crisp air, soft color, and enveloping warmth of a greenhouse.

sediments we move charlotte greve experimental, jazz, rock a stirring composite of choral hymns, progressive rock, and free jazz, the brooklyn composer’s suite presents a fluid cycle of matter as sound.
shut the fuck up talking to me zack fox rap on his debut album, zack fox doubles down on the joke rap shtick, resulting in a collection of tracks that is as disjointed as it is unfunny.

georgia blue jason isbell and the 400 unit folk/country released for charity, this star-studded covers album celebrates music from the state of georgia. it is a joyful affair with sadness lurking in the shadows.
optimist finneas pop/r&b without any of the gothic production flourishes that put him on the map, the producer and songwriter’s latest album is gloomy, on edge, and disappointingly hollow.
juno remi wolf pop/r&b in the california pop singer-songwriter’s bright, hallucinogenic world, everything glows in the dark and almost every chorus is chanted.
pins and needles natalie hemby folk/country on her second album, a country singer-songwriter accustomed to crafting songs for artists like miranda lambert and lee ann womack finds her own voice.

una rosa xenia rubinos rock the singer-songwriter’s latest album is steeped in caribbean texts that have influenced her musicianship. in its shades of love and grief, it sounds like life as it arrives.

seal seal pop/r&b each sunday, pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. today, we revisit seal’s 1991 debut, a luxurious album that grew out of the uk rave scene and took his inimitable voice to the world.
weight of the world maxo kream rap every aspect of the texas rapper’s personality locks into place on his latest album, the most deeply personal statement of his career.

eternal home fire-toolz experimental an 80-minute epic blending screamo, jazz, prog rock, idm, and more, the latest from producer angel marcloid offers some of her most focused and welcoming material amid the chaos.

wayfinder boy scouts folk/country with a focus on the minutiae of grief and heartbreak, the latest album from songwriter taylor vick nestles wry, careful lyrics into quiet arrangements that reward close listening.

let it be (super deluxe) the beatles rock a new reissue of includes four discs of live material, demos, alternate takes, and lost mixes, shining a light on the brilliant and tumultuous process of what would become the beatles’ final album.

high dragon and universe alice longyu gao electronic, experimental the debut ep from the rising hyperpop artist is exhilarating and unabashedly silly but falters when adhering to genre conventions and trends.
mercurial world magdalena bay pop/r&b mica tenenbaum and matthew lewin’s fuzzy, rococo synthpop confections have a magic power: they sound like whatever you grew up with, whenever that was.

i want the door to open lala lala rock pairing her simple, unaffected vocal style with carefully synthesized arrangements, the chicago-based musician departs from her indie-rock foundations in search of musical and personal freedom.
