why do birds sing? (deluxe edition) violent femmes rock released in 1991, the milwaukee trio’s fifth album marked a return to the misfit anthems that had made the femmes cult heroes in the first place.
ekphrasis bronze nazareth rap the rap duo’s latest project fits neatly into the stately traditionalism currently dominating the independent scene.
music of the spheres coldplay rock here he goes again, looking at the stars, seeing how they shine.
all hours ep anz electronic across six tracks channeling vintage freestyle, electro, uk garage, baltimore club, and more, the manchester producer pays tribute to dance music at its most joyful.
a night at the little los angeles kevin morby rock lo-fi and languid, these 4-track demos for 2020’s offer an illuminating window into the songwriter’s creative process.
trying not to think about it jojo pop/r&b on her rawest and most cohesive project to date, the pop singer explores themes of depression and anxiety but too often relies on familiar imagery.

seventeen going under sam fender rock with classic rock ambition and full-hearted sincerity, the 27-year-old british songwriter hits his stride when looking inward but fumbles when casting his gaze toward society at large.

to hell with it pinkpantheress pop/r&b, electronic the 20-year-old uk producer broke out on tiktok with snippet-sized songs that ache with nostalgia for the recent past. her intimate, lived-in music succeeds where cheaper imitations fail.
life of a don don toliver rap the texas rapper’s latest album sounds so damn good that the emptiness of it all is an afterthought.

illusory walls the world is a beautiful place & i am no longer afraid to die rock the band’s dense and ornate fourth album sacrifices intimacy and warmth in favor of the most technically proficient and hard-hitting music of their career.
then i’ll be happy ep glaive pop/r&b, rap the digicore scene’s two biggest rising stars aren’t yet distinct enough to complement each other in interesting ways.
geist shannon lay folk/country the singer-songwriter’s fourth album is largely focused on spiritual shifts and ruptures. throughout, presents a quiet, lovely, undramatic rendering of the dramatic.
piecework kowloon walled city rock the oakland-based heavy music band returns with its first album in 6 years. concise and crystal clear, it feels almost provocatively unadorned.

floating mountains soshi takeda electronic working with synthesizers and samplers from the 1990s, the tokyo producer channels the uncannily ersatz sounds of vintage video-game music into a post-vaporwave take on deep house.
talk memory badbadnotgood jazz with nods to the likes of miles davis and pharoah sanders, the inventive canadian band sets aside its affinity for hip-hop and kindles a love of classic jazz.

crimson poem yikii electronic, experimental on her most fully realized album to date, the prolific chinese artist serves up an enthralling blend of dread and beauty that feels quintessentially her own.
true love hovvdy rock on a warm and crisp new album, the texas indie-pop duo takes up the mantle of adulthood while remaining preoccupied with the nature of memory and longing.
amanita (25th anniversary edition) bardo pond rock reissued for its 25th anniversary, this dynamic and momentous release from the philadelphia rock band features some of their highest peaks.
garden of burning apparitions full of hell metal offering 12 songs in 21 minutes, the metal band refines its sound, creating an unsettled atmosphere littered with strange and memorable moments.
friends that break your heart james blake pop/r&b a warm and even-keeled collection of ballads, this is james blake’s most traditional album, but it offers little in the way of emotional insight.

one touch (20th anniversary edition) sugababes electronic, pop/r&b at a fraught time for young women in pop, the uk trio’s 2000 debut elevated candid songs about teenage girls’ hunger for experience by mining the sounds they might actually like.

crash dave matthews band rock each sunday, pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. today, we revisit the album that made the dave matthews band forever famous, in search of its long-overlooked dark heart.

all day gentle hold ! porches rock on his fifth album, aaron maine is having more fun, writing more playfully, staying out of his own head. it’s some of his most succinct and enjoyable songwriting to date.
trust fund babies lil wayne rap the duo’s collaborative mixtape isn’t a complete disaster, and it’s nice to hear lil wayne rap adequately again.

mod prog sic black dice experimental, rock sounding at once meticulous and reckless, sinister and goofy, the experimental trio’s first album in nearly a decade is its most direct appeal to the pleasure center.

vol. 3 topdown dialectic electronic like its predecessors, the anonymous electronic musician’s third album for los angeles’ peak oil label consists of little more than dubby swirls of static; the record’s power is in its restraint.

one hand on the steering wheel the other sewing a garden ada lea rock on her second album, the montreal songwriter pens straightforward tales of escape but fares best when she’s retreating into fantasy.
melodi kit sebastian rock the london duo’s second album boasts a sharpened, more streamlined sound while sticking to its roots in ’70s anatolian psychedelic pop.

ma délire - songs of love, lost & found myriam gendron folk/country the ambitious new album from the canadian songwriter features thoughtful and transformative interpretations of traditional music. it is both a meditation on the past and a novel step forward.

cxxi richard youngs experimental, rock structured around a grid of 121 minor chords, the english experimental musician’s 121st release injects process music with a welcome dose of beauty, chaos, and emotion.

only the end ashley shadow rock assisted by frequent collaborators like bonnie “prince” billy, the vancouver singer-songwriter’s second album is a gentle testament to resilience in the face of emotional hardship.

half god wiki rap produced entirely by navy blue, the new york rapper’s latest is one of his greatest. a wise and angry wiki reveals what it’s like to come of age in the city: the way it shapes, hardens, prematurely ages you.
expensive pain meek mill rap meek’s fifth album is an extended victory lap that can be thrilling and thoughtful in spots but is mostly content to aggressively spin its wheels.

to all sides they will stretch out their hands pendant experimental huerco s.’ second album under his atmospheric alter ego is eerie and unsettling: rhythms are frayed, harmonies are buried, and the usual reassurances of ambient music no longer apply.
girl, buried big vic rock the michigan band’s debut defaults to the moody rumble of 1990s shoegaze, but sounds best when it plows through the guardrails.
cacerolazo nick zanca experimental built from recordings of his 2013 tour as mister lies, nick zanca’s debut under his own name is sparse experimentation in clamor and free-form percussion.

local valley josé gonzález rock after six years, the swedish singer-songwriter returns with another soothing album of sweet indie-folk murmurs. spare electronic beats bring a new pulse to his sound, but the voice remains the same.

prose combat mc solaar rap originally released in 1994, the parisian rapper’s second album brought a particularly french sensibility to hip-hop, countering the hegemony of american artists—and the english language itself.
let me do one more illuminati hotties rock with poignant writing and irreverent humor, sarah tudzin’s second album as illuminati hotties plays like a demonstration in the art of persistence.
liminal soul kedr livanskiy electronic the moscow electronic musician and vocalist’s third album treats the haphazard textures of everyday life with a refreshingly playful sensibility.
our bande apart third eye blind rock the latest album from stephan jenkins’ alt-rock band is full of big swings and big misses, but its best songs elicit a modest, familiar sense of nostalgia.

moebius strips tim story experimental, electronic, rock moebius’ friend tim story gathers loops and samples left behind by the late krautrock pioneer and reworks them with the assistance of hans-joachim roedelius, michael rother, sarah davachi, and others.
colourgrade tirzah experimental the london songwriter’s mesmerizing second album turns towards porous, avant-garde love songs that celebrate kinship, change, and the wonder of quotidian experience.

molten mirrors various artists livity sound displays past and present iterations of its elliptical sound on this anniversary compilation, a low-key affair that serves as a testament to the focus and consistency of the bristol label’s approach to dance music.

animal kesha pop/r&b each sunday, pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. today we revisit kesha's whiskey-soaked 2010 debut, a ridiculously fun and somewhat fraught album whose garish aesthetic is being channeled anew.
fair & square john prine folk/country newly reissued on vinyl, this late-career gem from the beloved songwriter highlights the hope, humor, and underdog rage that animate his best work.
provisional license m1llionz rap shaped around a loose narrative, the birmingham drill rapper’s debut album paints an immersive picture of everyday brutality with gripping beats and detailed imagery.
lowkey superstar deluxe kari faux rap the l.a. singer and rapper offers a fun-forward deluxe mixtape that exudes color and energy, pinballing between personas and styles.

and then life was beautiful nao pop/r&b after rediscovering her creative spark, nao turns her organic-sounding third album into a kaleidoscopic testament to the pains and pleasures of modern love and the healing process they inspire.

sincerely, kentrell youngboy never broke again rap while it carries the same flaws as his previous work, the latest album from the baton rouge rapper provides a clear portrait of a tragic figure who often blurs the lines between fact and fiction.

crocus the ophelias rock the cincinnati folk-rock quartet’s third album is artfully and interestingly composed, a snapshot of four people figuring out their identities both as individual humans and as a subtly defiant band.
flux poppy music has always been just one aspect of the former youtuber’s cryptic multimedia experience, but makes it finally feel like the most important one.
in the meantime alessia cara pop/r&b alessia cara’s moving and mature album is a sleek ode to in-between states, whether they are relationships or her career track as a pop star.

songwrights apothecary lab esperanza spalding jazz esperanza spalding’s eighth album is a strangely romantic, sometimes didactic effort to mold the often private experience of listening and feeling the healing power of music.

the heart pumps kool-aid ---__--___ experimental on a collaboration between austin’s more eaze and orange milk co-founder seth graham, the music’s frequent rests and lacunae lend its jazz-tinged electroacoustic mesh a stony, severe quality.

sable (original video game soundtrack) japanese breakfast rock a gentle and mostly wordless collection of ambient pop, michelle zauner’s soundtrack for the indie exploration game is a streamlined glimpse into her versatility as a narrative artist.
a beginner’s mind sufjan stevens folk/country, rock with a collection of gentle duets inspired by great-to-iffy movies, the veteran songwriter and protégé uncover mythic resonances and ugly truths.
máscaras mas aya electronic the toronto-based musician explores his nicaraguan roots on an album of drifting, ambient-adjacent songs incorporating instruments like the quena and llamador.

wilds andy shauf rock because it’s not beholden to some overarching conceit, the latest album from the toronto-based singer-songwriter sounds looser, a bit wilder, more lackadaisical in a sadsack sort of way.

i shall wear a crown pastor t. l. barrett and the youth for christ choir some may know the chicago pastor only as the source of kanye’s “father stretch my hands.” documenting his ’70s fusions of gospel, funk, and soul, numero group’s box set captures the full sweep of his legacy.

i’ve seen everything trashcan sinatras rock the beloved scottish indie rock band reissues their 1993 sophomore album, a fan favorite, one that exemplifies the band’s communal songwriting and their indelible romanticism and pop instincts.

mouth full of glass macie stewart rock best known as one half of art-rock duo ohmme, the chicago musician turns towards lush, baroque-tinged folk on a solo debut with a reverent approach to self-knowledge and growth.

teenage dreams native soul electronic the teenage south african duo build the lean rhythms and jazzy melodies of amapiano into a sprawling debut suffused with dynamic energy and tantalizing uncertainty.

molecular level solutions ep dj stingray 313 electronic reviving his dormant micron audio label, detroit’s sherard ingram—also known as the chief architect of urban tribe—returns to the high-octane techno and electro that are his stock in trade.

flowerland pearl & the oysters pop/r&b the third album from the duo of juliette pearl davis and joachim polack takes on the soft psychedelic hues of stereolab and wendy carlos, shot through with malaise and a curious sense of overstimulation.

i’ll be your mirror: a tribute to the velvet underground and nico various artists st. vincent, kurt vile, sharon van etten, iggy pop, and more contribute to this tasteful if predictable cover album, faring best when their own identities shine through the music.
the gaping mouth lowertown rock with newly complex arrangements and more freeform songwriting, the atlanta duo ventures from its bedroom pop origins with occasionally fascinating results.

by the time i get to phoenix injury reserve rap on their first album since member stepa j. groggs’ death, the phoenix rap trio reintroduces themselves as wide-eyed explorers, a rep that suits their fascination with rap’s mechanics, its margins, and its future.
if orange was a place ep tems pop/r&b the breakout nigerian star’s second ep explores new sounds even as it returns to familiar ideas—her ongoing search for peace, love, and emotional clarity.

lewis taylor lewis taylor pop/r&b each sunday, pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. today we revisit a lost gem of neo-soul from 1996 made by a nascent phenom from the uk, heralded by aaliyah and d’angelo as one of the greats.
goldilocks x tommy genesis rap the canadian rapper and singer’s sense of playfulness is the highlight of a second album that attempts to reach beyond her raunchy sex-rap comfort zone.
black encyclopedia of the air moor mother experimental though the philadelphia experimental poet and sound artist has called this her most “accessible” album, her aims remain as radical as ever.

remember her name mickey guyton folk/country the debut album from the rising country artist aspires for universality but fares best when highlighting her singular voice and defiance of the status quo.

back in action ep midwxst rap on his latest ep, the indiana-raised hyperpop upstart takes a step closer toward the mainstream, sharpening his style without losing the irreverence that makes up his volatile vision.

american dreamer laura nyro rock the 8xlp box set gathers the ’60s and ’70s studio recordings of a singer-songwriter whose melodically intricate work had a profound impact on joni mitchell, elton john, and steely dan.
montero lil nas x pop/r&b on his melodious debut album, the pop-rap icon flaunts his verve and star power, all while a sense of isolation lives at the music’s brighter edges.

drive-by lullabies quinn experimental, electronic knit together with ambient passages and found sound, the teenage rapper and producer’s debut feels like a jumbled journey through folders of ideas, revealing new layers with every listen.

departing like rivers shackleton electronic shackleton’s first solo full-length in nine years is stripped of some of his customary idiosyncrasies, but it remains heady, beaded-curtains, incense-in-the-air music, filled with occult mystique.
observation of breath lawrence english experimental performed on a 132-year-old pipe organ, the latest project from the australian sound artist dials up the volume and revels in the rumble.
hey tony tony seltzer rap the first compilation album from the brooklyn beatmaker is an entertaining ride through the sounds of one of new york’s most underappreciated producers.

no more tears ozzy osbourne metal, rock featuring contributions from lemmy, a pair of hot 100 hits, and a newly vulnerable outlook, this peak from the rock star’s solo career gets a 30th anniversary reissue.
division jenevieve pop/r&b the miami singer moves through her debut album with a sense of self-assurance that doesn’t allow her to look into the rearview at missteps.

space 1.8 nala sinephro jazz, experimental the brilliant and unassuming debut from the young uk musician and composer is a benchmark in ambient jazz featuring outstanding players and delicately woven arrangements.
up 2 më yeat rap the inescapable portland rapper continues to go beyond the usual rage rap expectations, bending his voice without ever making it feel gimmicky.
a beautiful life heartless bastards rock on its straightforward but deeply felt sixth album, the ohio rock band positions music itself as a salve against the horrors of the world.
starshooter shootergang kony rap the sacramento rapper is more relaxed and nonchalant on his latest project, a mood that suits his knack for finding humanity in the darkest of situations.

established! rp boo electronic the footwork pioneer sets aside the obsessive minimalism of his previous album in favor of party-starting anthems and sly sample flips. but his work remains a masterclass in rhythmic dexterity.
texis sleigh bells pop/r&b despite its newfound musical relevance, the influential duo struggles to evolve beyond its signature template of empowering pop hooks and overdriven arrangements.
pictura de ipse: musique directe hubert lenoir rock on his second album, the québécois pop provocateur scales down the lavish glam rock of his debut for funky experiments with inconsistent results.

deja bomba estéreo global absorbing influences from the natural world and working with collaborators like lido pimienta, the colombian group pushes its habitual electro-tropicalia sound into new terrain.

the convincer (20th anniversary reissue) nick lowe rock a new reissue of the the master craftsman’s 2001 album offers the quintessential portrait of his third act, showcasing a fascination with the places where genres intertwine.
doe or die ii az rap the brooklyn rapper follows up his 1995 debut with an ornate sequel that indulges nostalgia on its own terms.
silence alexis taylor electronic with sparse arrangements and a lyrical focus on hearing loss and mortality, the latest solo album from the hot chip vocalist is a solemn and moving collection.
you heat me up, you cool me down king krule rock this live album is an intense, electric, and sometimes uncanny exhibition of archy marshall’s ability to reimagine his songs on stage.

look-ka py py the meters rock each sunday, pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. today we revisit an inimitable document of new orleans music, home to the deepest grooves and an enormous foundation for funk, rock, and rap.

lindsey buckingham lindsey buckingham rock on his first solo album in 10 years, lindsey buckingham’s insistent, almost irritating knack for melody suggests a resurgent talent for making his insularity accessible.
comfort to me amyl and the sniffers rock on their second album, the australian quartet expands into a colossus-sized version of itself. everything feels bigger, heavier, and more meaningful.
before i die 박혜진 park hye jin electronic singing and rapping in korean and english, the los angeles-based electronic producer takes tentative steps toward reinventing herself as a songwriter.

the delta sweete bobbie gentry folk/country each sunday, pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. today we revisit bobbie gentry’s 1968 album, a daring, atmospheric, and oft-overshadowed southern classic.
k bay matthew e. white rock filled with delightful moments of sound-craft, the third solo album from the spacebomb auteur places him at the center of a vast musical cosmology.
antiphonals sarah davachi electronic using a soft instrumental palette of mellotron and keyboards, canadian minimalist composer sarah davachi welcomes listeners into her fortress of solitude.
the melodic blue baby keem rap on his expansive debut studio album, the once enigmatic rapper expands his fascination with trap and melody to feature-length with mixed results.

flush real pharynx 2019-2021 lee gamble electronic gathering a trio of eps into a single sprawling package, the experimental club producer offers a nightmarish tour of late capitalism that’s dark, disorienting, and at times, draining.

i’ve been trying to tell you saint etienne electronic, rock on their 10th studio album, the uk electro-pop heroes look back on the end of the 20th century, when hooks and choruses dissolved into blissed-out loops and vibe became paramount.
crack dreams rxk nephew rap the latest disappointing mixtape from one of the year’s most exciting rappers proves that the best way to encounter him is his youtube channel.

certified lover boy drake rap drake’s sixth album sounds good but feels labored. melancholic and often incisive, it becomes an overlong and very familiar journey through the life, mind, and heart of drake.
m field ep m field rock on this indie pop ep, the cape town singer and guitarist generates warmth by pairing innocent inquiry with bright instrumentation.
hey what low rock on the follow-up to 2018’s astonishing , mimi parker and alan sparhawk push deeper into abstraction, finding fresh angles on the themes that have animated them since the beginning.

the metallica blacklist metallica metal celebrating the 30th anniversary of the black album, metallica enlist phoebe bridgers, kamasi washington, moses sumney, weezer, j balvin, and many more for this enormous and uneven tribute album.

star-crossed kacey musgraves folk/country kacey musgraves’ chronicle of marriage and divorce looks to the stars but takes pains to stay grounded. writing in the plain language of someone desperate to be understood, she sounds alternately vulnerable and triumphant.
mirrors dj seinfeld electronic on his first album in four years, the swedish house producer strips away the hiss to zero in on floor-filling club tracks and big, universal emotions.
everything bnny rock chicago singer-songwriter jessica viscius moves through grief in a profoundly moving and generous way on her spare debut as bnny.

dawn of chromatica lady gaga pop/r&b a remix album of lady gaga’s 2020 dancefloor epic is less a wall-to-wall collection of club bangers than an expansion of the cinematic universe, featuring charli xcx, arca, rina sawayama, doss, and more.

honest labour space afrika electronic a genre-spanning collection of cryptic transmissions, interludes, and asides, the manchester duo’s second album gets at emotion in an oblique fashion, remaking your desires as it plays.
gg bb xx lany pop/r&b, rock the nominally bicoastal pop trio’s fourth album is musically complacent and emotionally lifeless.

mercury – act 1 imagine dragons rock despite the ostensibly humanizing presence of rick rubin, rock’s patron saint of prestige, these quintessentially vegas showmen still sound like they’re firing their emotions out of a t-shirt cannon.
italians do it better various artists executive-produced by johnny jewel, this madonna tribute album transports her iconic singles to the boutique label’s seedy, neon-lit lounges.

structure water from your eyes rock the brooklyn electro-pop duo’s fifth album breaks into two mirror-image halves of a guided tour of heartbreak, hope, and longing. they’re still making cryptic indie pop that hits like a sugar rush.
i died for this?! grip rap the georgia rapper’s debut for shady records is a gritty showcase for his creativity and versatility, even if it only works in fits and starts.
senjutsu iron maiden metal the british metal legends return with their dark and patient 17th album. while their influence looms large in heavy music, no other band sounds quite like this.

backwards and forwards (the wea recordings 1984-1995) aztec camera electronic, rock this expansive collection follows songwriter roddy frame from his second album through his decision to retire the aztec camera moniker, highlighting forays into sophistipop, electronica, and soul.

baduizm erykah badu pop/r&b each sunday, pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. today we revisit erykah badu’s 1997 debut, an existential anchor of the neo-soul movement.

sometimes i might be introvert little simz rap on her fourth album, the uk rapper wrestles with the split between her public persona and private self, raising broadly relatable questions about the craving for validation.

any shape you take indigo de souza rock the north carolina songwriter’s outstanding second album spans grungy rock and colorful, hi-fi pop, illuminating her impressive voice and her ability to wring out every last drop of emotion.
the witness suuns rock by resisting the bluster of past efforts, the montreal band emerges with its most cohesive album yet, the first that never gets lost in its own dark gravity.

the mutt’s nuts chubby and the gang rock with the glow-up of a bigger indie label behind them for their second album, the uk punks ride again with burly bravado, but it’s notably the work of artists eager to show that they contain multitudes.

how long do you think it’s gonna last? big red machine rock justin vernon and aaron dessner’s expansive side project embraces new guests and familiar sounds, but sometimes feels lost in its own pleasant fog.

screen violence chvrches pop/r&b on its fourth album, the scottish trio steps back from the grandest pop aspirations and embraces a horror-movie concept without losing its signature brightness and sense of joy.

dissent moritz von oswald trio electronic the berlin dub-techno icon reshuffles his trio’s lineup on its first album in six years. alongside jazz drummer heinrich köbberling, laurel halo’s electric keys provide a surprising new focal point.

other you steve gunn folk/country recorded in los angeles, the songwriter and guitarist’s sixth solo album is ambitious yet effortless. even his lead guitar seems almost to melt away into the delicate arrangements.
deconsecrate ænigmatum metal on its second album, the portland quartet conjures a sense of ambient horror with shapeshifting, high-velocity death metal.

next is now vivien goldman global, rock in grappling with the “mess” of our present moment, the punk legend looks relentlessly to the future, and her optimism feels alternately like a salve and a delusion.

donda kanye west rap kanye west’s 10th album arrives barely finished and with a lot of baggage. its 27 tracks include euphoric highs that lack connective tissue, a data dump of songs searching for a higher calling.

feel flows: the sunflower & surf’s up sessions 1969-1971 the beach boys rock tracing the beach boys’ long road back to the spotlight, this five-disc set showcases a complicated era and a creative peak.
psalms nathan salsburg folk/country accompanied by joan shelley, will oldham, and others, the louisville guitarist sets hebrew psalms and poetry to music with a comforting, candlelit atmosphere.
love will be reborn martha wainwright rock on her first album in five years, the singer-songwriter meditates on love, grief, and motherhood with vibrant melodies and newfound perspective.

history of a feeling madi diaz folk/country the nashville-based singer-songwriter’s fifth album breaks through to a spare, unvarnished, and occasionally volatile style of indie rock that feels in step with the newly sharpened edge to her lyricism.

fire the bug electronic drawing inspiration from the abject state of contemporary britain and nourished by fantasies of righteous violence, the latest album from the uk producer is his heaviest in years.

everybody else is doing it, so why can’t we? the cranberries rock each sunday, pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. today we revisit the 1993 debut from the irish pop-rock band, a showcase for dolores o’riordan’s disarming songwriting and immaculate voice.
geezyworld ohgeesy rap the former shoreline mafia member launches his solo career with a concentrated dose of what he does best: rap music for the height of the party.

in it for the money (remastered expanded edition) supergrass electronic, rock originally released in 1997, the britpop band’s second album feels like a crash course in the history of uk rock, zipping through glam, psychedelia, punk, and pop in fresh, surprising ways.

glow on turnstile rock the baltimore band’s spectacular fourth record is all groove, riffs, and passion. it is not a crossover hardcore album that looks to transcend the genre, but one that tries to elevate it to its highest visibility.
year of the spider shannon and the clams rock the oakland rock band responds to tragedy with grace on their most musically diverse and lyrically affecting album yet.
the horses and the hounds james mcmurtry folk/country on his expertly written 10th album, the texas storyteller delivers some of his most intense and humane work.
america’s sweetheart 2 bear1boss rap bear1boss has been a breath of fresh air with his bright, melodic take on atlanta rap. his latest and best project yet focuses purely on fun.

the long and short of it quickly, quickly rock the fantastic album from the portland-based artist graham jonson turns beat music and bedroom pop into a complex psychedelic world with vast emotional horizons. his songs are lush and boundless.

corinne bailey rae corinne bailey rae pop/r&b though best remembered for its biggest hit, the uk singer’s eponymous 2006 debut remains unmatched in the weighty simplicity of its stories of love pursued and lost.

no sun nite jewel pop/r&b written in the wake of a divorce and while working toward a phd in musicology, the los angeles musician’s first album in four years is a breakup record stripped to its most elemental parts.

cracks bendik giske electronic on his second solo album, the norwegian saxophonist continues to develop an entirely new vocabulary for his instrument, using electronic treatments to yield a curiously disembodied sound.

cheers to the best memories dvsn pop/r&b, rap the trio’s collaborative debut stumbles into lovely stretches, coasting on the beauty of the singers’ voices. but it leaves you wondering why such an obviously winning combination falls short.
lost futures marisa anderson folk/country evoking the landscapes of the american southwest, these peaceful guitar duets find the duo tapping into the serene, timeless quality of the instrument.

long term effects of suffering $uicideboy$ rap channeling the stark sound and fatalistic worldview of vintage southern rap, the new orleans duo takes grim pleasure in grappling with substance abuse and mental illness.

long time coming sierra ferrell folk/country the west virginia native found fame on youtube, but she descends from a long tradition of american roots music. though assisted by nashville greats, her debut retains her essential wildness.
queendom red velvet pop/r&b the individual songs on the k-pop girl group’s mini-album are perfectly adequate, but the release itself never reaches the group’s former heights.

a martyr’s reward ka rap one of rap’s most inventive stylists surfaces from his memories to reflect on himself and his vocation, transforming his latest record into a searing, soulful gem in his catalog.
only up breeze rock recorded with an ensemble of toronto musicians, the fun and referential second album from josh korody’s indie rock project feels like a big, messy collage.
’til i start speaking morly rock the london-based singer’s jazzy debut album shines most brightly when she gets explosive, yet her muted moments also resonate.
body jumper provoker rock filled with muted vocals and no wave melodies, the bay area group’s debut album uses 1980s horror tropes and video games to reflect on contemporary alienation.
don’t know what i am alien boy rock the portland quartet crank up the chorus and distortion pedals in service of jangly hooks and gleaming counter-melodies.

if i can’t have love, i want power halsey pop/r&b produced by trent reznor and atticus ross, halsey’s spectral fourth album confronts the thrill and terror of getting what you want. it’s their strongest work to date.

primordial arcana wolves in the throne room metal working out of their home studio in the washington woods, experimentally minded brothers nathan and aaron weaver return to their roots in atmospheric black metal, but they no longer sound like pioneers.

rhododendron d’eon electronic the montreal musician and former grimes collaborator weaves synthetic woodwinds and harpsichord into a dizzying yet heartfelt fusion of classical pastiche and skewed electronic pop.
solar power lorde pop/r&b lorde returns with a self-aware, scaled-back album. its holistic beauty and revelations about the natural world are often lost in the drab music.
sylva sylvarum ora clementi experimental with vivid details and subtle textures, the latest collaboration between crys cole and james rushford folds real-world sounds into a landscape of dreams.
infinite granite deafheaven metal abandoning black metal’s harsh intensity in favor of softer, gentler sounds, deafheaven push themselves into surprising terrain. it’s a tricky proposition.
aisles ep angel olsen rock the songwriter takes an uncharacteristic breather with a collection of faithful, occasionally brooding covers of 1980s hits like “forever young” and “the safety dance.”

a hole in the fence walt mcclements experimental taken individually, the pieces on this album from the los angeles-based accordion player can be moving, but their similar construction yields transcendence and tedium in equal measure.

sweetness ep sarz pop/r&b, rap, global buoyed by afrobeats producer sarz’ nostalgic, ’80s-influenced production, the nigerian-born, london-based singer turns his attention to romance, exploring a gentler side of his voice.

bo jackson boldy james rap the detroit rapper and the famed producer rejoin forces for a spare, melancholy, and psychedelic album, solidifying their partnership as one of the most rewarding team-ups in hip-hop.

basic tools equiknoxx electronic the kingston-based dancehall crew’s fourth album presents a world of inside jokes and outsize characters set to slyly experimental beats that show exacting attention to detail.
anjelitu ep homeboy sandman rap bored by the status quo and excited by everything he hasn’t tried yet, the queens rapper is unafraid to take risks and get weird on his latest ep.
dreams still inspire abstract mindstate rap guided by detailed coaching from kanye west, the chicago duo embrace an urge to restore a kind of lyrical conscious rap that has never been lost.
cherrytape bbymutha rap the tennessee rapper’s latest four-song ep is a concentrated burst of energy with perfectly paced flows and a vibe that’s always ready for the dancefloor.

the ballad of dood and juanita sturgill simpson folk/country following two volumes of roots renditions of his own songs, the shapeshifting country musician returns with a bluegrass concept album about love among the legends of the kentucky frontier.

still slipping vol. 1 joy orbison electronic in his debut full-length, the uk producer puts his idiosyncratic stamp on a variety of club styles, folding in the voices of his family members to add emotional resonance.

don’t get comfy / nowhere carmen q. rothwell jazz on her solo debut, the double bassist largely lets her instrument play a supporting role for her distinctive soprano vocals, working through deep feelings via quietly adventurous songwriting.

twin plagues wednesday rock on its second album, the asheville five-piece goes big and loud, scaling up its shoegaze-indebted sound while frontwoman karly hartzman buries an undercurrent of anxiety beneath the clutter.
draw down the moon foxing rock the st. louis band’s fourth album scrapes away their unwieldy experimentalism in favor of the approachable, frustratingly anonymous sounds of 2010s festival rock.

pyrex picasso benny the butcher rap the griselda rapper’s latest album accentuates many of his strengths, highlights no unknown weaknesses, and is peppered with some of the finest tracks of what will be remembered as a golden era for the butcher.

complacency ep johnny football hero rock the philadelphia emo trio’s debut ep packs in a career’s worth of evolution, pulling from ’90s midwest twinkle, shredding, and the online angst of an emergent fifth wave.

above the fray dām-funk pop/r&b dām-funk’s latest is his most romantic and awestruck album. if his earlier work suggests a bleary-eyed, late-night haze, is a cloudless vista where you can see for miles.

fiori chiari, fiori oscuri alvin curran experimental fusing toy piano, minimalist improvisation, children’s voices, modular synthesizers, and a purring cat, among other fanciful sounds, the american composer’s 1978 album revels in the accidental music of everyday life.
a sky record damon & naomi rock the duo’s latest album is a calming and tender reflection on appreciating what you have in uncertain times.
pressure machine the killers rock brandon flowers dials back the pomp for an intimate, homespun, and sometimes clunky tour through the small town where he grew up.

harmonizer ty segall rock the tireless psych rocker’s latest is simultaneously sleek and sludgy. it’s not quite his cleanest-sounding album, nor his heaviest, but it stands close to the top of both categories.
pono a great big pile of leaves rock with its wistful musings on adolescence, the indie rock trio’s first album in eight years picks up right where they left off.

fire of love the gun club rock each sunday, pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. today we revisit the incendiary, hell-bent debut from the los angeles punk band who used blues and rockabilly to paint a depraved portrait of a young artist in their purest state.
all dogs go to heaven ep glaive pop/r&b, rap recorded in a sleek l.a. studio, the gen-z hyperpop artist’s latest ep hides his natural talent under a layer of amorphous production.
refuge devendra banhart folk/country, experimental the songwriter and producer team for a loving, referential collection of new age music that doesn’t always color inside the lines.

rich shooter young nudy rap with tightly packed bars and adaptable, uncanny flows, the atlanta rapper’s latest is precise and loose at the same time. pi’erre bourne and coupe’s beats are showcases for his originality.
bloodslide ep bloodslide rock featuring members of protomartyr and preoccupations, the post-punk supergroup’s debut is refreshingly blunt and ambitious.
native sons los lobos rock a tribute to their hometown of los angeles, this covers album spans genre and style, showcasing los lobos’ versatility, taste, and strength as a rock’n’roll band.
project x ken carson rap the atlanta rapper and playboi carti protégé aims to set himself apart with his zoned-out sing-rap.

the apple drop liars rock with new collaborators and a little psychedelic aid, the sculpted rhythms and dark-hued instrumentation of angus andrew’s long-running art-rock project feel like a summation and a fresh start.

megabear me rex rock the london band’s full-length debut is an audacious experiment: 52 short snippets of rippling pianos and synthesized symphonics that can be shuffled in any order to create one continuous song.
feminista tomu dj experimental the california producer’s debut album channels new-age synths and retro dance styles into a dreamlike synthesis of disparate musical modes.

sinner get ready lingua ignota experimental kristin hayter’s latest is an intense and frightening religious inquiry, incorporating traditional appalachian instruments and samples from televangelist sermons.

therapy anne-marie pop/r&b the british singer’s crisply rendered, competently hooky second album promises a more personal self-portrait, but she ends up disappearing into vague songwriting and anodyne dance-pop production.

house of lull . house of when alexis marshall rock the debut solo album from the daughters vocalist is a left turn: an eerie, improvised collection of industrial music that places you deep in the heart of the abyss.

painful enlightenment jana rush electronic the veteran chicago footwork producer tests the genre’s stylistic limits on a bracing, sometimes harrowing album that documents her struggles with depression.
333 tinashe pop/r&b parlaying creative independence into her best work to date, the r&b star’s latest self-released album is a showcase for her omnivorous tastes and supremely light touch.

fragments rachika nayar experimental five months after her stunning debut album, the brooklyn composer offers up a modest yet revealing set of sketch-like guitar pieces, drawing unexpected connections between pat metheny and midwestern emo.
9th & walnut descendents metal, rock the veteran california band reconstructs some of its earliest material for an unusual sort of lost album that captures an ephemeral moment in punk history.
razor’s edge rome streetz rap the rapper’s latest album, a sleek modern update to a classic formula—helmed entirely by producer futurewave—expresses a tenderness rarely seen in his catalog.
king’s disease ii nas rap the queensbridge rapper’ sequel mythologizes his business acumen and doubles down on the formula of its predecessor to mixed effect.
gumbo’! pink siifu rap the genre-defying rapper’s third album pays tribute to the artists who helped shape his sound—and sounds like something else altogether.
h.r. meljoann pop/r&b the irish diy artist isn’t the first to note that while pop is fun, capitalism is perhaps a bit of a downer. but she’s uncommonly committed to the bit.

country funk volume iii (1975-1982) various artists the third volume of light in the attic’s ongoing survey of this largely notional movement puts a new twist on the idea of combining two seemingly incompatible genres in one unruly sound.

young dolph presents paper route illuminati various artists featuring key glock and newcomers snupe bandz and joddy, this compilation from the memphis rapper and his associates feels like the culmination of a thoroughly unique career.

born in the u.s.a. bruce springsteen rock each sunday, pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. today we revisit a 1980s rock blockbuster: the bold, brilliant, and misunderstood apex of bruce springsteen’s imperial era.

glans intercum ben bondy experimental ben bondy makes ambient music shot through with sharp, pristinely mixed drums. this album for huerco s.’s label is psychedelic in a way that suggests a faint sense of nausea or discomfort.

happier than ever billie eilish pop/r&b on her second album, billie eilish sings with unsparing honesty about her rapid ascent to stardom and all its accompanying horrors. it’s woozy, effortlessly melodic, and showcases her command over the pop landscape.
stand for myself yola rock the bristol-born, nashville-based singer-songwriter’s second album isn’t defined by genre as much as it is by yola’s indomitable spirit.
laura stevenson laura stevenson rock the singer-songwriter’s sixth album remains enigmatic, processing trauma and joy through the force of its unvarnished arrangements.
wildhund lantlôs rock on their first album in 7 years, the blackgaze innovators lighten up their sound with bountiful hooks and life-drunk enthusiasm.

new day with new possibilities sonny and the sunsets rock billed as a country record, the san francisco garage-rock hero’s eighth record with the sunsets uses the genre as a means for chronicling the lives of lonesome men.
heart-shaped scars dot allison folk/country with a tendency to drift, the scottish songwriter’s first solo record in almost a decade is a quiet, graceful collection of autumnal folk music.
mood ring kississippi rock the latest album from philly songwriter zoe reynolds embraces the synths and glitter of pop music, but it feels most luminous when it’s raw.

vanice cookiee kawaii electronic following up the viral hit “vibe (if i back it up),” the new jersey singer’s official debut aims to render the fast-paced, energetic sound of jersey club in her own image.

yes/and yes/and experimental, rock the debut album from meg duffy and joel ford maps the interaction between delicate fingerpicking and precise electronic textures; it is a study in subtle, gorgeous discord.
shiloh: lost for words john glacier rap, electronic the east london rapper and producer’s debut has the feel of a mixtape, luxuriating in the tension between her reticent persona and raw lyricism.

welcome 2 america prince pop/r&b, rock recorded in 2010, prince’s first posthumous album of all unreleased material is a state-of-the-union concept record in which he bluntly broadcasts his opinions on taxes, technology, drugs, religion, and the music industry.
debonair horsey rock grating yet perversely gratifying, this king krule-adjacent south london band’s debut also contains music of inarguable force or surprising beauty.

at pioneer works les filles de illighadad folk/country in tuareg culture, women rarely play guitar; this nigerien group breaks with that tradition. their 2019 live recording captures them at a hypnotic high, far from home but in command of an eager, inviting spirit.
we’re all alone in this together dave rap the british-nigerian rapper’s second album is as ambitious, technical, and deeply felt as his first. it is sure to keep his star on the rise.
thirstier torres rock mackenzie scott’s latest is anthemic and euphoric, loaded with hooks and joyous reflections on love and self-discovery.
moon boy yung bleu rap the mobile, alabama rapper’s debut album is weighed down by streaming bait, but thankfully it does include a handful of his highest highs.

a night at the baths ruth mascelli electronic the special interest synth player’s latest solo project is an emotional tour of the bathhouse: a celebration of defiantly queer spaces in the form of heady, hazy techno and ambient.
âlem altin gün rock on their second album this year, the netherlands-based anatolian psych rockers push deeper into electronic pop, infusing traditional turkish melodies with the spirit of disco.

amapiano now various artists curated by london djs shannen sp and joe cotch, this 17-track compilation takes the pulse of the quickly evolving south african genre built around log-drum grooves, bright synths, and jazz-inflected keys.
peppa’s adventures: the album peppa pig pop/r&b the four-year-old pop phenom and famous pig’s second album is a charming and self-assured celebration of family, friendship, and muddy puddles.

take the sadness out of saturday night bleachers pop/r&b on his third solo album, jack antonoff ends up splitting his time between careful rock songwriting and carefree pop singing, leaving a minor impression of both.

ngủ ngày ngay ngày tận thế rắn cạp đuôi experimental the vietnamese experimental trio’s debut album offers a breakneck onslaught of disparate styles and moods. the sounds can be thrillingly haphazard, but the vision is unmistakably focused.
the house is burning isaiah rashad rap the tde rapper returns with newfound poise and even joy, taking r&b, southern rap, and his inimitable lyrical style and casting it into a sophisticated collage.

celestial blues king woman metal kristina esfandiari and her band move from the darkness to light on their second album, taking liberally from post-rock, grunge, and doom metal to tell a tale equally inspired by a childhood brush with death and paradise lost.

jesus freak dc talk rock each sunday, pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. today we revisit the story around the ’90s boom of contemporary christian music and one of its biggest records.
crowlink ep shirley collins folk/country interspersed with birdsong, new age synth, and poetry recitations, a new ep from the english folk singer returns her songs to the elements that inspired them.
seance maxine funke folk/country on the new zealand singer-songwriter’s fourth album, spare acoustic arrangements make deceptively simple containers for songs charged with memory and mysticism.
psa peyton pop/r&b the houston singer’s debut blends pop, alt-r&b, and soul into a polished and pensive account of growing into young adulthood.

last train to paris diddy - dirty money pop/r&b each sunday, pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. today we revisit sean “diddy” combs’ 2010 side project: a dark and stormy concept album about one man’s transit through love.

van gogh’s left ear zelooperz rap the detroit rapper pays tribute to van gogh’s most infamous moment, extending his own recent prolific streak with a chaotic, creative album that switches styles like outfits.
blind obedience taphari rap the enigmatic brooklyn rapper’s debut album is part airing of grievances, part origin story: a blood-stained portrait of the forces that made him.

an afternoon whine claire rousay experimental, electronic texas musicians and real-life “bffs” mari maurice and claire rousay work in the same room for the first time. more than a cool biographical detail, this fact defines the album’s lovingly meta style.

yellow emma-jean thackray jazz the debut from the english bandleader and producer is a fascinating blend of spiritual jazz and brass band that can sound full-on psychedelic while staying grounded in its clever arrangements.

banned lightman jarvis ecstatic band rock a low-pressure psych-rock jam session between canadian artists yves jarvis and romy lightman produces a few happy accidents and a lot of aimless experimentation.
under the lilac sky arushi jain electronic the indian composer and vocalist blends hindustani classical music with new age synth on her dreamy, meditative debut.

life, and another mega bog experimental erin birgy’s delightfully freaky sixth album is dense but full of whimsy and romance, pulling in strains of folk, jazz, and chamber pop to marvel at all the odd little wonders of the world.
scout ep samia rock the singer-songwriter aims for a bigger sound with her new ep, a condensed whirlwind of breakups, reunions, long-distance phone calls, and long-haul road trips.
change anika pop/r&b, rock the berlin-based artist’s first full-length solo release in over a decade is a stylish, sexy record where not much happens.
it’s remble remble rap the los angeles rapper’s debut charts his development as he settles into a style that’s funny, winkingly formal, and rich in commercial potential.
gold-diggers sound leon bridges pop/r&b the texas singer delivers a smooth, risk-averse r&b album whose nostalgic trappings aim for timelessness.
the asymptotical world ep yves tumor rock even on a brief ep, yves tumor’s prismatic world seems to get bigger as it mutates into certain conventions of goth rock, dream pop, and shoegaze.

ain’t that the truth drakeo the ruler rap drakeo’s fifth full-length release in eight months is brooding and entertaining. the lesser cuts can’t help but bleed together, but there’s just enough new variations to keep things fresh.

spiral darkside rock nicolás jaar and dave harrington return with a meticulous work of unexpected and even unprecedented familiarity—less a portal than a kiosk existing entirely within the boundaries set by their 2013 debut.
signals in my head dj manny electronic the south side producer infuses footwork’s intricate syncopations with the romance of r&b; in the process, he underscores the shared lineage with chicago house.

tiny music… songs from the vatican gift shop (super deluxe edition) stone temple pilots rock newly reissued for its 25th anniversary, stp’s sunbaked album of glam and pop and rock ranks as one of their best, separating them from the pack of post-grunge wannabes.

temporary highs in the violet skies snoh aalegra pop/r&b with dreamy experimental production and standout tyler, the creator features, the l.a. singer’s latest is an affecting document of how pain can smolder beneath a veneer of nonchalance.

lately i feel everything willow rock willow’s fourth solo album continues to unpack her lifelong struggles with the extremes of human emotion, using a trove of pop-rock stylings from nu-metal to pop-punk to somewhat mixed effect.

utopian ashes bobby gillespie rock feigning coupledom, the two singers offer a fictionalized divorce album modeled after the tear-jerking country, soul, and pop duets of yesteryear. they flirt with camp without ever succumbing to it.
fabric presents overmono overmono electronic traversing classic uk genres like 2-step and jungle, the duo’s first commercial mix doubles as a celebration of multiculturalism in modern britain.
luminol midwife rock with cosmos-filling drones and blazing noise, the third album from madeline johnston’s experimental pop project feels ambitious and communal.
hideaway wavves rock working with producer dave sitek, nathan williams returns with another mixed bag of combative rock songs that are straightforward to a fault.
faith pop smoke rap pop smoke’s second posthumous album sounds like it’s solely designed to generate clicks as a new generation of rap fans continues to be exploited for their streams.

diva annie lennox rock each sunday, pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. today we revisit annie lennox’s 1992 solo debut, a joyous and liberated pop album with a prophetic message about the disillusionment of fame.
sob rock john mayer rock is the sound of a man alone in his success. even if this is one of john mayer’s stronger albums, the whole thing feels self-consciously minor.
tell me about tomorrow jxdn rock the 20-year-old tiktok personality turned punk rocker’s debut album won’t stop announcing how punk it is.

muvaland vol. 2 ep cakes da killa rap the no-holds-bar rapper and producer weave a tight tapestry of musical references that only hundreds of hours spent sweating to music by queer elders could produce.
tx, ’98 flight mode rock the debut ep from this reverential emo band is full of nostalgia, wonder, and autobiographical detail, like a linklater film soundtracked by deep elm records.
sling clairo pop/r&b on her second album, reluctant gen z ambassador clairo turns back the clock, embracing classic touchstones of 1970s folk.
blue heron jodi folk/country chicago multi-instrumentalist nick levine’s solo debut will feel familiar to pinegrove fans but struggles to expand on the band’s formula.
na zala zala rey sapienz electronic powered by brittle electronic drums and buzzing synths, the congolese musician’s debut album is simultaneously bleak and exhilarating.

the soft bulletin companion the flaming lips rock originally released in 1999 as a promotional cd-r, this collection of alternate mixes and non-album tracks bridges the gap between the band’s experimental hijinks and pop instincts.
twin shadow twin shadow rock george lewis jr.’s self-titled fifth album is an island of good feelings and vacuous summertime indie-pop jams.

dee gees - hail satin foo fighters rock dave grohl’s six-piece finds common cause between gaudy disco-pop and willfully absurd arena rock on an album-length collection of bee gees covers and live-in-studio cuts.

fun is not a straight line ripatti electronic sasu ripatti—aka vladislav delay and luomo—returns to footwork with his first album-length attempt at the form, translating the genre’s fast-paced syncopations into a harsh, elemental blast.

kirtan: turiya sings alice coltrane jazz, experimental these 1981 devotional recordings for voice and wurlitzer, meant to guide meditation through chanting, offer an alternate version of the cosmic jazz visionary’s synthesizer masterpiece, .

20+ piano improvisations antiguo autómata mexicano experimental the monterrey-based experimental musician abandons the outward trappings of electronic music on his latest album, a hushed collection of cryptic etudes that flicker in the margin between the played and the programmed.
mythopoetics half waif pop/r&b created during a residency at gainesville’s pulp arts studio, nandi rose’s latest album as half waif is complex, daring, and emotionally unsettled.

ry ry world mariah the scientist pop/r&b the 23-year-old singer’s careful observations add new profundity to her storytelling. her second album confirms her place as one of modern r&b’s realest talkers.
hologram a place to bury strangers rock with a new rhythm section and tighter performances, the noisy new york band’s latest ep moves deliberately from chaos to catharsis.

last year was weird, vol. 3 tkay maidza pop/r&b the australian musician caps an adventurous trilogy of eps with another round of plush, laid-back songs that effortlessly mix pop, rap, r&b, and reggae.
uy scuti olamide pop/r&b the nigerian rapper and singer’s easygoing charm guides this lush and freewheeling collection.
banoffee pies white label series 01 tim reaper electronic breakout uk producer tim reaper and his collaborator comfort zone convey the power and possibility of jungle.

origin of symmetry muse rock each sunday, pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. today we revisit the grandiose british rock band’s second album, a supranatural space odyssey powered by all-too-human emotion.
it’s just wind connan mockasin rock new zealand psych rocker connan mockasin’s collaborative album with his dad, ade, has bad jokes, stream-of-consciousness poetry, and an odd, undeniable appeal.
space jam: a new legacy various artists much like the cinematic remake, which functions as nothing but an advertisement for the entire warner media library, the soundtrack is soulless and gratuitous.

yasuragi land foodman experimental on his first proper full-length in three years, the japanese electronic musician collages tiny sounds into intricate grooves that harness the wonder of everyday life.
vice versa rauw alejandro pop/r&b, rap the nascent pop star attempts to move beyond reggaetón on his latest album, but he never fully commits to any particular direction.

sin city the mixtape ski mask the slump god rap on his new mixtape, the south florida rapper is content honing the blade of his technical precision while his peers take direct stabs at crossover success.
nastavi, calliope babehoven rock singer and songwriter maya bon’s bedroom-pop dirges are both intimate and removed, filled with understated yet strangely meaningful detail.

moot! moin rock raime’s joe andrews and tom halstead, together with percussionist valentina magaletti, swap their customary electronics for muscular, guitar-driven sounds influenced by bands like slint and unwound.

a color of the sky lightning bug rock guided by the inquisitive lyrics of singer audrey kang as she narrates the process of searching for self through song, the band’s lush third album feels like a ride-along to the creative process.
mirror ii the goon sax rock the brisbane trio immerses itself in cavernous, eerie post-punk to soundtrack the uncanny horror of young adulthood.

agor koreless electronic arriving a full 10 years after his debut single, welsh producer lewis roberts’ first album is a bravura display of brain-bending editing that’s more concerned with big feelings.
vince staples vince staples rap produced entirely by kenny beats, the album’s reserved musical approach magnifies the blunt scene-setting vince has used to build his name over the last decade.

exit wounds the wallflowers rock on their first album in nearly a decade, jakob dylan and co. return with highway ballads and saturday afternoon rockers, sounding like the classic rock band they’ve always ached to be.

former things lonelady rock manchester post-punk musician julie campbell’s third album is dense with possibilities, whiplashing between past and future. the maximalism isn’t big-picture, but granular: busy, hyperreal instants by the millions.

let the soil play its simple part caroline shaw experimental centering her own voice for the first time, caroline shaw proves to be a master of collapsing boundaries, whether between her performer-composer roles or the corporeal and the immaterial.

the hustle still continues juicy j rap three 6 mafia’s tireless frontman has done it all as an artist and collaborator, which is why it’s disappointing to see him combat his ageless production with uninspired guest features on his new deluxe album.
space & time justine skye pop/r&b the newly independent singer’s latest project is designed to make her stand out in a crowded r&b field but falls short of any singular, defining moments.

i lie here buried with my rings and my dresses backxwash rap the zambian canadian rapper and producer’s third album is heavy and suffocating, cranking up the murk and intensity to reveal the relief within unbridled anger.

será que ahora podremos entendernos mabe fratti experimental the guatemalan musician’s second album explores the friction between interiority and exteriority; blooming with ecstatic synth riffs and spirited cello, the record captures the sound of a mind abuzz.

alpha charlotte day wilson pop/r&b on her debut album, the toronto singer-songwriter and producer draws variously from gospel, folk, and adult-contemporary influences; no matter the style, every song is a showcase for her powerful voice.
the veiled sea six organs of admittance experimental an extended investigation of the electric guitar solo, the latest record from ben chasny’s experimental project is graceful and surprising.
golden doubt quivers rock the melbourne jangle-pop quartet hits all the right ‘80s pleasure points with an understated sense of humor and anthemic songcraft.
sgv1 surf gang rap the new york city rap crew’s latest is a mansion of sweet beats and vocal textures that bring a whole new level of professional polish to their sound.
the nightmare of being at the gates metal on the strongest album of their unlikely second act, the swedish melodic death metal band lets their weirder side take the reins.

quietly blowing it hiss golden messenger folk/country despite its grand scope and good intentions, the latest album from m.c. taylor is the sound of an artist beginning to repeat himself: lite music for dark times.
dark in here the mountain goats rock a gloomier companion to 2020’s , john darnielle’s latest is patient, tense, and full of empathy.
rain’s break lucy gooch experimental the uk musician’s latest release is her most substantial work yet, adding a new sense of momentum to her ambient dream pop.
valdez birds of maya rock the noisy, cosmic trio of philadelphia diy lifers returns with an unearthed studio album. it’s an upgrade in fidelity and a shit-ton of fun.
nine sault experimental the elusive uk group’s third album in just over a year—to be made available online for only 99 days—renders black trauma in the eerie, sing-song cadences of children’s rhymes.
the last ride hrsmn rap once united in their status as industry misfits, the four-man supergroup has reassembled for a fan-service album that hinges upon a certain taste for bars.

get lost in the music ep ambar lucid rock the new jersey singer-songwriter’s five-song ep tries out different frames for her strikingly powerful voice, variously exploring reggaetón, futuristic americana, and psychedelic club pop.

who hurt you? ep jensen mcrae pop/r&b, rock the 23-year-old songwriter’s debut renders tales of young love and its quandaries with diaristic lyrics and anguished singing. she’s at her best when she’s plainspoken and immediate.
tezeta hailu mergia global a long-lost recording captures the ethiopian organist and his band at the hilton addis ababa in 1975, laying down deceptively breezy jazz songs steeped in nameless longing.

united states live laurie anderson experimental each sunday, pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. today we revisit laurie anderson’s grand theatrical treatise, an avant-garde piece comprised of sound sculpture and rock music, gender and social studies, philosophy and linguistics.

born this way the tenth anniversary lady gaga pop/r&b a decade ago, lady gaga created an enormous, bravura flex of electronic pop. an anniversary edition arrives with six “reimagined” versions of its songs by lgbtq+ artists and allies.

to enjoy is the only thing maple glider folk/country the melbourne-based songwriter’s debut is sparse and hypnotic, drawing connections between her experiences of leaving a relationship and leaving a religious upbringing.

get up sequences part one the go! team rock indie aesthetics have changed considerably in the past two decades, but the uk group is still throwing block parties for a utopia where time and genre collapse.

the stranger billy joel rock each sunday, pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. today we revisit billy joel’s greatest album, a sublimely crafted breakthrough that finds the meeting ground of the romantic and the mundane.

call me if you get lost tyler, the creator rap with dj drama in tow, tyler thrives in the realm of the rap mixtape, which allows him great freedom to explore every facet of his talent as a producer, writer, and vocalist.

the golden casket modest mouse rock the band’s first new album in six years is a procession of pinging, clanging, reverberating tactile pleasures, an inventive backdrop for isaac brock’s familiar blend of forced optimism and unforced paranoia.

mood valiant hiatus kaiyote rock, jazz no longer content with merely capturing the sound of four wildly talented musicians in a room together, the australian “future soul” group transforms on their vibrant and psychedelic third album.

soundness of mind liila experimental informed by their study of zen buddhism, danielle l. davis and steven whiteley create spacious, playful synthesizer melodies that push at the boundaries of what “meditative” music can be.

fate in seven lessons cold cave rock, electronic the post-punk band’s new seven-song collection owes a conspicuous debt to new order, and while the presentation begs to be called “spooky,” they’re having fun with it.

how much time it is between you and me? perila experimental, electronic recorded in a mountain village, the russian ambient musician’s debut album molds field recordings and hushed vocals into a form that’s richly textured and occasionally unsettling.
the turning wheel spellling experimental the myth-skewing, oakland-based artist is a chameleonic pop singer on her third album. whimsical and urgent, these are fairy tales meant to wake us up.

death of a cheerleader pom pom squad rock equally indebted to pioneering girl groups and her punk heroes, the new york singer-songwriter’s debut is a fiery exploration of love, anger, and coming-of-age.

fatigue l’rain experimental the brooklyn songwriter and sound artist’s second album is a kind of spiritual accounting, a swirling blend of orchestral groans and human whispers that evokes subconscious drift.

planet (i) squirrel flower rock on ella williams’ second album as squirrel flower, the road is a space of intimacy and disaster. her vivid songwriting and bright, searching voice bring both sides to life.

fat niggas need love too bfb da packman rap the flint-raised, houston-based rapper is known for his outrageous punchlines, but the engine of his raps is the personality-filled flow and the piano-driven michigan beat.
icons eli keszler experimental the composer and percussionist’s latest work is intricate and eerie, drawing attention to the small sounds that slip unnoticed in the chorus of a busy day.

escapades gaspard augé electronic the french musician’s giddily maximalist solo debut maintains the spirit of his group justice’s debut album; though inspired by ’70s prog and disco, it inhabits a singular universe of its own invention.

i know i’m funny haha faye webster folk/country there is so much depth to faye webster’s dazzling fourth album. it strikes a perfect balance between classic country stoicism and the sound of the saddest person you follow on social media.
home video lucy dacus rock addressing faith, young love, and nostalgia, the songwriter’s autobiographical third album is empathetic yet unsparing, catchy and finely crafted.

i still miss theresa benoit catch prichard rock the oakland band’s darkly psychedelic country folk suggests things on the verge of collapse. in march 2020, as singer sawyer gebauer unwittingly contracted covid-19, that was truer than anyone knew.
planet her doja cat rap, pop/r&b the third album from the extremely chaotic pop star, battle rapper, and edgelord is a thrilling ride that puts her eclecticism on full display.

stardust faith coloccia experimental mamiffer’s faith coloccia pressed her music—faintly liturgical songs and sound poems about self and motherhood—onto dubplates for turntablist philip jeck to smear and distort, to uncanny effect.

back of my mind h.e.r. pop/r&b the long-awaited debut from the lauded singer and guitarist is a fine showcase of her immense talent, though the constant balladeering doesn’t really capture what she does best.

year of the horse fucked up rock, metal on this elaborate concept album, initially released in monthly installments, the hardcore collective reclaims its status as the most fearless prog-punk band of them all.
disco! mike rap mike’s place in the vanguard of new york underground rap has invigorated him. it would be a stretch to call this album happy, but the atmosphere is undeniably warmer and more hopeful.
i love my mom indigo de souza rock the asheville songwriter’s newly reissued debut divulges her restless thoughts through folksy garage-pop that’s both vulnerable and fierce.
after the storm duwap kaine rap by blending everyday stories with spacey beats, the savannah rapper makes the mundane unexpectedly entrancing.
about you suzanne kraft electronic the amsterdam-based electronic musician trades his habitual house and ambient productions for blissful bedroom pop influenced by the shoegaze music of his youth.
hall of fame polo g rap the chicago rapper steps further into the mainstream on his third album, an ultimately hopeful exploration of how trauma manifests.

broken hearts & beauty sleep mykki blanco rap with flourishes of r&b, house, and funk, this exuberant and sweltering nine-track mini-album nails the transition from left-of-center cult favorite to bona fide diva.

the lion and the cobra sinéad o’connor rock each sunday, pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. today we revisit an uncompromising debut, pop music that ventures to the extremes of sound and emotion.

delusive tongue shifts - situation based compositions tibslc electronic his name is short for “the international billionaire’s secret love child,” and his ambient pieces are weightless as a sigh, splotchy as a bruise, both cozy and unsettling.
our extended play ep beabadoobee pop/r&b on a collaborative ep with the 1975’s matty healy and george daniel, the former tiktok phenom devotes herself to the ambiance of late-’90s guitar-pop.

the bbc sessions ep phosphorescent rock a set of intimate, in-studio performances from matthew houck’s creative breakthrough in the early 2010s reveals new meaning and intensity in his tough-hearted songs.
black metal 2 dean blunt experimental the sequel to 2014’s beloved is a brief but thrilling project from the mercurial artist, featuring the most approachable music of his career.

mother nature angélique kidjo pop/r&b collaborating with artists like mr eazi, burna boy, and sampa the great, the beninese icon builds upon a proudly pan-africanist musical vision that celebrates the power of community.
taste of love twice pop/r&b continuing to mature into a more grown-up image, the nine-member k-pop girl group balances self-contentment and romantic confidence with breezy summer thrill-seeking.

wary + strange amythyst kiah folk/country an intensely personal document, the tennessee singer and guitarist’s third album examines the realities of being a southern black lgbtq+ woman in songs both defiant and vulnerable.
blue weekend wolf alice rock the uk band’s enormous third album is pristine and emotionally extravagant, the platonic ideal for contemporary big-tent rock music.
troubled paradise slayyyter pop/r&b the proudly campy hyperpop singer’s debut is vibrant and ridiculous, for better or worse.

path of wellness sleater-kinney rock on their first self-produced record and first in 24 years without drummer janet weiss, sleater-kinney find pleasant comfort and not much else with down-the-middle rock tunes.

peace or love kings of convenience rock after a 12-year hiatus, the norwegian duo returns with an especially airbrushed take on easy-listening pop. at their best, the kings sound deceptively effortless, but the facade is sometimes too smooth.
finally ep elissa mielke folk/country the los angeles-via-toronto singer offers a finely wrought ep that showcases her oceanic voice and her austere songwriting.

limitless frame ulla experimental, electronic layering reverberating guitar melodies with subtle electronic sound design and foggy atmospheres, the ambient musician formerly known as ulla straus has a way of making the vaporous feel intimate.
slitherman activated rxk nephew rap the rochester rapper is at his best when he isn’t folding to the pressures of wider appeal or tightly-packaged collaborations on his latest project.

absence keith rowe experimental in this 2015 set marking his retirement from live performance, the veteran improvising guitarist explores the simpler, starker side of his abstract, purposefully formless music.
jordi maroon 5 rock maroon 5’s seventh album sets out to experiment beyond their comfort zone. it sounds like a band trying desperately to appeal to as many markets as possible.
ancient dreams in a modern land marina pop/r&b the unmistakably dramatic pop singer seeks the divine feminine, embracing a bold yet soft aesthetic that’s more effective than some of her lyrics.

butterfly 3000 king gizzard & the lizard wizard rock album number 18 was recorded in the band’s homes during the pandemic, and trades psych-rock blitzes for a finely-woven sprawl of synth programming and midi sequences.

sdm​-​la8​-​441​-​114​-​211 speed dealer moms electronic this unlikely electronic trio—featuring the chili peppers’ john frusciante, venetian snares’ aaron funk, and noise musician chris mcdonald—cherry-picks from 11 years of dazzlingly complex improvisations.
islomania islands rock on their first album in five years, nick thorburn’s ever-evolving band takes a pop-friendly turn. with neon synths and disco grooves, these songs are top 40 at heart.
culture iii migos rap the rap trio’s latest, like its predecessor, can become a slog and at times seems shoddily constructed. but at its best, the album is a callback to their inspired peak.
degrees of freedom found “blue” gene tyranny experimental the fearless work of the late avant-garde pianist is celebrated with a momentous new anthology, showcasing his immense talent and passion.

bombay a. r. rahman pop/r&b each sunday, pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. today we revisit the groundbreaking 1995 soundtrack that changed bollywood forever.
no gods no masters garbage rock with pop stars once again performing garish exaggerations of what seems like real personal trauma, shirley manson & co. have timed their return perfectly.
the life of pi’erre 5 pi’erre bourne rap the fifth installment of the rapper-producer’s long-running series lands closer to the sweet spot between beats and bars glimpsed on his previous effort.
mommy issues ep the narcotix experimental, folk/country with influences ranging from afrobeat to choral symphonies, the brooklyn-based group’s debut is bright and bursting with detail.

scuro chiaro alessandro cortini experimental built around his new custom synthesizer, the latest project from the electronic musician and nine inch nails member offers some of his liveliest music yet.

the rich are only defeated when running for their lives anthony joseph jazz backed by veteran jazz musicians and newer players, the trinidad-born, london-based poet summons spirits of the caribbean diaspora to ask what it might take to build a better world.

pool skee mask electronic compiling several years’ worth of material and spanning nearly two hours, the munich producer’s first full-length since 2018 feels cohesive, virtuosic, and thrillingly physical.

time machine fousheé pop/r&b after a viral sample made her feathery vocals famous, the singer-songwriter arrives on her own terms with a debut that flits effortlessly between guitar-based soul, alt-pop, and r&b.
hildegard hildegard experimental montreal musicians ouri and helena deland recorded their debut album together in eight days; the album’s eight songs feel like the diary of a gradual mind meld.

jubilee japanese breakfast rock michelle zauner embraces the spotlight and goes for the brass ring on her third album, a stylish and eclectic record that feels of the moment and also steeped in classic indie sensibilities.

picnic picnic electronic, experimental connecting kansas city and melbourne, picnic’s debut full-length is rounded out by a more than an hour’s worth of remixes by artists like huerco s. and dntel—a celebration of ambient music as a social phenomenon.

eternity dark0 electronic, rap drawing inspiration from narrative thrust of video-game soundtracks and sound design of trap and trance, the london producer revels in melodramatic builds and spaced-out bliss.

jade 玉观音 pan daijing experimental the berlin producer is a master of negative space and biomechanical sound, lacing her uneasy compositions with voices that excavate images of unceasing loneliness and longing.

light armour ep iglew electronic on his first release in six years, the uk producer trades the atmospheric grime of his debut for a more driving techno sound, lush enough for headphones but punchy enough to keep one foot on the dancefloor.

the codex necro anaal nathrakh metal the birmingham duo’s 2001 debut introduced their nightmarish hybrid of black metal, grindcore, and electronic music. on a new reissue, it sounds as extreme and subversive as ever.
